Bbq carrots $10 loved it! i hate carrots with a passion like i get mad if a dish has carrots in it but this was so flavorful. The carrots are not hard or supper hard n the flavor on them really does taste like ur at green street smoked meats the walnuts adds crunch wish there was more the dill adds freshness n the sauce was really good

Pinkerton Avacado salad $14 if u like refreshing dishes or drinks youll love this i didnt really care for it because it felt more like a palate cleanser wasnt really that flavorful it was a very subtle dish
wish the sauce was more rich the best part was the fried quiona put more plz

It comes with a salsa verde that is so tasty just put more plz and gooseberries cut through the richness the herbs added freshness best dish of the nite

Hake $26 i didnt like this. The fish was cooked perfectly crispy and supper moist the issue was the sauce did not taste like a curry it tasted like a very basic sauce the other components added good flavor like the clams added saltyness n the gooseberries added acidity plz give this curry flavor

The sirloin was cooked perfectly n had the best sear on it so it was really crispy the walnut ajika was amaizin it was like a pesto but with more of a nut flavor with more flavor the cheese added such a great flavor loved the straberries but they werent sweet enough making a sauce n making it more sweet would have been better

Pork belly $27 best dish of the nite the pork belly was the biggiest i ever seen n it was perfectly it was supper crispy on the outside n supper tender on the inside the peaches added sweetness so it was the perfect combination of sweet and savory the beans with the sauce added richness to the richness i wanted to order it again

Porchetta $33 this was the worst dish of the nite. It was extremely bitter n had a bunch of odd flavors that didnt work together. Chicories are extremely bitter so cooking the sauce in it was a bad idea because it made the sauce bitter then theres chicories on the plat which adds to it the black berries were really acidic so it added a weird tart flavor. Then this dish need a crunch factor badly the pork was tender but not that flaborful

Oprah cake 12$ if u love tiramisu youll love this i didnt like it because there was to much of a coffee flavor it overwhelmed everything else

Pros:
Dishes are all well-balanced in flavor, texture, and saltiness
Bread is amazing
Chefs are not afraid to use less conventional meats like chicken liver and pork rinds--expect something interesting on the menu
Picnic plate had uniquely pickled cauliflower and mouthwatering bread and spread
Poached eggs were cooked well, and prosciutto and arugula paired perfectly

Cons:
Appetizers tasted good but I'd rather save my money for the entrees

Recs:
Order the picnic plate and an extra order of bread to share between two people
Visit Sawada for coffee

Delicious food, no doubt. But one of the best restaurants in Chicago? I'm not sure it quite lives up to the hype, in my humble opinion...

...which is shared by several other people I know...

Anyways, I'll start with a couple of the issues we had. First, the notion of food coming out when it was ready was never explained to us. So, we ordered like a normal restaurant, with appetizers then main courses for each of us. It was frustrating that each of our mains came out at different times, so essentially one of us was eating at a time. The other issue was that dessert took a while, and our server, who was fantastic besides that aforementioned lack of explanation, was clearly frustrated. It was my mom's birthday, and it took forever to get her candle out to the table.

Now that those are out of the way, the food was very tasty. Fortunately for you readers, I was able to taste all of the dishes. Appetizers were the bbq carrots, beets, and shishito peppers. The flavors in all three were great - my personal favorite was the beets. The carrots aren't super soft - some of my family liked it better that way, while I would have preferred a bit softer. I'm honestly not a huge pepper fan, but the rest of the flavors were really delicious in that dish.

For mains, we ordered mussels, halibut, beef tongue and sirloin. Again, all delicious. The sauce the mussels were bathed in was amazing, and it was great that they serve it with a fresh sourdough baguette to dip. The halibut was sublime, tender with a perfect sear on the outside. The beef tongue was also great, though maybe my least favorite of the bunch. The sirloin, which was my main, may have been my favorite. The tzatziki and feta really gave it a unique Mediterranean twist, and it was perfectly cooked.

The desserts were overall the most underwhelming part of the meal. As usual, I ordered well, but the others were not as well loved by the group. The worst was the strawberry mint sorbet. The mint was totally overpowering, and it was tough to taste the strawberry at all. My dad ordered the waffle, and added the ice cream. The weird thing about that is if you add the ice cream, they take away the fruit preserves. It was decent, but not worth getting at such a good place. The cajeta tart was very good, probably the second best dessert. The best dessert was the rhubarb crostata. It was like a warm apple strudel a la mode, but with unique flavors that set it apart. We made sure to scrape all of the crust off the skillet, so as not to leave any leftovers.

Overall, it was a very good meal, but I've had better non-Michelin Starred meals in Chicago. I'll also say if you have both carnivores and vegetarians in your group, this is a very solid compromise.

I want to preface this by saying that I was feeling extremely under the weather when we had dinner here and this might've impeded my tasting abilities and my drinking.

We had reservations about a week out for a party of 5. We were sat in one of the long communal tables. These actually were big enough that you didn't feel you were soaking in the conversation from the party next to you. The interior was cool; lots of hanging lights, wooden tables and chairs, and some high-tops on the side. A few of us had gotten dinner there in the past so they had many recommendations. We got way too much food and the waitress even said so.

The plates were brought out one or two at a time and they're all designed to be shared family style. Nothing really stood out to me except for the bread + cheese platter. The ham was actually also pretty good, but I was expecting to love the pasta or the carrots. Everyone loved the carrots, so I'm really thinking that the hype went over my head because I was sick. It's also pretty pricey for what it was. They had the spicy pork skin w/ flakes of spices on them and all I could think was, "I could find this at a grocery store in queens!" Shame that I was in a funk all night, but I'd really like to come back and confirm that it was my sinuses and my throat to be blamed.

Genuinely enjoyed eating at The Publican. I drove here with my sister. We valet the car ($12). We had a reservation and got seated right away (and there was a crazy long line waiting to be seated)
The place was buzzing. The noise was very high, like in a market place . Our waiter checked in with us right away. We decided pretty quick on what to have: marinated beet salad and the pork shoulder.
The beet salad was fresh, a bit tangy, and well balanced with farro and feta cheese, finished with fresh herbs (the fresh dill was the perfect finish). The pork shoulder was cooked to perfection. Incredible moist and easily coming apart but still holding its shape.
Service was impeccable, food was just right, ambiance matched the neighborhood, and the feeling I left with was that of returning soon.
PS: kid friendly place (high chairs and the women's bathroom to the far right has a changing table).

Amazed that they have maintained their quality.  We only go with 4 or more people because when we go with two it's less fun (less capacity for sharing).  We were there on a busy Saturday night.  It is loud so if you have issues with that, beware :)

We had our usual chicken dinner. It was still good but the chicken was a little less moist than usual. Great fries and flavor on the chicken.  Always love the pickles.  Had the three ham tasting dish. Always delight and this was no exception.

Because there was a long pause they brought us a complimentary dish of mussels and halibut. The mussels were clean and tender and the halibut delicious. We had not even complained about the wait--they just noticed and brought it as an apology. That's classy service :)  The flank steak dish was good too but I'm not sure because my husband and daughter were not great at sharing :)

Drinks were delicious too.

This is probably one of my favorite brunch places in West Loop. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The food is flavorful and the service is great. We were able to get one of the booths and it was nice and intimate. We did five dishes for four people and it worked out perfectly. Pork Schnitzel was my favorite.

Bread was tasty. As was butter. Good drinks. Liked the cauliflower. And the cookie dessert. No espresso though. Pork and chicken were fairly dry. Carrots were underdone. Disappointed versus what I was expecting.

Oh man! If you love pork and can't afford to go The Publican for dinner, brunch is definitely the way to go here! The porchetta melted in my mouth. It was juicy, tender and full of flavor. It paired perfectly with the cornbread underneath the sunny side eggs. Breaking the egg yolk over the porchetta and corn bread = ultimate savory. And brunch is never complete for me without a side of hash browns. The crunch from the perfectly toasted hash browns was divine!

pics.caption: Porchetta with Hash Browns // corn bread, calabrian chile, sungold tomatoes, and sunny side eggs

review.des:
Strictly from a food perspective, The Publican in Chicago's hopping Fulton Market would be a winner.  We were four and we all shared a trio of ham (the Serrano was particularly good), some seafood, chicken, oysters, carrots, and tomatoes.  Everything was super-delicious.  So too was the berry cobbler we had for dessert. No complaints there ... but a restaurant is more than food of course.

So as to the rest of the evening ... the hostesses were incompetent.  There's no other word for it.  We ended up waiting twice, first for our table outside which was "ready" but we still waited about ten minutes.  We'd just gotten off a (late) plane, our body clocks were an hour ahead, and we were hungry, so this was particularly annoying.  Then, after it started to rain, we came back inside and waited again even though there were several empty tables.  Not impressive.  It was also unimpressive that there were insufficient umbrellas outside for the rain. It's not as if rain is unusual in the summer in Chicago (more like it happens all the time).  And once inside, the acoustics were awful.  I could barely hear my dining companions.  Finally, there was no decaf espresso.  

Other than a long wait to take our order, the waitress was sweet.  Still, I'd not likely go back gIven the plethora of other options in the area.

Had to come to Chicago on business and called my daughter who is always traveling and said "seafood" She replies "Got you dad". The Publican  was  amazing the service perfection and the food OMG. Make a stop you  wont regret it
Great spot in the meat packing district of Chicago. This place is a great spot for local beers and fresh food, cooked to order. Staff was really great as wll

Right off the popular Randolph strip, the Publican still exudes the hip cool-kid, yet professional, vibes. The menu changes and offers a really good assortment of American Contemporary food that is delectable to the foodie but presented in a way that will not frighten a picky eater, which is a truly remarkable balance to strike. In addition, compared to its peers, I would say the Publican offers a great meal at a GREAT price point.
Expect communal eating that makes it a fun atmosphere - good for groups of 2-6.

it also has the benefit of being slightly removed from Randolph so there is hopes of finding a table in LESS THAN THREE HOURS (shout out to Au Cheval).

*Disclaimer* if you cannot tell already, this is my favorite restaurant.

The Publican is one of the more unique places I've dined at. The interior is super interesting. We had a reservation at 5:30PM and were promptly seated when we arrived at a section of the long tables they have for communal dining. Around the walls of the restaurant are booths that are completely enclosed by tall swinging doors. The set up reminded me of medieval dining halls.

Bf and I opted to get 2 small plates and 2 larger plates like our waiter suggested. We ordered the sweet corn, chicken liver pate, aged sirloin, and cuttlefish ink pasta. Everything is meant to be shared. We loved the chicken liver pate, super creamy and came with perfectly crisp bread slices. The cuttle ink pasta was my favorite. Aged sirloin was pretty good too but a little too sweet for my liking. Surprisingly, our sweet corn came last and the portion was tiny! It was good but probably not worth the price.

Overall, I had a great experience here. If I am ever back in Chicago again, I would definitely come back to try more of their dishes.

This is one of those family seating type of places. So you will most likely sit very closely to other parties. Around 9:15pm it was still busy, but not a long wait compared to other places in the area.

Brussels Sprouts - I never had brussels sprouts shredded so it was different. The dressing on it was light and citrusy

Charcuterie Plate - Mix of everything which was good! The pate was delicious!

Mussels - Fresh and tasty, I could have eaten these all day

Half Farm Chicken - It took a while for it to come out. Flavor was kind of there. The good tender parts were really good, then there were some dry pieces that lacked

This has been on my list of "go-to" places in Chicago. I finally had the chance to go on my birthday. The restaurant is really nice and they even have patio seating options.

Started off with the pork rinds. They were realllyyy good and satisfying as an appetizer. The menu items are meant to be shared family style. My boyfriend and I decided to order 2 plates each for us to try. I got the mussels and the country style rib. The mussels broth was flavorful and light. The country rib was great. It had a very asian kick to it with lemon grass and soy sauce flavors. The peaches were a sweet addition. My boyfriend ordered the sirloin and the pork belly. The pork belly was GONE in a minute. It melted in your mouth and the ricotta it came in was perfection. The sirloin was a dish that we didn't really care for. It was kinda charred and salty but the sirloin is meant to be charred. We weren't too keen on that. However, everything else exceeded our expectations. The food was amazing and the staff was super friendly. Definitely recommend this place and we will be back :)

The buttermilk cheesecake sounds great, what you get is this IKEA deconstructed looking like dessert. There's ton of liquid sauce and in that sauce is the tiny portion of the cheesecake part. It was pretty disappointing and I felt like it was trying to recreate the wheel while being bit misleading.

We got the farm chicken, I felt this was overpriced for what I got and had me comparing it to much cheaper chicken dishes that I've had and enjoyed far more in the past. It's $35 for the whole one, you do get some frites and sausage with it, but it wasn't worth it in my opinion.

A so so experience for me, others seem to love it here and they do serve some different and unique items. It's mostly highly regarded here from what I read but I wasn't the biggest fan.

The Publican is a large gastropub with a unique seating arrangement - private booths along the perimeter, and this large communal wooden table with seats on both sides that wrap around in a large square around the restaurant.  Its a loud and fun environment, and service was quick and attentive.  We had a pretty good dinner here - one half-flawed dish but four very solid dishes.  3.5 stars but rounding to 4 for the great service.

Let's start with the half-flawed dish.  There were artwork of really, really chubby pigs adorning the walls.  It should have been a sign to order their pork dishes!  I ordered instead their half Farm Chicken which turned out to be half good.  Dark meat was tender, moist, seasoned, and great smokiness (5 stars).  Breast meat - seasoned, smokey, but dry like sawdust. (2 stars).  The rest of the sides of frites and summer sausage were actually good, so 3 stars overall.

The other dishes were very good:

* Half Dozen Oysters: Three from Vancouver BC, three from New England.  All very fresh and briny. (5 stars)
* Strawberry Salad: I like the addition of hazelnuts for crunch and the creamy cheesiness mixed with the sweet, ripe berries (4 stars)
* BBQ Carrots: Wow, the use of fresh dill really adds a nice tart flavor to the char-grilled carrots, which are sweet.  They added pecans for crunchiness! (4 stars)
* White Bass: Large filet roasted with clams, green chile broth, and fregula. Solid dish. (4 stars)
* Fulton Mess: This dessert is on the lighter side, with fresh raspberries, and lemon-vanilla meringue with the texture and taste like yogurt. (4 stars)

Portions are huge here.  Maybe best to order a few veggie apps and then either split a meat entree or order two seafood entrees.  I would not recommend the Farm Chicken, though surprisingly lots of them were getting ordered tonight.

pics.caption: Fulton Mess - Raspberries with vanilla-lemon meringue.  Similar to yogurt (4 stars)
Roasted White Sea Bass with clams, green chile broth, fregula (4 stars)
Half Farm Chicken with summer sausage and lotsa fries.  Dark meat awesome, but white meat dry like sawdust!

review.des:
Okay this was AMAZING. We went for brunch on St. Patrick's Day and enjoyed coffee, pork and potatoes, thick cut bacon, and a Belgian waffle. I capped my meal off with a peppermint tea and it was so nice to sip it and be surrounded by loved ones in such a pretty space. The only not-so-great item we ordered was the chocolate pastry which I felt was a little dry.

The giant pig art is a riot, the different patterned plates were beautiful, and I really like the communal seating. The only odd thing we noticed was the boxed-in booths with swinging doors. We couldn't figure out their purpose or benefit and thought they concealed booths that were in need of repair.

Service was kind and kept the coffee coming. Bathrooms were clean, nongendered (woop!), and had neat Hogwarts-looking sinks.

A fascinating and visually interesting place to have brunch with friends.

Came here for dinner on a Thursday night while visiting Chicago. The place has a trendy hipstery feel. Most of the dishes are very meat-centric. It's not the best place to find healthy options as even the vegetables on the menu seemed to be drenched in butter and salt but I guess one doesn't come to a place like this to eat healthy. We ordered a variety of small plates and everything was pretty good. I particularly like the salmon and the beets plate. The beer list seemed to emphasize European style beers and not too many IPAs which happen to be my favorite. The atmosphere was noisy and the booths have a strange door that closes to resemble a pig pen which made me a bit claustrophobic. Overall I'd recommend it if you're looking for a trendy place with hearty, meaty dishes.

I feel like Chicago is becoming my second home since I come here at least one week a month. Since Chicago is pretty much a foodie paradise, I get to try different cuisines and restaurants with each trip.

Recently we tried the Purple Pig and it was stellar. We wanted to try something with a similar vibe, shareable plates and a great menu. This place delivers on all fronts.

Before I get into the food, the area where The Publican is located is going through a renaissance. There's a ton of construction, and this looks like it will be a super place to live.

Okay, back to the food. This really is a 4.5 star place, with nearly perfect food, friendly staff and cool vibe.  The menu changes regularly, but they always have their standard cured meats, which I hear they offer in smaller and larger serving sizes or you can order a charcuterie plate with a few options. We decided to try the Serrano ham since I haven't had any since I was in Spain. The ham came with goat butter and bread, but I just focused on the ham. It was super.

We also settled on spicy pork rinds, pork belly, corn, fried cauliflower and green chile sausage. The spicy pork rinds were fine, but we ended up just eating one or two. To be honest, they were good but not much better than what you can buy at the grocery. The green chile sausage was a high point for me. Wow! This was good. It came with a squash caponata, Swiss chard, pine nuts and a cheese called ubriaco rosso. It was superb. The pork belly was also super.  They are so confident in its tenderness that they serve it with just a spoon.  Yep, it's that tender! The cauliflower to me was too sweet and could use some acid, but wow was it crispy. It's so hard to fry vegetables well, and this was crispy. The corn was the last item we received and it was a nice way to end. It had shishito pepper, pecorino, basil and crispy fried shallots.

The Publican also has a nice wine, beer and cocktail menu. I ordered the veltliner, which is a white wine from Austria. It was good.

I really like The Publican with its communal tables and great food. If I lived nearby, I'd come here often for a great meal and an opportunity to meet my neighbors.

I don't know what else to say besides that the Publican was by far the best brunch spot. If you're visiting Chicago, this place is a must. Not only is the food and coffee incredible, but the atmosphere makes t great for any occasion. The menu not only offers a unique option of brunch plates, but is also diverse enough for everyone to enjoy.

Great service and definitely great food! I heard of this place through the traveling channel and I have to say, it's definitely worth the try. From the carrot plate, to the bread and cheese spread, to the half chicken and fries, everything was simply amazing. Our waiter was attentive and welcoming. Thank you for the great experience! We'll definitely be back

pics.caption: Cheesy Bread was to die for! Great recommendation on behalf of our waiter

review.des: Came here for the second time for a short weekend visit to Chicago. Since I had such a great time a couple years ago, I made sure to take my friends here to have them experience the same awesome time I had. We made reservations ahead of time on a Sunday, so there was no wait. Service is great as always. Servers and hosts were very friendly and accommodating. Since we had a group of 7, we decided to order as food items off the menu as we could to share. Their food is just so well-made, created and plated. Flavors and textures are all on point. I had the bbq duck confit, and public bacon (which is the superstar small plate for everyone everytime). I also had a bite of the hashbrowns, veggie egg scramble, and belgian waffles. All were wonderful. No complaints. Will be back again for more great food and company. And that Bacon! Mmmm.

On another recommendation we heard that this was the place to come for oysters, living in the Pacific Northwest raw oysters are one of the bases for our food pyramid so had to come and check them out.  Had a good selection and also they had a wonderful selection of local craft and imported beer. On Untappd I am close to 3000 unique beers and even I was able to find a few I had not tried yet.  Communal table seating so be aware of that, and the atmosphere is quite loud. but we were prepared for that and it didn't affect the taste of the food or beverages any, so all was well.

We had high expectations for this place! The food was just okay. My friend got the brioche French toast, whose tartness was just overpowering. It was too sweet and tasted as if it had been sitting out for a bit before it was brought to the table. Something about mixing chocolate, raspberry and lemon curd didn't quite make sense to our palates. I got the "steak and eggs" equivalent. The steak was tender and good, but the dish as a whole was underwhelming. Plus, it was small. We shared the bacon, which was okay. We also shared the pecan sticky bun which looked delicious but was not as soft or moist as I had hoped. The coffee was also very fruity, so if this isn't your style, I'd save the money to go towards another great cup of coffee near by! Our waitress was also kind of rude. She walked away as my friend was in the middle of explaining her credit card situation. Also, When we asked her for recommendations, she practically listed everything on the menu.
Otherwise, the service was great. Water and coffee were always refilled by other kind staff members. The host and hostess were very friendly, too!
All in all, I wouldn't recommend this place. We were definitely let down by our meal.

Place came highly recommended and finally got the chance to try this place on the very busiest time on the weekend... saturday brunch. I never think highly of brunch or breakfast food as it's just all too simple. I mean i dont know how much more u can elevate and be creative with eggs and bacon to 5 star ratings. But yeah, this place just shut me up as i had the best bacon i could ever imagine and the eggs are the fluffiest i have ever had. The eggs felt like a nice hug on my tongue. Toast was just a wee bit burnt, i prefer my toast lightly toasted but it was my bad for not requesting.

I dig the communal seating and even though it was crazy busy, i did get the service that i expected. Would highly recommended this place

Long community tables, huge beer stines, and no waiter left untattooed, this place brings you back to the great American Dining Halls of the past. Vegetarians good luck eating here. Meat on meat. Appetizers: The bbq carrots make carrots somehow interesting, the brussel sprouts have an unexpectedly light and tangy flavor profile, and the cauliflower is a wonderful yummy mush. I found the farm chicken to be rather unexciting and wouldn't recommend. The dry-aged sirloin however is fantastic and juicy. Our server was an incredibly sweet and helpful guy. Come here if you are looking for a unique and loud experience!

Great concept and great food.

If you've never been, it's a community table concept, so you are seated next to other people or groups on a very large / long table. If you have 4 or more people you may get a private booth, but there aren't many of those.

You don't actually share meals with the other groups.  It's a normal menu and everyone orders individual meals.

The food is amazing.  It's a twist to regular food, so they infuse the meals with ingredients that hit your tongue like no other.  Sometimes you ask what was in it as you try to recognize the ingredients.

Everything we tried was good.  We got the red wine poached eggs.  As you might guess, the eggs are red.  It still looks good, but it tastes amazing.  Such a good flavor combination.

We tried something I believe was called moca roca, which was a couple of sausages with potatoes and a fried egg.  Also very good.

We ended with a pecan muffin that we shared.  It was warm and goo eeee.

I highly recommend trying this place.

This place! Came for dinner and as to be expected, it was really good. The brunch though is worth the longer review. We had the Saturday brunch which was a more limited menu but it was incredible!! Our group had a bunch of the items so I tried the mushroom eggs, waffles, biscuits, salad and more. The mushroom egg dish and biscuit with jam and clotted cream was SO GOOD. The flavors were outstanding and I can't wait to come back to try the expanded brunch Sunday menu!

We decided to come here because we saw so many great reviews, but ended being really disappointed by the food. ):

The decor is lovely, as well as the service. The center has communal tables, whereas the sides have cute booths with a door to swing shut so that it's like you're in a pen!

We ordered 4 dishes-- a crab salad, the johnnycake, a blueberry muffin with their blueberry jam, and the crispy potatoes + sunnyside eggs.

The crab salad was fine, but it's just kinda pricey for what it is. Actually, everything was pricey for what it was. Anyway, for this specific dish, you don't get a lot of crab...I mean I know seafood is expensive, but c'mon, more than a sprinkle would be nice (slight exaggeration here, but seriously, minimal crab).

The johnnycake...what can I say. A medley of unharmonious flavors. Again, you don't get a whole lot of meat (baby sprinkles of bacon), and the whole dish is just too sweet-- just drenched in a weird syrup that tasted really odd. Like you try it and you're like "I've never tasted anything like this before and I'm not sure if I like it or not, but I'm leaning more toward not liking it." Also, the eggs weren't soft, they were overdone (I know-- omg she's just nitpicking at this point).

Blueberry muffin-- in short, all in all way too sweet, dish desperately needed some acidity to cut the sugar. Muffin tasted like it could've been store bought. Maybe the jam too. Who knows?

The only saving grace were the crispy potatoes. Beautifully crisp and seasoned. Didn't care for the dijonnaise though, just tasted like mayonnaise.

On the bright side, you do get free coffee refills!

The Publican is designed like a German beer hall with long communal tables so come prepared to get cozy with strangers.

They are known for their oysters, pork and beer and that's exactly what we ordered plus a few other dishes. Everything was delicious! Chef's choice oysters were fresh. Striped bass, though small, packed a lot of flavor. Mussels were juicy and paired well with a broth that I slurped right up. I don't usually like beef tongue but it was undoubtedly one of my favorite dishes, along with the pork belly. Both meat dishes literally melt in your mouth. The half order of chicken came last, at which point all three of us were already really full so we didn't get to appreciate it as much. The half order was actually a significant portion so unless you're sharing with a large group of friends, stick with the half.

I thought this place was very pricey as our bill for three came out to be $300 with tip so I would recommend you save The Publican for a special occasion!

In making my tour of Chicago food classics, I had to bring my parents back to The Publican.

Service & atmosphere: the space is less stuffy than some other Fulton Market places, with communal seating, warm wood paneling, and pig pen-like booth seats. Our service was a little weird this time around: when my mom asked for something like a Belgian pilsner (think Stella Artois), our waiter said that Belgium didn't make pilsners...which was wrong, but whatever. But then our charcuterie came out very last after appetizers and our main dishes, which the waiter tried to rationalize by saying the plates came out when they were ready and he thought it would be better suited with our bigger dishes (which were pork belly and beef tongue), which also wasn't the greatest.

Food: nevertheless, I care much more about the food than service. We ordered bread with salted butter, beets, butter lettuce, ham tasting, beef tongue, and pork belly. You can't go wrong with bread and butter, the lettuce with crispy pig ear was delicious, and the pork belly with dill was good, though not exactly what we had been expecting. The stars were absolutely the beets and beef tongue. The beets with kale, burrata, balsamic, and walnuts was so well balanced- creamy, tangy, sharp with the nuts for texture, I'd eat beets more if they came like this! The beef tongue was cubed and atop sesame toast. Oh my god it was so juicy, tender, and flavorful.

Overall, I'm glad we came back and I would definitely recommend it to anyone. I would just hope they get a different server :)

pics.caption: Beef tongue on top of sesame toast- GET THIS TOO

review.des:
I came for brunch on a Sunday and I had high expectations for the $7 burton's maple syrup-braised publican bacon. It was alright. The bacon was a little burnt on the edges so it was hard to chew the ends. I don't think I would order it again. I think the thick-cut bacon at Au Cheval is better than this one.

I ordered the Cajun sausage and it was flavorful! Each bite was so good and I can taste the Calabrian child aioli. It went well with the waxman potato and the sunny side up egg that came with the dish. The combination of everything on the plate balanced each other out. The portion of the dish was not small or big. It was about right and I left feeling "satisfied" full.

pics.caption: The $7 burton's maple syrup-braised publican bacon

review.des:
Came here for brunch with a group of 9 people and a reservation and they accommodated us really well and fairly quickly! The service was top notch, and the food was absolutely delicious.

Pros
- Food
- Service
- Vibe / Atmosphere
- Hash browns
- Red wine poached eggs

Cons
- Possibility of community-style seating (if you're not into that)
- $5 bottomless coffee (unless you know you're going to down more than one cup)

We all had a great time, and everyone was really happy with what they ordered. I was left being amazed that I hadn't eaten here before! I absolutely want to come back here again for another round of brunch!

pics.caption: Red Wine Poached Eggs & BBQ Brisket

review.des: This place knows how to do pork right - bacon (SOOO GOOD, best we ever had), capicola (open face sandwich) and pork rinds. This is the perfect brunch place!

Not too many vegetarian options, but the waffle was delicious! Light, flaky and served with jam. I was looking for syrup, but the jam combo pleasantly surprised me! Sadly, the portions are fairly tiny and I wish I had ordered more food, but the service was very quick.

If you're a party of 2 - be prepared to sit communal style! The booths are for primarily for parties 4+.

We went to the Publican for brunch on a weekend visit to Chicago.  It was recommended to us from a local.  The restaurant had a nice, comfortable atmosphere.  It was decorated nicely and had very pretty and clean restrooms.  

We had made a reservation through open table for six and we didn't have to wait.  They had our table ready to go.  The service was good; I think we had a few different people helping us.    The food didn't seem to take very long also.

First of all, the coffee was perfect; not too strong, but not too weak.  We shared a Belgian waffle for the table.  The waffle was crispy, which was unexpected.  I might have been disappointed if I had gotten that as my meal though.  It was nice to have a little taste, and the honey butter and jam were so good.  I chose the red wine poached eggs with Bearnaise, prosciutto, and a grilled baguette.  The dish also had some arugula with some kind of vinaigrette.  Everything was delicious.  I had my Bearnaise on the side and that added a lot of extra flavor along with the arugula.  We also shared a plate of the grilled baguette with house-made nutella, which was fantastic.  

It was a little pricey, but I think it was worth it.  Overall, I enjoyed the coffee and brunch at The Publican.

pics.caption: Red wine poached eggs on a grilled baguette with Bearnaise sauce, prosciutto, and arugula on the side.

review.des: Some of the reviews are stellar, so thought we'd check it out.  The venue is undeniably a fun place, lots of noise and crowded.  The dining areas consist of a bar area, a large common dining table and individual booths enclosed by swinging doors.  Somewhat odd, but that's the décor.  The four of us decided to go with the sampling menu rather than having to choose from the extensive menu.  The main thing I wanted to try were the pork bellies, which I must say were very good...could use a bit more fat, but the flavors were great.  As expected a parade of dishes came out covering the spectrum of the menu and all were interesting.  Oddly, the only iffy item was the porchetta which was not done well.   Drinks were well made and the service from our server Gio,  was excellent.

Amazing food! The wait was a bit long, but we didn't have reservations. The food was totally worth the wait though. I just thought the sitting arrangements to be a bit weird, since we shared a table with other people

Avocado salad and desserts were AMAZING. The oysters were good too.

But the Redfin crudo was tiiiiiny. It was good, but just a bit pricey. The country rib was really tough and we only got the stems for the broccolini, 1-2 florets.

Overall tasty, good atmosphere. This place is definitely on the pricey side and their portions are smaller - and I'm almost always ok with small portions, but these were a bit too small for their price point.

pics.caption: Chocolate creme pie. Also dank. Loved the darkness/bittery, but creamy consistency of the chocolate
Avocado salad; the texture and taste of it was amazing! Recommend.
Country rib. Biggest disappointment. Dry, almost no florets

review.des:
I had dinner with a friend here tonight, and it was so good that I felt compelled to write this review ASAP while it was fresh in my delighted memory.  I made the reservation yesterday and was able to snag one for 7:15 pm (on a Wednesday, but still!).   I showed up around 6:50 this evening and checked in with the hostess, who was very pleasant.  She offered me a spot at a table to have a drink while I waited for my friend.  I was seated at a communal table for four near the kitchen.  As I waited for my friend, another diner who was also waiting for their friend joined me at my table, and almost immediately someone came over with glasses of water and menus.  

My friend arrived and our server, Geo, asked us if we wanted to remain at the high table near the kitchen or if we wanted to move to a low table.  We opted to stay where we were.  After ordering our drinks we perused the menu and decided to start with a half dozen chef's choice oysters and a half plate of charcuterie.  My mind was blown by the charcuterie.  I am a fan of charcuterie and have tried it at various places back in SF and around Chicago, including Purple Pig (yum), but this was phenomenal.  My friend isn't the most adventurous eater, but I convinced him to try the harissa pate and the head cheese (I didn't bother explaining what head cheese is), but we both really liked it.

We also ordered the fried broccolini, the sand dabs, and an off-the-menu rib eye.  The sand dabs were brought out first, presented in an aesthetically pleasing fashion, and then our server filleted them and deboned them before our eyes.  The cooked grapes that were served with this dish added a delectable element of sweetness, and the fish was flaky and flavorful.  We were both so delighted by the food and service at this point that we decided to buy the kitchen a six pack.  Yes, you read that right, you can buy the kitchen a six pack of beer for $10.  Maybe you are wondering why you'd buy the people cooking your food a beer, but ask yourself why wouldn't you?  You can see into the kitchen if you sit in the back, and everyone in their is busting their butt to prepare beautifully presented and exceptionally tasty food.

Next up was he broccolini came out next, and we cleared that plate, too.  Imagine something way better than a fried vegetable:  it was served on top of a semi-sweet romesco along with little cubes of soft, fried cheese.  Last of the savory dishes was the rib eye, which was served medium rare with greens and ramps.  We each ate a slice of the meat and decided to have the rest boxed up so we could indulge in dessert.  

I opted for the small French press of coffee and asked about the rhubarb strudel.  I ended up ordering a scoop of the mint ice cream.  Keep in mind these ice creams are made in-house with fresh ingredients.  If you like weak mint ice cream from Baskin Robbins, then maybe this mint chip ice cream won't be for you.  I cannot describe it well enough, but imagine a lightly sweetened creamy scoop of frozen  cream packing a punch of very fresh mint!  To my delight the next thing brought over to our table was a cookie jar.  I thought I was told I could pick one cookie, but then I realized the whole contents of the jar was ours' to take.  Damn right I took those cookies to-go (there's an amazing horchata rice krispy treat in there).

I want to give a special shout out to our server, Geo.  While everyone that refilled our waters and brought us our dishes was attentive, Geo answered every single one of my copious questions as if we were buddies.  There was no air of pretentiousness about him or any of the people working at The Publican.  I had several questions about how the fish dishes were prepared and he had excellent recommendations as well, so thanks Geo!

pics.caption: Incredible sand dabs. So good it will make you do the dab.

review.des:
Was visiting a friend in Chicago and asked to go out to boujee brunch. The Publican delivered.

I ordered the buttermilk chicken and was not even a little bit sorry for getting chicken at a nice restaurant !! It was delicious. The thick cut bacon was so good but the portion is pitifully small and it's a bit too fatty for my taste.

Communal seating was OK, but I didn't get those boujee brunch vibes from the ambience.

My experience at the Publican was slightly confusing.  The food was very good and had the smaller portions you'd expect from a place with exquisite, higher-end food. The bathrooms (which were very cool, high-ceiling individual stalls) also felt super fancy, but the main atmosphere felt communal and rustic and did not match the prices of the food. It kind of felt like the restaurant was having an identity crisis.  I enjoyed the food but would probably not go back.
Also about the food: I had the lemon curd poppyseed donut and it was not what I expected but was surprisingly good!

From the selection of drinks paired with various aspects of the menu. Our server was totally on point and beyond knowledgeable.

Atmosphere: family orientated, somewhat loud, but once your seated it provides you the ability to have a real conversation without worry about interrupting anyone.

Staff: friendly, KNOWLEDGEABLE, and invested in your experience.

Food: simple but amazing, intentional in all aspects of taste, presentation, and total experience.

Finally made it to the Publican! Another restaurant off of the bucket list. It did not disappoint. We had wayyyy too much food everything from the pork rinds, apple salad, squash to lamb, chicken and fish, then dessert. Pure gluttony. The service was top notch and I loved how casual and comfortable everyone was. No pretense.

Wow. I love this place. I love the idea of communal table but they won't put you right next to another couple. I love their creative take on food. Highly recommend the bacon, Johnny cake, and pork rinds! I love the service here as well! The people here had so much good vibe I wish I can live in Chicago! Next time we are in touch we will definitely come by again! Keep up with the good vibe!

pics.caption: Johnny Cake, taste like blueberry muffin with savory duck! Nom nom nom!
Omg.. it's like honey ham for Thanksgiving but it's bacon!

review.des:
This place is amazing, the service is always fantastic.  I do not know what they do to their chicken, but I have no words to describe how juicy  it is and the flavor is so good!

We like to visit this place when we have to entertain customers during shows in Chicago, because we know we will always be able to have the perfect experience.  

The first time I visited this place was a recommendation from a Chef that know the Chef Paul Kahan and has been a great experience since then.

Congratulations to those carnivores, you've got Publican! Proudly being the owner of numerous JB foundation award winners/nominates, Publican really has a deep thought in making that slice of meat juicy and delicious.

We came in around an hour early, and was being told that there was no way to get seated before our reservation time (due to its popularity), yet got real lucky and were seated about 20 min later.

The long communal table was probably the first thing one needs to accommodate - people were literary just sitting next to each other. Service was pretty slow I would say, but I would not complain too much on that..Food was the flawless - crispy pork rinds, juicy sugar bacon slices, and tender pork cutlet paired with two fried egg sitting nicely on top - I could not think of a better way to kick off my morning!

Don't forget to give a try on their renown pecan sticky bun, and just forget about counting calories at the time being! It was just a heaven.

We came to the Publican for brunch. Apparently the menu changes so you may not have the same options available!

We got the Spicy Pork Rinds (3/5) to share.
The hash browns (3/5) were a little too greasy.
The Belgian waffles (4/5) are just plain waffles and a small portion. You may need to order something in addition if you choose this as your main.
The red wine poached eggs (4/5) are quite good.
The smoked pork shoulder (5/5) was excellent and the peanuts were a nice touch.

The only downside to our experience was the service which was a little slow (I got my meal 5 minutes after everyone else at the table even though a few others ordered the same thing).

Came here during my bachelorette weekend! The biggest impression this restaurant made on me was the decor, which was super unique, with wood everywhere and interestingly styled booths. The food.... tbh I don't really remember and it was only about a month ago.

I got the yorkshire pudding with smoked ham, cheddar, eggs, and microgreens. I was excited to try a new breakfast food kind of thing, because it sounded like it would have a great texture balance and flavor balance with the ham and greens! But alas, I was disappointed. I barely tasted (or saw) the ham or cheese. The yorkshire pudding didn't have any texture and had an excessively light flavor (needed salt?). And overall just eh.

On the bright side, my friend's chicken and waffles next to me tasted DELICIOUS. So... get that.

I'm stumped on how to review this one and the mixed experience takes me to the middle of the road review.

Some of the dishes were excellent.  The mushroom dish (more pasta than mushroom) was excellent.

Loved the carrots (great level if spice and just crunchy enough).

The bread was enjoyable - liked the cheese spread.

Really liked the 3 ham option (note - cold prosciutto style) was nice. All were pretty good, thou I'd order as an appetizer not a main entree.

The rib was tough and too fatty for my taste. I did like the topping (cashew, lettuce, orange slices).

The porchetta was also way too fatty (also not traditional preparation, so I'm told).

Strange wine selection. I'm sure it fit with the Eastern Europe theme, but many of the wines came from countries just not known to make good wine. Maybe they were excellent-- but I sure wasn't interested in trying them out for the price (just under $20 per glass.)

We had out of town guests two weeks back and they requested a trendy, American place, and The Publican fit the bill.  It was not a place I've been to before, but I will be back.  It's definitely a happening place on a Saturday night and reservations are a must.  It gets loud so you will be shouting to hear your dinner companions.  The seating is a bit odd - in that they seat you in a booth but then close the doors on you - so you're sort of enclosed in.  It's different!

It's mostly a small plates set-up, so we shared several different options.  We had the Barbeque Carrots, Honeycrisp Apple, Cauliflower Gratin, Mussels, Charcueterie Plate, Pork Belly, and another fish dish that I can't remember.  We actually liked everything but the Cauliflower, but our favorites were the carrots, apple and mussels....to the point where we would have gotten more of those and been content.  I'm usually not a carrots fan, but they were wonderful.  For dessert, we had the apple tart to share - delicious - especially the ginger ice cream.

Wonderful meal and a populate place and a very solid option in the Fulton Market area.

Unbelievable meal. This place is not for the picky eater. There is a very interesting menu with unique meat, fish and vegetables. We had spicy pork rinds, pig ear and cows heart. For fish we had skate mackerel and hake. The skate is a must try. It melts in your mouth and hits you with a wonderful garlic butter sensation. The vegetables were all very unique and so flavorful. The Apple with burratta were a particular stand out. Every drink we tried was fantastic particularly the ciders. Finally do not pass on dessert. The cheesecake is to die for as is the Belgian waffle with homemade apple ice cream. The ambiance is one of a hip upscale bar hall. It felt slightly noisy at first but we were in a cozy booth that made it feel slightly quieter. It definitely will set you back a few bucks but if you are a foodie this has to be on your list

Dear Publican,

Your delicious brunch wins my heart over and over every time. Whenever I want to eat brunch, you're always on my mind. But by the time I try to make a reservation, you have already been booked out. :( And so, I wait until my friends from out of town visit and make reservations in advance so that we can meet once again.

Yours truly,
Your #1 Fan

..................................................................

As you can already tell, I LOVE the Publican. This is my favorite brunch place of all time! Their pork is amazing! From the sausages to their bacon and pork shoulder, no other place even compares. See that picture of a big, fat pig on the wall? Forget the french toast, waffle and salad, you must get meat here! Their sausage is also spot on! It's never too fatty and always perfectly cooked. The bacon is super tender and a MUST TRY! You'll never try anything like that. It's not overly salty and overcooked. Their bacon simply melts in your mouth effortlessly. Mhmm. I'm drooling just thinking about it.

While I love the food here, I wish their service was better. I'm not sure why, but every time I come to the Publican, we're always seated right next to the door. This restaurant is huge, yet we never get to sit on the other side of the restaurant. It's even worse when it's the winter and the wind peaks through the door and hits us throughout our meal. Another major complaint is that I never seem to find our waiter. We literally have to hunt someone down to take our order overtime. It's as all the waiters disappear once we are seated. No one ever comes to talk about the menu with us, we always have to wave someone down to order. Maybe they need to hire more waiters, but the service is definitely subpar compared to the food.

P.S. Their bathrooms are unisex! The concept is pretty weird at first but it grows on you. I love their hand soap!

Recently re-visited and this experience was significantly different. We had a reservation for 2 and were seated at the communal table. We ordered 2 grapefruit mimosas which were perfect and I ordered the scramble - I think it was the mushroom feta. The portion was a perfect size and  the flavor was incredible. I am looking forward to going back.

The Publican is like an Oktoberfest Hall dropped into the fancy Fulton Street area. I was a lone diner and I had a reservation on Opentable so they sat me at bar seating, which is less social than the common shared tables but that's fine with me. I was right by the serving area and developed a sense of how seriously all the staff are about the quality of their product. I overheard discussions about the food, patron questions and complaints and saw the respectful way they dealt with them.

For myself I wish I had others with me so we could try different things, but it was hard to select just three things, as the server suggested that would be a conservative start. I selected one from each section of veggies, seafood, and meat and they were all excellent. The veggies selection was the lettuce salad with PIG EARS! What a surprising and tasty combo! The charcuterie plate was great. And the mussels had a perfect al dente texture to them (not too mushy and not hard and undercooked). Their broth was lightly salted so it was more subtle umami rather than salty. How wonderful.

I did a beer flight for my drink.

All in all I had a good time there and hope to return with a larger group.

Ummm. YES!

This place is excellent in many ways.
First, the atmosphere is well lit with well designed lighting--and stylish too.
Second, the booty seats are fun. They have short barn-style doors that close you off from the rest of the patrons. That Aline's helps make your dining experience feel intimate.
Third, the food. Well, this is where it really shines. The good is fresh and very tasty. If you like fresh,  healthy food that tastes good then this place is for you. If you like to make it sweet and tastier, then this place is for you too.

You can't go wrong with any of the menu options.

pics.caption: Bathroom is even fun! Check out this sink outside the restrooms.
The London Pudding is amazing. Egg over easy  in the middle.

review.des:
What an unbelievable experience! We had a group of 10 with 2 separate reservations for 8:30 on a Wednesday. We got there early and asked if we could combine the reservations for one big table. They were so accommodating and sat us almost immediately out on the patio and even came to the bar next door to let us know the table was ready. Our server was so patient and sweet with our rowdy group.
For drinks we had everything from beer, gin, a bottle of wine, individual glasses of wine, and basic mixed drinks. All were great of course.
For food we ordered pork belly, whole chicken, charcuterie plate, tilefish, halibut, mussels, scallops, peppers, beets, asparagus, steak, pork rinds, fries.... maybe more I just can't remember. Every single bite was spectacular. The folks who "don't like that" tried it and were blown away! The family style serving with 2 plates per order is such a great way to experience more of the menu. Perfect for groups.
I absolutely loved the time spent there (almost 3 hours of feasting) and was very impressed with the overall flow. We never had an empty glass of alcohol or water, never had a crowded spot on the table because they pulled dirty dishes so quickly.
If you're in Chicago, a visit to The Publican is a must!

I adore Publican! It is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Prior to last night, I had only ever gone for brunch but it was always fabulous and wonderful each time.

I went last night for dinner for the first time for my birthday with my sister. We ordered the chef's menu and there was so much food! Every single dish was wonderful and I had such a good time.

Here were the highlights:

Plums: there was burrata and dandelion greens and the whole thing was just delicious and yummy
Porchetta: I normally do not like porchetta because I usually think it is too fatty but this was so flavorful!
Oysters: The oysters here are briny and wonderful and everything that oysters should be
Waffle: I LOVE waffles! I am also extremely picky about waffles however because I humbly think that I make the best waffles ever... but Publican's was so so so good! Perfectly crisp and I am pretty sure that they are the over night yeasted ones like what I make. So delicious.

Our server was absolutely delightful. Turns out that her son's birthday is the day after mine and we are both only allergic to shrimp! Coincidences abound! She made me feel so special and welcomed without being overbearing. To celebrate, she got us both bourbon creams on the house. I've never had a bourbon cream before but this was delicious and I was in love. They also give you a little pot of what I think was butterscotch pudding with caramel and whipped cream for your birthday! It was so nice it even had sprinkles and candles!

I will definitely be back!

We visited back in February, it was such an amazing experience. The chefs tasting menu had a great spread of food and an excellent dessert at the end. Our server was THE BEST (sorry I can't remember his name now)! He helped my friend and I with custom beer parings to match the tasting menu which had us over the moon. Our server along with awesome food made this the best Chicago dinner extravaganza in a very long time. Thanks again!

Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing!

After all of these years, Publican continues to provide the highest quality of food and a super balanced beer & wine menu.

Highly recommend the Pork Belly and Strawberry Sorrel Posset.

One of the most accommodating restaurants in Chicago when it comes to being vegan. Not only are all veggie forward dishes easily and happily made vegan (removing cheese, etc.) but during every visit the kitchen will put together a "vegan plate" with a variety of delicious options that is different every time.

Some places will not do much to accommodate a vegan diet but the Publican consistently goes above and beyond each time we visit.

A HUGE recommendation for vegan eaters when looking to try a place out in the city.

I had never been to The Publican before and had heard good things so I was excited to give it a go. The many favorable reviews on Yelp got me all excited too! A friend and I showed up at 11am this past weekend and were seated immediately at a long communal table in the center of the restaurant. The restaurant features a confusing mess of tables going all sorts of different directions and booths along the side which had doors on them, resembling that of a stable. Kind of different but neither good or bad.

The bus boy immediately came over and offered coffee. We perused the menu checking out the options and the couple next to us had a plate of hash browns...so whatever I got I knew what side I wanted. I ordered an orange juice to start with and then went with the red wine poached eggs on toast with prosciutto and a bearnaise sauce. My friend opted for the Cajun sausage with eggs, crispy potatoes, and a pickled ramp aioli, and then the pecan sticky bun as a side.

The sticky bun arrived right away and it was pretty good. Generally I'm not a huge fan of cinnamon or pecans but I ate my half and enjoyed it. It wasn't too messy to eat and tasted great. My hash browns arrived next before our meal but I left them alone waiting for the entrees. Our meals arrived not long after and it all looked really good. The poached eggs were cooked well and had a cool purple color to them from the red wine they were poached in. I didn't even know you could do that?!? The toast I got, however, was burnt to a crisp and nearly inedible. Of the two pieces of sourdough I got one was completely black and the other was not far off. I'm no chef but toasting bread shouldn't be hard. The prosciutto was good but it was just piled up on the side of the plate as if it was an afterthought or a garnish. I feel bad admitting this but the best part of my brunch was actually the hash browns which were flavorful and crunchy. As for my friend's meal, she enjoyed it.

Overall I had convinced myself before arriving that I was really going to enjoy The Publican. But after spending $60 on brunch (with tip) for two people I was really disappointed. For my half of the bill I essentially got two poached eggs, some prosciutto, a serving of hash browns, and orange juice. If I had gone to a good greasy spoon anywhere else in the city I could have spent half that and gotten a hearty breakfast. The service was attentive and friendly but the food was just meh. I'll probably come back for dinner at some point and see what that experience is like but I'll probably pass on brunch in the future. 3 stars.

Wow the publican has very delicious food.  I loved everything I ordered the desserts were amazing.  The service was great.  Our server was so nice he made our stay very enjoyable he suggested the best and honestly I loved the everything.  I been having an amazing summer with my big spender.  He has spoiled me and I became very dependent that he orders for me he know what I love and for sure he is always right.  I will come back soon.

This is probably the best restaurant I've ever been to.  The amount of care they put into each of their plates is 2nd to none.  They show the same amount of care to their customers.  The waiters know everything about the menu and treated us like we were VIPs.  The food was 5 out of 5 and the deasert was a 6 out of 5.  Must try their ice cream. And everything else on the menu.
So delicious! Been here 4x's this year and every time it's different! The pork rinds, pork belly, bbq carrots, fish, all so good!!! And the desserts are all good!

The service was very good as our waiter was attentive yet not overbearing. We tried oysters, eggs, bacon, the blueberry muffin and waffles. The blueberry muffin was the big "awe" with a melt in your mouth texture and wonderful flavor. The ambiance is really cool and different- good different. The Publican is worth a repeat visit!!

This is my favorite place to eat in Chicago. The quail was unreal. UNREAL. My wife and I had a great experience. We arrived way early for a reservation and they seated us early, gave us some free appetizers, and provided one of the best meals  we've had in a long time! We'll be back!!
Pretty good brunch here. We got the avocado scramble, dungeness crab, and sides of bacon and sausage. I wasn't crazy about the sausage (which was a surprise), but the rest was very good.

I have to compare to Girl And The Goat.  Close location. The same price range. Completely different experience.

1. Interior. It looks like huge diner. Far from being fancy. Communal tables. You don't hear your server. Beige walls.

2. Prices and food. I would say it was ok if the prices are 30% lower. For that money I expect something more interesting.  Yelp $$ price range food.  

Go to Girl and The Goat or BLVD.

I met a long time friend at The Publican for dinner while in Chicago; the restaurant did NOT disappoint.  The food (Country Ribs and Sea Bass) was GREAT.  Benny was our server and did an Excellent job helping us though our decisions for drinks and food.  I'd come back!

We've heard many things about this known establishment.  Very clever stalls and swine theme and fun, attentive team.  Communal seating is available everywhere and you'll prob end up right next to an obnoxious guest and a witty foodie.  No worries there, love watching people, listening to them and sharing thoughts on the grub.  

Our server was right on top of things and had great assistants to ensure plates were removed when finished unobtrusively and keep waters full.  I found it odd that they would take my sullied knife that had raspberry and pate all over it.  Just had to clean it myself between courses.  

We went with the chef's choice menu at around 65$ a person.  Totally cool with trying some of their favorites and even some odd the menu items. It was semi lack luster as we received similar items if not the same items as everyone around us and nothing too edgy.  An over abundant use of dill, cilantro and tiny heirloom tomato seemed to garnish 4 consecutive dishes.  All in all we had a great time and will more than likely stop in again but choose our own plates instead.  

Would definitely tell people to check it out but veer away from the chef's menu.

What a great place. Large, noisy room with a great atmosphere. We came for brunch and enjoyed everything we ordered. 1" thick bacon was great. The jalapeno sausage knocked it out of the park along with crispy potatoes, corn and eggs.
Great coffee and drinks.
Reasonably priced for the quality.

Let me just say up front: Publican is inarguably the best lunchtime venue in Chicago. Hands down. My complaint is rather, shall we say, ethotic, dispositional. It has to do with Publican's capitulation to an irritating trend amongst hip, upscale restaurant-and-service establishments of its ilk, whose staff--in some misguided appeal to their patrons' class-conflictedness--put on an affected nonchalance, as though the relation between us weren't waiter and waited-upon but that of stuffy acquaintances. Call me old fashioned, but I've always believed that the quality of one's viands is only as good as the hand that serves them. Enough with this faux egalitarianism--nobody dining in the West Loop can stomach the hypocrisy!

Really liked the partisan. Heavily pork/meat based menu, but there are some decent fish offerings (just not as good as their land counterparts).

Ordered the following:
pickles (onion, cauliflower, cucumber)
avocado salad, snap peas, farro verde
english pea toast with burratta
crispy broccolini with spicy sauce
brown butter poached halibut
trout
duck confit, fava bean hummus
porchetta, broccolini, hazelnut and pecorino
ham chop
apple strudel

Favorites were the porchetta (amazing), duck confit, english pea toast, and avocado salad. Make a reservation

Get the chef's menu! It's a great way to try a lot of different dishes I wouldn't have normally picked out on the menu. It's $65/ person but well worth it. Our waiter was also excellent and had great recommendations for beers. The atmosphere is fun yet cozy.

The space is so open and airy. Service is friendly and accommodating. There were some hiccups but it got fixed. The pound cake was baked to perfection, the buttery goodness topped with fruits, hazelnut and ricotta. The bacon is a must and their eggs are soft and fluffy. The meal is so tasty and definitely a great brunch place.

The Publican is definitely a place I would recommend if you are visiting Chicago for the aura/decor and the unique pairings of ingredients they are dishing out. The setup is really nice with a modern touch. Our waitress which I wish I could remember her name was very informative, courteous, attentive and very understanding. One of the dishes we had were very salty and not really edible. When sent back she was really nice about it and took it off our tab, although I wish we had another dish made for us we came alittle close to closing and I'm sure the kitchen was either closing or about too which I didn't mind just having it taken off our tab.

Typically I would not send food back but I do if the restaurant I'm going to is like the Publican. Previous Michelin star winners with plates starting off around the upper 20 to 40 range. It may sound snobby, but I do have alittle higher expectation when it comes to restaurants like these. I feel like when you come to a place like this, a lot of what you're paying for is the experience than the food so if the food is not made correctly than I do have a problem with that. Anyway onto the food before I go off on a rant here on yelp that you're not interested in...

We ordered several plates. Started off with the apple crisp which I could not tell you how it was because I am allergic to apples but it was the tables top 3 choice when talking about favorites. The sweet corn was, if not my personal favorite. Corn is corn but the way it was buttered along with the ingredients used to induce such flavor was delectable. The pasta tagliatelle was ok, all I tasted was vinegar but the texture of The pasta was perfect and well put together. The dry aged sirloin was scrumptious.....I love steak and although some at the table felt it was alittle too rare for their liking, I thought it was perfect and wonderfully seasoned. The farm chicken wasn't anything special, the chicken was dry and the sausage wasn't anything special. Also came with a bunch of French fries.....nothing special. My absolute favorite there was the pork belly, btw these are all pictured! Perfectly cooked, it had a nice crispy exterior and juicy interior that burst with flavor! This and the sweet corn would've been the perfect meal for me although the serving they gave you was pretty small.

Price is a bit steep but again it's the experience is mainly what you're paying for. Everything went well in my
Opinion except for the one pork dish we had to send back, some of the chicken from the half chicken was pretty salty too but it's definitely an experience! We also had dessert which I can't remember off the top of my head but I'll go back and check to see if I can't identify it off the menu but I believe it's pictured. Sorry this was so long, good day!

This was the most disappointing brunch I've ever had.   I don't even know where to begin.

I ordered the bread pudding, which was supposed to have sausage, gravy, and mushrooms.

What I got was a burned piece of bread, with about 1/20th of an onion, 1 half of a small mushroom, and two tiny slices of sausage, about the same thickness as you'd find on pizza.  Food cost should be about 30% of the menu price.   On this item, they couldn't have had more than 50 cents invested in the $15 item.

There was a half dead fly  on the (half) mushroom.  It struggled to get off the plate when I nudged it with my fork.  I'm not one to send something back just because of a fly (and I didn't) -- but this just added insult to injury.

My girlfriend ordered coffee.  She asked for cream.  No cream 10 minutes later.  Asked again, 5 minutes later, no cream.  Asked a third time, and finally got some.

The place was also ridiculously hot.  Like 85 degrees.  When we walked outside after brunch, it was almost the same temperature in the shade (which was 88 degrees).

We sat at the bar, near the kitchen, and I saw some other staff behavior that wasn't ideal.  Most guys had lots of facial hair -- and many scratched their beards, without washing their hands after -- and then served food.  One waiter touched a customer's cinnamon roll with his bare hands, another guy was texting, and also didn't wash his hands after.  

None of these are terrible -- but didn't help an already poor experience.

Overall- cute brunch spot with some friends, nice open floor plan and seating for large groups (with a reservation... like all good things in Chicago).

A girlfriend and I made a reservation about a week out for Saturday brunch and showed up for our 10AM booking about 45 mins early because we were hangry. We were told that our table wasnt ready yet which seemed fair, but that there was a spot for two at their bar which we went with. I am happy we did- don't wait for a table, this place is so casual that the bar is a great alternative for a short wait time. Our seat was right in front of the line and we had a great time watching the kitchen crank out breakfast.

Service- great, friendly folks working here!

Food- a little pricey for what you get, but felt like they do simple food and do it well. We tried the biscuit and gravy, hashbrowns and french toast. All of the dishes didn't blow my mind, but were solid, good food.

Highly recommend for a casual brunch spot!

pics.caption: Nice open floor plan with seating for big geoups
Our awesome view in to the kitchen, had a blast watching the line at work. Seems like great camaraderie here.
Charcuterie from the deli next door!

review.des: Ahhhh....yum!  What a fun place for a Chicago brunch.  I had the fried eggs on the crispiest batch of fries and a side order of maple braised pork belly!  And the beer selection is pure perfection!  Go here.

This place was so cool. I loved the design and decor. The oysters were a bit pricey but the best I've ever had sooooo... it was worth it. Also I had a beer that was blessed by a monk or something but it was phenomenal! They say the portion are shareable but if have to disagree. They are a bit small so you may have to order a bunch so we just each had our own and that worked for us. Our waitress was super cool too.

I really wanted to love The Publican. I wanted to be blown away by the bacon and not feel awkward sitting in their communal, long Viking style tables. We came for brunch one Sunday morning. I tried the Apple cider doughnut muffin (amazing), the chicken and waffles (average), and the bacon. I mean, come one guys, we are REALLY stretching the definition of bacon. This takes thick cut to he next level, and it was not for me. Their "bacon" is basically a slab of pork - neither crispy nor chewy. At $7 a serving, I would skip it.

We sat next to a family at our shared table, and had children starring at us and talking about us throughout our meal. I like the concept, but I do not like it in practice. To be fair, maybe the Publican is a better place for dinner. I will be skipping it for brunch in the future.

pics.caption: Chicken and waffles and $7 "bacon" on the side.

review.des:
Came to Chicago for 4 days. Publican was the most disappointing meal of trip.

Has Sunday brunch reservation. Arrived and sat timely. Ordered crab scramble with sides sausage, bacon and hash browns. Significant other ordered one egg, planning to split other sides. The food had all the elements for fantastic (look, smell and taste were perfect) except ALL were cool or cold. Don't know why or really care, is it that difficult? Apparently yes.

My first time here. Delicious sandwitches. Can walk up and grab something to go or get a full sit down service. They serve breakfast and beer. Will be back for more.

The Kale salad is quite sour, so may try the coleslaw or chips instead.

pics.caption: Roast beef sandwitch with side of kale.

review.des: Not very impressed. Had the Yorkshire pudding and it was burnt. So was my friends toast. Egg was cooked well and fries was good. Probably will not come back again.

Got to check this place out last Sunday and I was extremely pleased. It took about 45 mins to secure a seat BUT they have a market right beside the actual restaurant that has coffee & tons of crap you don't need but buy anyway because greed.

The mood of the place was giving me...hipster lunch room? I guess. There are these superrrrr long tables and so you're essentially eating with other people but it was actually pretty cool. I'm a people watcher so this was perfect for me. I ordered the chorizo gravy and biscuits(probably not the name) butttttt it was actually pretty good. I ordered a side of bacon bc I saw it on yelp and BOY... that bacon was damn delicious. It almost tastes like ribs. lol maybe that's the southern gal in me but I could've threw some BBQ sauce on that bad boy and went to work!

Really delicious food. Scarce menu if you're a picky eater like myself. But ues

I got the fried chicken for brunch, and it was very delicious! Comes with an egg on top (the way you like) served over what I believe was polenta. I can't remember.

Tip: order a side of frites and aioli. The frites are perfection.

Very hip and popular spot on a restaurant-rich street. All dishes were on the salty side but perfect with a beer or a cocktail. For vegetables, we really enjoyed the beets with burrata and the bbq carrots, both are probably regular menu items. Meat-wise, the pork belly with grit melted in our mouths and the duck breast was cooked perfectly tender to a medium. For dessert, the honey waffle was light and flavorful but not too sweet. The pineapple cake was a bit too heavy and sweet, and that's the only item we will not order again.

Overall, food was tasty, and service was very good considering how busy and crowded the restaurant was

pics.caption: Waffle with honey buffer and fruit preserve

review.des: Stopped in here almost by accident and was very impressed.  The pimento cheese they have is amazing and worth the trip alone.  Open style seating with great meat.  I had the chicken for dinner and you get a giant portion.  If you are in the area and looking for dinner and or drinks, this is the place to go.

You already know it's good because of the 2K+ reviews at 4 stars. So here's a 4 star review and some pictures of the food cause that's what I use Yelp for. We went for Sunday brunch and note that the endless coffee was $5 so make sure to get your cups in.

pics.caption: Notable artwork and unique booths with doors

review.des: My only complaint would be its noisy, food is amazing. But if you Aren't looking for a romantic dinner and just want to eat too much. This is the place

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago, this is the place you want to bring guests who are visiting from out of town. It's not a quite, romantic restaurant; it's loud and lively and you might sit next to some people you don't know. Get the Country Ribs, just do it. Anything you order is going to be good, really good. Came back last night for dinner and I'm not really into deserts but the Pear Cobbler with Sour Cream Ice Cream was a dish that I was still thinking about today. Seriously delicious. If you haven't been here yet...you should go.

pics.caption: Peach Cobbler w/ Sour Cream Ice Cream. Yummm.

review.des:
Met friends for Saturday brunch.

There were three of us so we opted to order a few things and do family style. Definitely would recommend this.

Coffee is more on the floral acidic side. Not my preference of coffee style since I like earthier and darker brews. Easily remedied with a touch of cream.

Ordered the chef selection dozen oysters, liver pate dish, biscuits with sausage gravy,  bacon, and dutch baby for something sweet.

1. Yes to Oysters.
Oysters came first. I can officially say I've had oysters in the Midwest and didn't die (I'm originally from the west coast so most thoughts of seafood in the Midwest makes me wary). Joking aside, a very good sampling of different oysters. Most were light and bright in flavor, but my favorite one was the Olympic miyagi groom Vancouver island. It was soother and richer than the others. That being said, I don't think I would have been able to handle more than a couple of those since they were richer than the rest.

2. Yes to bacon.
Their bacon is amazing! Being they were thick  cut the smoke flavor was still there while not being overly sweet with the glazing. Tender and not as heavy as I would have expected.

3. Mmm, too much
Liver pate was very flavorful, but I dare say too flavorful. There wasn't enough toast for how much pate there was, which made enjoying more than a few mouthful difficult. We used some of the oyster crackers with the pate. It needs some more unsalted bread to go with it. The pickled elements on top helped, as did the perfect soft boiled egg.

4. Yes to biscuits and sausage heavy.
Biscuit and sausage gravy had better balance in terms of overall flavor. They also garnish it with fresh mint, which was surprisingly pleasant as a flavor addition. Love an egg on my breakfast foods.

5. I'll pass on the Dutch baby next time.
Dutch baby was dryer than expected. Didnt have anything to moisten it other than the garnishes and toppings that were listed in the description. Mainly creme fraiche, raspberries, hazelnuts, and mint. There weren't any other wet elements. Outside was crisp tough, I'll give them that. Wish it wasn't so dry though. Just means I'll get to try a different sweet next time.

Had a simple small salad , every bite was Devine , crazy how it's the details that can make such a difference in taste ., split a club sandwich and a Italian sub ,  it was beyond good , No sandwich place can compare. It's that good

After repeated and fruitless efforts to get into the best restaurants in the world that exist in this fair city, my coworkers and I finally landed on The Publican, on the recommendation of the concierge at Palmer House.
