It was definitely popping hard on an idle Wednesday night, with most of its communal, family-style sitting occupied by night revelers under the globe-glow of the multivarious orbs of light. They were able to carve out three spots for some reals G's so we sat next to some wild strangers and prepared for the experience.

Being people of exquisite and refined taste, we started the meal off with a crudo and a chicken liver pâté. When the dishes arrived, it was a real yin and yang situation. The crudo, or what you could see of it, seemed like it could have been served on the head of a pin. Six microscopic slices of presumably high-grade fish floated on a shallow puddle of flavor that imbued the meat with light and delicate taste, but it wasn't nearly enough to warrant the $18 price tag. Luckily, we are corporate ballers, and expensed the whole shit anyway.

Now this chicken liver pâté, that was a whole different story. One of my compatriots is a connoisseur of the stuff, and having eaten pâté all over the globe, I was interested in his take, though not particularly excited to try it myself.

Bruh.

This shit was b-a-n-a-n-a-s! The texture was mad peanut-buttery and spread onto some grilled bread. The fat, and spices and flecks of strawberry woke up my flavor senses in ways I've never experienced. I for real couldn't believe it; I've never enjoyed a pâté ever, and now I'm scouring the internet for reviews on where I can find something half as good as this. Def a must order for appetizer.

For entrées, each dish is served in a shareable format so and exciting arm-reaching game of fork-Twister is encouraged. Despite this, we decided to go for 4 dishes to sample the largest cross section of the menu possible. First up was the dry aged steak which came out in about 5-6 pieces underneath some thin asperges and various other seasonal flavors. I could tell you that my heart stopped long enough for me to be declared dead and then restarted on the next bite and that's how good it was, but I'm just gonna say it was fye and if you got it like that, you should give this wild ass Illinois beef a place at the table.

Keeping with the dry-age, we moved into the duck breast next, which was juicy, flavorful and didn't suffer from the heavy duck flavor you can sometimes get. It was perfectly fine and a good choice.

On the lighter end, and I wish it'd come out earlier, was the hake which was a standard fried fish scenario that came with a dipping sauce and some lemon. Some might say it was dressed up Long John Silver's I'm gonna say it was pretty delicious.

At the end of the meal came the crown jewel of this motherfucker: a king chicken hacked up cooked to perfection and perched on a throne of frites. I can tell you with confidence that the colleagues had long since tapped out, so we had to take this monstrosity to go, but damn if it wasn't good in the hotel room later that night.

I think the people of Chicago already know what this place is about, and its a fine thread in the fabric of excellent cuisine around the city, but if you're in the city for a bit, The Publican will take care of you.

pics.caption: I've never liked a chicken liver pâté until this one

review.des:
Came here on a Monday night around 6:30pm and was able to get seated right away without a reservation.

Beef Tongue (5/5): this is the dish that was the highlight of the meal. the beef tongue was so thick yet so tender and the flavor meshed very well with the toast underneath

Pork Ear Salad (3/5): while the crispy pork ears were good, the salad was very underwhelming

Country ribs (4/5): the ribs had a nice flavor to it, but the meat was somewhat hard to chew. Liked the veggie garnishing on the side though.

Service was mediocre. Had to ask twice for the wine menu. If you're a meat-lover, this is a good place to try!

pics.caption: Lettuce gem salad with crispy pork ear

review.des:
AMAZING experience both times I've eaten here. Came recently for my anniversary. Food is SUBLIME, staff is so friendly and kind.

Word to the wise; if sharing tables and noisy atmospheres aren't for you I would skip this one.

The Publican does brunch oh so well and you can tell just from the wait line alone.  We ended up waiting for about 30 minutes and it was due to luck because we were able to snag a table that didn't show up for their reservation.  The Publican has a really awesome vibe with long community tables which you can strike up a nice conversation with others quite easily and there are cubby tables around for a more private dining experience.  

Our group ordered a good variety of food from smoke pork shoulder, the bacon, spicy pork rinds, red wine poached eggs, sourdough pancake, and honeycrisp apple salad.  Hands down my favorite dish was the smoke pork shoulder!  It was the fastest devoured entree as well!  Our least favorite was the spicy pork rinds - they were more like pork skins (less meat and less crunchy)

Service and food were amazing

Outstanding food, wonderful ambiance, perfect service. The Publican is on my list of top restaurants ever visited.

We came without reservations for dinner around 9:45 at night. The interior was still quite crowded and the ambiance is like a king's mead hall. Long wooden tables span the inside of a single, colonnaded room. One wall is filled with private, wooden booths like in some British pubs.

Our server, Jaime, was phenomenal in every way. She knew all the menu items and made some amazing recommendations. I was pretty insistent on ordering their grouper crudo, though it was not specifically recommended. This dish was disappointing as the portion was minuscule and the lime juice content was through the roof - totally overpowering and fish flavors [C].

They have quite the impressive beer list, but many things were not on tap but rather bottles/cans. Not many local beers were on tap, instead they seemed to be Belgian import focused. I went for a local hoppy beer from a can, one from a well-known and respected brewery, Pipeworks. I was served the beer in a glass and the can was placed on the table. After smelling and tasting it, it didn't seem fresh. I looked under the can and it was about 2 months old. Poo. [C]

We went for a second appetizer since that one was a letdown. We went for the recommended barbecue carrots. These were honestly one of the best things I've ever tasted in my life. I don't know how they make these, but they are dry-rubbed then perhaps smoked underneath pork for multiple hours gaining incredible meaty, fatty depth. I couldn't believe it. [A++]

For our main course, my wife and I split their smoked pork shank, which was served as a gargantuan portion fit for The Mountain. The meat fell off the bone effortlessly. The polenta base and garnishing apples and cilantro were perfect. Given the mead hall ambiance, I felt I was eating like a king. [A+]

Clearly, The Publican isn't perfect in every way, but the dishes they excelled at were so phenomenal that I have to give them 5-stars. I will certainly be back!

pics.caption: Potato photo quality, but King Arthur's feast level of this beast smoked pork shank. Unbelievably delicious.

review.des:
I came here for brunch with a friend. He ordered the Yorkshire Pudding (smoked pork shoulder, apple cider, & sunny side egg) while I ordered the Posole Verde (chicken thigh, tomatillo, cilantro, and soft egg). I had a few bites of the Yorkshire Pudding and thought it was delicious. The name was a little misleading though because it was more like a savory pancake with pieces of smoked pork shoulder. As for the Posole Verde, it was a a thin soup, which is rather refreshing. However, I felt that it lacked flavor. However, this is entirely my personal opinion as I have always enjoyed heavily flavored food. It was also the reason why I gave a 3 stars instead of 4.

Both of us also spontaneously decided to share a side of Burton maple syrup braised bacon and it was divine! It was more of a pork belly as they were really thick cut! The pork was sweet and savory, melt-in-your-mouth goodness. Highly recommended! Service was great as well. We arrived an hour early to our reservation and we both seated immediately.

Wow, ....we happened to stop by after CoffeeCon 2017 to grab a light, late lunch before our dinner reservation at Blackbird.  Not only was the Potted Rillettes + Fried Cauliflower from the light menu really good, but our fun conversations with Aaron (our waiter/bartender) made the experience so worthwhile.  We'll be back for sure.

*******
Update as of 10/16/17...

3rd time here at The Publican in 1.5 weeks -- an indicator of how good this place is.  We love the fact that the menu changes regularly; however, at the same time, we're sad when some of our favorites disappear.  We took some pictures, but it may be useless since some of the menu items may not be on the menu in a couple of weeks.  BTW, it is a bit loud though (but fun), so be prepared to speak up with friends.  BTW, everyone from Kevin (host), Yesmena (hostess.. spelling???), Jaimie (wait staff), Aaron (bartender), Alexandra (wait staff), Carrie (server), and Ben (bartender) are absolutely awesome!!!  They just make the experience that much better.

I had a good brunch here with friends this morning. I thoroughly enjoyed my pork schnitzel, and my husband liked his duck confit but thought the portion size was a little small. It was somewhat hard to hear our friends while seated at the long communal tables. But everything was good and I would definitely return to have a cocktail or try other dishes.

I had a feeling this place would be a wonderful adventure. we moved to Chicago about a year ago.  My daughter and her boyfriend were coming to Chicago for a visit. He is a chef and he told us he really wanted to go to a Paul Karan restaurant while in Chicago, so I made a reservation for the Publican because it sounded unique and casual.

Our server was extremely helpful with suggestions. Great curated selections of beer and wine.  We first ordered from their snack menu as they had not started dinner yet.  We ordered the cheese plate, all three hams and the bread with all three spreads to start. Killer eggplant spread; smokey and creamy. We then ordered three vegetable dishes and three entrees. A fish, duck breast and the roasted chicken.  My youngest son said it was the best chicken he has ever eaten. The French fries were a bit salty, but still good. The duck breast was perfect.  

Another cool thing that I have never seen is that you can buy the kitchen a six pack; its on the menu. We told them we wanted to add the six pack and they went over and rang a bell and cheers came from the kitchen.  

There is another Kahan restaurant across the street, Beatrix, so I guess we will have to come back to this cool neighborhood.

I've noticed that a majority of my friends who visit Chicago usually want to try the Purple Pig or Girl and the Goat, which of course are both amazing. I always try to steer them towards the Publican if it's not on their agenda because it's great food, in a great environment, with great people.

I mention people because I'd recommend coming here with at least a group of 3-4, order up a plate of charcuterie and wine while you wait, and soak in the lively ambience around you. Be prepared to sit at the communal table and enjoy the company of complete strangers.

I try to order something different every time I come back, but when entertaining guests I always go to the carrots, pork rinds, a half dozen oysters, pork belly, and the bass before adding on other dishes. Some of the dishes can be on the rich and savory side, but hey you only live once right? Excited to come back on a weekend to make it in time for the brunch menu!

Great food, drinks, and atmosphere. A great place to go with friends!

They have fabulous beers on tap. Ask the waitress to help pair one with your food.

The cauliflower and sweet potato dishes were my favorite. The bread and butter was OK, nothing super special. The bbq carrots didn't have enough flavor in my opinion, mainly just tasted like grilled veggies.

Don't skip dessert! The mint chocolate ice cream was so good. Tasted like real, fresh mint!

This my favorite restaurant in Chicago! Went with group of 6 to celebrate my birthday and had a wonderful night. The food amazing as always...my picky parents absolutely loved it. There is no better place to explore the great menu of meat, fish, and veggies...or stick to my favorite,the chicken!

I'd be remiss if I didn't mention our fantastic server Gio!!! This is the second time we've had the pleasure of him hosting us for the evening. He's great at helping us navigate the menu for a large group of people while working with my girlfriend's dairy allergy. Super knowledgeable with the beer menu, and over all just a great guy! Thanks again Gio!

A friend and I made a reservation for brunch on a Sunday. There are The restaurant is beautiful during the day time and has plenty of natural lighting. There brunch menu is small and there were not many items that I wanted to try. My friend was recommended the spoon bread, which is like a savory bread pudding, and highly enjoyed it. I had the waffle, which came with honey butter and plum preserves. While enjoyable, I would not pay $9 for a rectangular carb again. Because it was not very filling, I also opted for the hash browns. It was much pretty much like a flat potato pancake that was fried. It would be great for hangover food since it was greasy, but it also lacked seasonings. The Publican is a bit on the pricey side, but it also immensely popular. I would recommend this place to people who stray from traditional breakfast/brunch foods and are willing to shell out a bit more.

pics.caption: Waffle, hash brown, and spoon bread

review.des:
What I loved: the friggin waffle (it almost made this a 4 star by itself)

What was 'meh': believe it or not, the sticky bun (it was kind of dry)

What was a hard pass: the communal table thing, just because I like to enjoy the company of who I'm with more than the strangers next to me
Food was decent. Waitress was nice and didn't charge for the undercooked pork. Praying that I don't sick from eating the undercooked food.

pics.caption: Pork. Oink. Not a fan but everyone but it's what its known for
Three types of ham what not too like

review.des: Food is ok but they have way too many rules to the point of being obnoxious. You can definitely have a more pleasant experience elsewhere for less/same money.

Had dinner here tnight. Oysters from cape cod can't go wrong... the Edward County ham is bomb too w bread and butter. The sirloin was decent nothing to write home about. Tomato salad...would I again?? YUP!!! All around great & efficient service and dude... THE ESPRESSO MARSHMELLOW MOOUSE THING FOR DESSERT WAS OUTTA THIS WIZORLLLLD. And Raul was top notch w the drink service

First, foremost, the Publican is one of my favorite restaurants for dinner. I've been here many, many times for dinner, and it has yet to disappoint. However, Saturday brunch is a whole different story. Overall, my brunch experience here came out to be really slow and underwhelming.

By the time our group got seated, we waited about 10 - 15 minutes before a server came to our table. After having taken our order, it took about 40 minutes before we got our starters! The waiter was unapologetic and nowhere to be seen even though it was really early for the start of the brunch service. Finally, the food was nothing special. I would expect a place like the Publican to go above and beyond but there was not one item that stood out as being really good. The mimosa was okay. The avocado toast was decent though could have used more avocado. The waffle was okay but had good honey butter on the side. The only thing that may have stood out is the bacon, if you've never had thick cut bacon before; it had a nice texture and flavor.

Overall, Publican brunch was disappointing. I don't know if it was because it was the Saturday, not Sunday, brunch service but there are so many better for brunch in Chicago. Publican dinner will always be a favorite but I'd probably stay away from the Saturday brunch.

pics.caption: The Publican bacon with maple syrup for Saturday brunch.

review.des: All praise the most beautiful and delicious bacon there ever was to grace a plate! My partner and I came here on our trip to Chicago and we're always recommending The Publican as the perfect brunch spot for meat-lovers and non alike. The atmosphere is unique, with a ton of large shared tables but even amongst the bustle of customers coming and going Publican maintains a pleasant ambiance. We also enjoyed the ability to make a reservation considering how well-regarded the food is. Definitely the type of restaurant for a repeat visit to explore a great menu.

This place was great! I loved the minimal wood design and the beautiful orb lighting. Also, weird comment, but can we talk about how much I loved the silverware?

For a place known for its meat, I was pleasantly surprised by the salad options. Every single one of them sounded more amazing than the last! I'd go back just to try some more of the vegetables. I wasn't super hungry, so I kept it light with a citrus and avocado salad, which was beautifully presented. Even more than the salad, I loved the cheesecake. I was way too full, but who could say no to buttermilk cheesecake with roasted cherries, lavender, honey, and hazelnuts?! The Publican was an excellent intro to the Chicago food scene.

Came for the delicious bacon and hash brown,
Stayed for the sticky bun, waffle, coffee and egg dishes....and bacon and hash brown :)

Expert tip: Sit outside. I *hear* inside can get way too noisy. ;)
Do yourself a favor and eat here.  The food is amazing, the service impeccable, and it has now won a place in my heart for top places in Chicago.
I love the layout of community tables. It makes for a different dining experience than what you typically find. We tried every oyster on the menu and the veggie selection on the menu was delicious.

Made a reservation for 8pm and was seated immediately even though I arrived late. Sat right near the bar. I really wish I could have sat closer to the kitchen, but all other seats were taken.

Ordered a glass of cab to start the night off and the pig ear salad.

Pig ear salad was super crunchy. I'm talking LOUD, noisy crunch haha, you could probably hear me chewing through those things from a mile away. Very good on flavor I would have enjoyed less pig ear and more salad.

For my entrée I got the sirloin steak and OMG it was the absolute best piece of beef I have ever eaten. So tender and perfectly seasoned. Even the onions and edamame it was paired with were amazing. I wanted to lick the plate, but resisted.

This was the only place I had "dessert" which was actually a bread course served with hazelnuts, brie and jam. Very good but I should have skipped as I was already pretty full and left most of it there. Paired this with a Riesling.

This was the cheapest of the three places I was set on dining at even with my glasses of wine.
I thoroughly enjoyed this restaurant and I'd love another plate of sirloin right now, or whenever actually.

Must try restaurant if you're in the Chicago area.

pics.caption: Little gem lettuce salad with crispy pigs ears.
Dry-aged sirloin. One of the best steaks I've ever had.

review.des:
Food is great, and service is amazing!

Food is intended to be communal, with some items being larger portions than others. Our server did an excellent job coaching on how much to order for our group. We ordered a sampling of most things on the menu - standouts were: charcuterie plate, cauliflower, beets, pig brains, and pork belly (everything was honestly good though).

HUGE shout out to the host/hostess and management for handling of a situation most restaurants would have done poorly. We came with a group of 8, with a reservation, and the group sitting at our assigned table loitered for 45 minutes after paying their check - forcing us to wait 30-45 minutes after our reservation time. Management got us a high top and comp'd apps for us to accommodate and kept us updated throughout the process. Can not speak highly enough about how it was handled!

It is really hard for me to write this review because I really wanted to like it. I heard such wonderful things and was hoping it would live up to the hype considering the sheer number of review that this place has.

First I have to say that the waiting staff and members are all attentive and great. They helped me get seated right away and was polite through the whole evening. However, that is the best thing I could say of my entire experience.

I went for dinner and got the Chef's Menu, which includes 8-9 savory dishes (they say), and then 1 or 2 desserts on the side. To be honest, I don't remember the names of all of them, but I can tell you that we only got 7, but did not want to argue with the waiter as they repeated told us that we have received our savory dishes for the night, repeatedly. Aside from that, we received 3 vegetables (strawberries, asparagus, fried spring onions), 1 fish (squid), and 3 meat dishes (potted rilletes, porchetta, and some sausage that I don't remember the name of).

Out of all those dishes, I can only confidently say that I would order the squid again, and do so happily. They were perfectly cooked and had a complex, yet light sauce that brought out the flavor of the squid. The rest of the food was either too salty (fried spring onions, asparagus), very bland (white looking sausage), or a poor blend of flavors (porchetta and also white looking sausage...) I will not even going into the details of the other dishes, as they were poorly executed and should not have money wasted on. For example, the fried spring onions were supposed to be "tempura" like, and yet it was oily and heavy as you would think of onion rings you get from the fair. It was very heavy and honestly I think a poor choice to give at the end of the meal.

What was even more demoralizing was the desserts. We received a mint chocolate chip ice cream. Though it had been made with real mint leaves and dark chocolate, It did not taste great together. A few bites sure, but we left the rest to melt. The second dessert we received was the chocolate cake with a smear of peanut butter... oh my goodness I do not even know what I was eating because it was so salty and the texture just did not work. It was even saltier than some of our main dishes. I would've preferred if they just trashed the dessert and given me an ice cream cone from McDonalds.

Though not something I considered for my rating of the restaurant, the decor and interior design of the place is interesting. I personally would not have boxed people into (they literally sit in a booth that the sides close on, nor would i have made long tables that make it difficult to work your way around and have to fight with your random neighbor you sit with. Though I would say it was intriguing nonetheless.

This is a restaurant that I would say looks great on paper, and even when reading the menu, but does not work out well in real life. They tried to made the dishes too innovative and in turn ruined the harmony that these dishes could have had. The pace of the food was also obscure. We received 5 dishes within the span of 10 minutes, and the last 2 had a 15 minute delay from when we finished the first 5. That is definitely a miscommunication or misstep somewhere.

For the price, I would highly recommend you walk 2 blocks south, and plead with the good people at Girl & The Goat for a standby spot. The food there is what good innovation and execution looks like. It is worth the money and you'll even save yourself a few bucks when you walk out full and happy.

pics.caption: The mud pie. More salty than sweet. Avoid it unless you have had it in the past and very much crave it.
Fried spring onion. Oily and heavy.
Charchuterie half plate. So little headcheese even the small pinch of baguette covers all of it.

review.des:
I would've never found this place had it not been for that one Munchies episode! I had this place and Blackbird bookmarked (same owner) but decided to give Publican a try for my friends birthday. Everything was coming to place, right when the Lyft dropped us off to putting our name on the list and then finally getting seated. It was like that episode all over again.

We came here around 7:45 and there was about an hour wait. They text you when your table is ready but I never got a text so around 9pm we showed up and voila, our table was ready for us. We were seated at the bar area, this place is pretty big but looked like it was hard to get a table since everything was full. I usually don't sit at the bar either but I was so excited to try this place that I didn't even care.

Once seated, that's where we met our awesome waiter Will. This guys great!! He offered so many suggestions and was super attentive throughout our meal. We ordered the chefs selection oysters, the spicy pork rinds, the striped bass, dry aged New York steak, fried quail and the half charcuterie plate.

What I love about Publican is that they change their menu daily. They also mention what farm their food is sourced from and they work with a set amount everyday. For instance, we ordered the dry aged steak but by the time we were seated, they only had a 21oz. Portion left. We also ordered two drinks, a Moscow mule and the "legs that dance" which has blackberry jam mixed in there, yum!

Overall, the food was presented very well and it looked just as good as it tasted.
Spicy pork rinds- perfectly crunchy and not too spicy
Oysters- Really fresh
Charcuterie- not bad, could've done without a few of the meats but overall a good starter
Striped bass- the sauce this fish was cooked in was to die for. Fish was super tender and it almost melted in your mouth
Fried quail- heavily breaded but very tender and the slaw they have on top is a must with the quail in every bite
Dry aged steak- Very tender but a salty for my liking

Overall, I'm glad I got to check this place off my list. Definitely want to try Blackbird the next time I'm here but overall, all the staff are super friendly and the place had a very live atmosphere :)

Our first true meal in Chicago was at the Publican and what a way to set the bar. I loved reading the menu as it has a focus on fresh local vegetables and seafood... two of my favourite things plus an amazing dessert menu.  Clearly I was made to eat here!  Overall, the level of professional but warm service plus amazing dishes made it one of my places to eat.  The environment could be a bit quieter (it was LOUD) and the communal long table can strike up interesting conversation but also some side eye action from awkward interactions.  This is a small note compared to the amazing food coming out of the kitchen and the great service.

As mentioned, the service is great... we had a phenomenal server.  Not only he managed a LARGE group that had 3 kids beside us, he took care of us as if we were his only table.  Never once did we see him ignore us. His interest in the dishes was infectious ... he shared what he loved and didnt love as much.  He was very honest on what were the hits in his opinion and together we built a great order that I loved.  Another great thing about the service is the staff cleared each dish and the empty plates never sat more than a few minutes.  Our water was always topped and our server knew exactly when to talk to us to see how the meal was going and when to order.  Overall... just great.

We started with the bbq carrots (loved how they paired it with the pecans), tomato and burrata (my dining partner never had burrata before and he LOVED it.  The tomato had a vibrant flavour that paired well with the creaminess of the cheese), and hamachi crudo from Japan (this was good though it did seem a bit pricey for several small pieces but ... still very tasty).

We had 2 fish dishes and wow... they were great.  We ordered the sea bass and skate wing. We were hesitant on the skate wing cause our server said it came boned in.  I'm so glad we decided to go with it.  The sea bass was good but no where as excellent as the skate.  If you see skate on the menu... order it.  The meat comes off easily from the bones and whoever is doing the seafood in the kitchen... they are amazing.  Each fish was still tender and perfectly cooked and yet had a great sear on the skate.  

We ended the night with 2 desserts... blood orange sorbet and the deconstructed pavlova.  I love pavlova but their unique take had me scratching my head at first.  Still it was very good.  The blood orange sorbet though... oh that was very good.  Tangy, bright, and true to the fruit... it was just as good as the ones I've had in Italy.

Between the excellent skate, burrata and tomato dish, and blood orange... there was some definite highlights of the entire week.  With the incredible service, this made a clear winner for our week of dining.

pics.caption: The blood orange is so true to the fruit!  Pavlova is a deconstructed version... Good but not as good as the blood orange
BBQ carrot... Loved this.  Natural sweetness balanced by the BBQ and crunchy pecans
Sea bass ... Good but got overshadowed by the excellent skate wing

review.des:
I went here for dinner with some friends last time I was in Chi-Town.

They raved about the pork and the place did not disappoint!

Be prepared for long waits and communal tables - but worth it!

Wanted to like it more.  Crowded and loud, the food is delicious but over priced, even for Chicago.  I'm all for spending money on a quality meal, but they call it family style; but it seems more "small plates."

Wanted to try this place out for myself because the menu looked so interesting! I met a couple of adventurous-eating friends there for late night dinner.

4 stars for atmosphere and service, 3 stars for food.

I have to say overall, this place is slightly overpriced. The food was good but not like OMG FANTASTIC OUT OF THIS WORLD.

We ordered the spicy pork rinds, the ham variety plate, chef's choice oysters, cajun sausage, and the cuttlefish ink pasta.

Spicy pork rinds - "A" freaking plus. I would come back just for these. They have a slight kick to them along with a delicious white cheddar season. Crispy, light, fantastical.

Chef's choice oysters - Great variety. Wish they could give some cocktail sauce and horseradish but I know, I know, it takes away from the flavor of the oyster, yada, yada, yada.

Cajun sausage - Pretty legit. Not a huge fan of sausage myself, but my friend loves sausage, so she devoured most of the plate. I really enjoyed the creamed corn sauce they drizzled on top.

Cuttlefish ink pasta - No go on this one. They offered to replace our dish because the pasta was SO SO SO SALTY. As in someone may or may not have spilled the entire contents of a salt container into making the pasta. They said it had something to do with the sauce reducing into the pasta throughout the night which may very well be true, but I feel like as far as quality control goes, it didn't make the cut. We didn't ask them to replace the dish since we were all so full and it was closing time. They did take the dish off the bill which I appreciated!

Overall, I love the atmosphere of this place. It is great for family-style dining. I love to share and eat a variety of foods. Loved the decor and the lamps on the inside. Drink selection is also nice. Lots of different beers and a good number of cocktails to choose from. Great for large groups!

Here's yet another review that raves about this restaurant, amazing food, appropriate prices, friendly service, located next to a ton of other fabulous dining establishments in case you aren't a fan. Communal seating. No bar. Dimly lit bathrooms with a communal washing station. Outdoor seating. This is great to come to once a year, or on special occasions, as dinner can turn out to be a 2 hour affair (at least it can on the weekends). Plan accordingly.
Great food and ambience. Amazing Bloody Mary! Saw an article about The Publican at an airplane magazine. Can't believe this gem!

this is my protein nite.  the spicy pork rinds is so light and crispy almost liked rice crispy.  i am sure it will wash down well with a beer. 5*

the pork belly is interesting. i worry it would be greasy and it is not at all.  4*

great place for a date night if you don't mind the noisy environment.

Had a really good brunch.  Started with pork rinds, fresh and spicy, airy with perfect crunch.  I had the green chile sausage on potato salad with an egg on top and the combo of potato salad, egg and sausage was delicious.  Great beer selection, good service and a really nice atmosphere.  Def return trip worthy.  Great frites also!

Chefs at the Publican nailed the art of dancing on your taste buds - all the dishes are full of flavors and textures. My dinner at the publican was like drinking a dreamy cocktail or climbing a good hike - full of surprises yet so good that makes you tipsy! They just don't need any Michelin star to be sooooooo good.

Publican as another successful venture of Paul Kahan, is a modern creative restaurant with solid options in seafood, pork and beers (recommend you to try their house-made beers while the cocktails are solid too). The space is big and open - high ceilings, big long communal tables inside and outdoor seating in the summer. Here are the highlights of our night:

Mussels - SO FAT!! Never had mussels this big! The sauce was a killer too. It was rich, super creamy, and buttery with delightful white wine aroma. Four of us couldn't help but want more bread just to finish the sauce! The bread was delicious too - crusty outside and warm inside. I have to confess this is the best mussel dish I ever had. You just have to try!!

Fried chicken - just the smell was driving me crazy... One bite - the crunchy sound and the burst of the flavor in my mouth made me forget about everything else... The meat inside is also flavorful and soft. Chewing them quickly released more flavors. The hot peppers and herbs also add nice kicks to the flavor!

Clams with squid ink pasta - another solid dish! Clams are huge as well. Very well seasoned with herbs and spices. The squid ink pasta is thick and chewy. Very satisfying texture yet also absorbed a lot of flavors.

Solid spot for food, drinks, and good vibes! Strongly recommended to anyone who's visiting Chicago in the summer (you can sit outside to enjoy the weather at the same time - can't be more perfect than this!). Just be aware of the lines - we waited ~1hr before getting seated on a Saturday afternoon.

pics.caption: Mussels with white wines sauce and French bread - so good!!!

review.des:
The Publican is an amazing space. There are huge communal tables all around. Definitely admired the ambiance the whole time we were here. Funny story about the communal tables: Shawn C. and I ran here from our hotel because we wanted to get a morning workout in. Probably shouldn't have done that.. LOL

Anyway, on to brunch. We shared the smoked arctic char scramble, bread pudding and a side of hash browns. Everything was good, but the bread pudding was TO. DIE. FOR. AMAZING! HIGHLY RECOMMEND! 10/10! Would order again! Get it, you must.

My only gripe is that we had some of our leftovers packed up and they lost a sausage somehow..

pics.caption: Artic char scramble, side of hash browns and bread pudding

review.des: This was s perfect stop on our culinary tour of Chicago. The food is all served family style, and is more than enough to share. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable. ...and the vibe is upbeat & engaging - especially with the communal seating!  I would definitely revisit The Publican.

I really hate to give a mixed review to such a highly regarded place, but I just wasn't wowed by the Publican when we went for Sunday brunch. Maybe I just have simple taste and don't appreciate the finer details of each dish because everything was just alright for me. My initial impression of the Publican was that it was basically a tribute to pork and beer, so I was expecting the dishes to be very hearty with heavy, meat dominated flavors.

Food: One thing I love about going to a restaurant with a big group is that you can try a bite of a bunch of different things. So we pretty much ordered almost everything on the menu/

Publican mimosa - I was a little hesitant because I thought the beer would be heavy and dominate the flavor, but this was actually pretty refreshing. You still got the boozy orange juice flavor, but not quite as sweet, which I actually liked more. The beer was very subtle, and actually complemented well with the fruity flavor.

Pork rinds - I love pork rinds, and used to eat them all the time as kid since it's a popular Filipino snack. But something was just off about these. I liked the texture of the rinds, very light and airy and not dense/greasy at all. But that powder they dumped on top was a little weird. Some pieces were just covered in it and gave my mouth a dry, chalky feel. Not sure what was in it, but the flavor was way too tangy. I would've probably liked it better if they didn't sprinkle anything on top.

Waffle - Very light and airy...almost too much since it was to the point where it tasted like nothing. There wasn't any dominant flavor like vanilla in the waffle batter, and the honey butter was again too subtle in sweetness for me.

French toast - I'm more of a meat and potato guy, so I rarely order such fresh and fruity type breakfast items. Altogether though, I think the flavors worked well. Nice dense french toast as a base and then a very light creamy yogurt type sauce to bind everything together. It was topped with some nuts, peaches, and mint leaves. Overall a very refreshing bite.

Pork shoulder - Probably my favorite dish of the meal. This is what I was picturing most of the items on the menu to be like. Just like any dish served with eggs, I smashed it all together to spread that yolk around for every bite. It was topped with some chimichurri sauce and crispy fried onions. Great dish.

Frites - Basically normal fries with 2 fried eggs on top. I like fries, and I like eggs, but together it didn't create anything more than some plain fries sitting in a puddle of yolk. I feel like the fries needed any type of seasoning, and I needed something to bring it all together. There wasn't enough yolk to go around. Maybe some sort of dipping sauce like a garlic aioli would've helped.

Publican bacon - It's probably sacrilegious to not love this, but again I thought it was just aight. I swear I'm no bacon snob, but I thought Au Cheval's side bacon was way better. It was basically thick cut bacon with a little syrup drizzled on top. Some parts were too lean where it had a jerky type texture. Overall, not the melt in your mouth type experience I wanted from succulent pork belly.

Spoon bread - I wasn't exactly sure what this was. Was it a quiche? Was it some sort of savory cornbread? Either way, I thought it was surprisingly bland, especially since the menu said it contained bacon and parmesan cheese.

Cajun sausage - By the time this came out, I'm pretty sure I've already eaten 4 eggs haha. The sausage had a very subtle spice that tasted great. It also came with some grilled naan that was useful to soak up some of that egg yolk. Portion size was a little dainty though.

Overall, none of the dishes were terrible, but none were memorable enough for me to rave about to other people either. The waiter made it sound like we over ordered, since we got 5 dishes for 5 people along with a bunch of sides. But I definitely left hungry since a lot of the dishes were actually small and only a few bites, just dressed up with a lot of filler garnishes. Maybe it's because I had high/different expectations coming in, but I was slightly disappointed with Publican's brunch.

Service and staff here were great, everyone is very knowledgeable about a menu that is constantly being changed and updated. We had one person with a shrimp allergy and the staff was quick to ensure there was no contamination for her. All the food was delicious and the portions quite generous!

A family of 4 vs 20 top table of conventioneers:

Don't expect anything less than a sneer, callous service or passive-aggressive​ behaviour from your waitstaff.  Don't have a $3K+ ticket, forgetabout it.

1.  When asked what's the difference between the size of the mussels (half or full order) condescension ensues.  What? You can't order a full size of mussels?  Shame on you.

2. Vegetables were pretty good, admittedly.

3.  Oh,  Porchetta. If you're expecting a crispy, golden brown, tender and juicy.  Don't.  When asked why it was sitting under a sweet, sticky and saturated goop of vegetables, with thick streaks of fatty bacon, your waitstaff will show you rudely, the pork loin, the bacon and spin on her heel and haughtily walk away.  Shame on you for asking.

4.  Oh... my demure wife chased you down as you rudely walked away.  Jessie.  When you cleared my plate, and asked me if I wanted dessert, no.  I'm going to finish my meal first.  Thank you.  You would surely like me walk away and open your section for more convention people with fat expense budgets, right?

Advice : next time you enter, swagger in with your fat expense wallet and flash your cash.  Otherwise, you'll just get ignored.

Jessie : You disgrace your chef's food.  What was supposed to be a fabulous meal ended up being a gobful of excrement because of utterly appaling service.

My friend and I made a reservation for a Sunday afternoon so we were able to grab a table right away. We were placed at the communal table in the middle, and like most people have experienced, it was a little bit uncomfortable. I do not mind sitting that close to my neighbor, but it really affected the interaction with the server as I do not think she was able to make it very personal while shes shouting over my head to the person across from me.

As for the rest of my experience, it was very positive. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and food that both of us ordered. I did the red wine poached eggs, which I thought was a cool spin on a classic dish. The red wine taste was not overwhelming, and the sides really complemented the dish.  I would visit again if I did not have to sit at that table, but I think that is almost a guarantee if you are a party of 2.

Visiting Chicago and looking for a brunch place? Go here! You're bound to find a different experience here than at other places.

PARKING: Street parking all around the block - free! May be difficult to find close by but you should be able to find street parking within a 1-2 block radius.

MENU: Changes everyday! So even if you come by often, you'll probably be trying something different. This goes for their entrees. The sides and such stay the same (like the bacon - which is so thick its like ham).

SEATING: We made reservations so we were seated immediately.  I can see how the line can be long for this place. We were seated at a booth which had barn-like door that enclosed you in the booth (that's different!). It was nice cause it was a little more private and we didn't notice much when people were walking by our table. The sun was a blazing when we sat down - fear not, just reach over and pull the lace curtains to cover the windows. There will be light but you won't get sunburned trying to enjoy your meal. There are also community tables and well as some standing tables too.

The food was delicious! I wasn't all that stuffed, but it was just the right amount of food. We all ordered something different and enjoyed the meal! Hard to recommend entrees since the menu changes daily. Order whatever sounds good that day and come back next time to try something different!

Our server was a-OK. We actually received the wrong menus (for the day before). He also looked hungover and kept touching this face/hair before setting other tables and touching plates, etc. That doesn't look sanitary??

Bathrooms are located by the entrance. Communal sink with designated full bathroom stalls - large doors. Unique!

Worth noting, they're opening up a restaurant at O'Hare! This is great for those who have layovers and delays at the airport. What a great dining option! And a bar too!

pics.caption: Inside dining! Doors that close you in booth seating

review.des: The photos don't do this place justice. Make a reservation and go! The food is wonderfully flavorful. I wish I lived in Chicago so I could go back again and again.

I was enticed into brunch here. Prior to going I logged on to the website and reviewed the menu. My first thought was I don't like the offerings. Then I remembered this is Publican. If anyone can pull off such a bold menu, then this is the place. First off, they do everything from scratch. Yes, I do mean everything, the bread, preserves, butter, bacon, and the sausages. The last time I was in a restaurant that does this; I was in Indiana Amish country(Nappanee, Middlebury, Goshen, Shipswana). But just like everything else location, location, location. I live in Chicago and a trip out to the Amish is about 2.5 to 3 hours of driving. Also, don't expect a mimosa with your brunch in Amish country, which is a big minus with foodies like me.

We arrived and were welcomed by the friendly host, then quickly seated at our reserved booth. Tess our server was very nice and menu knowlegable. We started with delicious mimosas, a very good bloody mary, and a excellent Spanish cidra. Then, we ordered some very fresh tasting oysters. Which we followed up with Char scramble which was simply outstanding; the waffle with preserves and in house butter were addictive; some very good bacon and perfect breakfast sausage. The hashbrowns were some of the best I have ever had. The carrot cake with apricot preserves and cream cheese was very good. The carrot cake was good but it was the toppings that made it memorable. Last but definitely not the least, the excellent bread produced here is some of the best in the city. Top their excellent baguette with in house made nutella and you have a simple, yet delicious sweet treat. When you pay attention to the details it doesn't just make a difference. Rather, it makes all of the difference, and this meals proves that. Everything was simple, straight forward and delicious.

If you have not been here for brunch, then yes you are definitely missing out. Chef Paul Kahan and his group run some of the best high quality restaurants in Chicago (Avec, Big Star, Blackbird, Dove's Lunchenette, Nico Osteria, Publican Quality Meats, Publican Bakery, and The Violet Hour). Also, I do have to mention, don't make the same mistake I made when leaving. The valet drove my car around and I quickly pulled into the bakery on Lake St. thinking I was going to take home some of their great bread. It turns out the Lake St. location is only a wholesale facility!?!  Well, now I know not to make the same mistake next time.

I had only one night on my own for dinner while in town on business.  So after reading a couple of food blogs, and Yelp of course, I picked the Publican as my dinner destination.  My colleagues decided it sounded good and wanted to tag along.  

Once there and reviewing the menu, we decided to divide and conquer by sharing a number of tasty offerings.  Because of how dishes arrive and served (family style), this is probably the best way to dine here.  

After a round of drinks, companions and I enjoyed the bread plate, the barbecued carrots, the "taste of 3 hams" plate, and the oyster fry.  Unfortunately, I was unable to convince anyone to try to the spicy pork rinds, one of their most famous offerings.

Everything we had delicious and presented beautifully.  All the flavors where full but nothing overwhelmed the other, especially with the carrot dish.  Service was helpful and friendly as well.  

If I get to go back, I am doing the Chef's Dinner!

pics.caption: So *what* exactly is an "after pork digestif"?

review.des: Came here for weekend brunch after making a reservation on Opentable (I recommend you make a reservation). I'd been looking forward to trying the Publican for a long time. We were seated next to the bar at a somewhat communal table right by the servers, which made us feel in the way. As a gluten free eater, I was disappointed that they did not have more gf options on the menu or any gf toast or bread options, particularly given their strong reputation and location in west loop, where a lot of their competitors do offer gf options. The menu changes frequently, so the waiter couldn't tell me offhand which items I was going to be able to eat. He checked in with the kitchen and came out to give me my options -- 2 options. It ended up working out and I enjoyed my brunch, but I felt like I inconvenienced them. I really wanted to love the Publican, and I think the guests I brought with me (who did not have any dietary restrictions) enjoyed it -- but, it was loud, our table was in a weird spot with a lot of servers rushing behind our chairs, and they didn't have many food options for gf people. If you don't have dietary restrictions, you'll probably like it; but, if you do, I recommend you check out some other locations in the area.

Interesting concept. We were early for our PQM reservation so we came here for a drink first.

You can choose a regular sit down table or a standing table, bar-like. We had about ten people and did a standing table since we weren't staying for dinner. Their drink menu is huge and spans two large pages. I got a cocktail with blackberry jam, lavender, mezcal, and another liqueur in it I believe, it was decent.

It was a bit too noisy here for me otherwise it would be 5/5 stars.

Not that this place needs another glowing review but here it is. My meal here was phenomenal. And I don't even eat pork or oysters or meat besides fish and eggs. So I can only imagine the quality of their meat dishes. For drinks I ordered the "get caraway" which is gin, ginger, lemon, and honey, and it was wonderful. This would be my go to drink anywhere if other venues offered it. The ginger really made it unique and the ingredients tasted super fresh. Not too sweet or strong either. For food I ordered the persimmon dish which was phenomenal. It came with salmon roe, some greens, avocado, and quinoa and everything worked wonderfully together. I couldn't get enough of this dish. I also ordered the grilled squid which was also perfection. I'm not sure what all was in it but it was amazing. There was a side of bread for the table so I was able to mop up all the yumminess. Friends at the table ordered a bunch of the pork dishes and they said it was really good. The service was great and I loved the ambience; I've never seen this kind of set up with the communal tables and enclosed booths in the States anyways. I recommend x 100. So glad I had the opportunity to check this place out!

I've probably eaten here around 20 times. This is one of the best restaurants in Chicago. I love the food and desserts. The menu changes here often, and everything is just so tasty.  Be adventurous and try different things! The Publican can make just about anything taste phenomenal!

Eagerly came here for dinner after hearing and reading such great things about Paul Kahn's restaurant. The space is very open and bright, almost overwhelmingly so. Between two people, we ordered 3-4 dishes but none were incredibly memorable. Perhaps we ordered the wrong dishes but our server didn't provide much guidance after we gave her our choices.  The communal style eating was nice but I don't know if I'll be back again soon especially for the price.

Hip and trendy place definitely for brunch. I loved the vibes and high tables even though the open space definitely can make for a louder acoustics. Nevertheless, I found the food at the Publican really delicious and well executed dishes.

This review is specifically for brunch, but I've heard stellar things about dinner as well.

We started off with the oysters which were pretty good. Though our waiter explained which each Oyster was sourced from, they honestly tasted all similar - though that just shows my lack of oyster tastebuds. There was no "salty sea-water" taste, meaning it passed my quality test.

I got the Mushroom Strata, which I don't even think is on the current menu right now, which is cool meaning that Publican really tries to follow seasonal trends. Not only was it beautifully presented, but the egg really was perfectly sunny side up and the mushroom baked strata underneath was subtle; no real flavors overpowering.

The portions are indeed on the smaller side, but definitely will leave you satisfied.

I only docked a star since service was a bit slow, but they were quite busy.

This place was ok, very hipster and the menu was more eclectic than I've seen elsewhere.

Dishes were a bit more expensive and this restaurant encourages you to share with the table, so more tapas style than anything. Bottles are around $45 and above.

The food was good, but nothing stood out to me.

Had a private party of 20 for a graduation dinner organized at Publican Quality Meats with a preset menu (that the graduate picked out himself). It was great that they set us up across the street at their storefront rather than inside the restaurant, it assured us that service would be on point.

There was a cheese spread accompanied with bread and their spicy pork rinds on the table for us to enjoy while waiting for the entire party to show up. The delice de Bourgogne was my favorite cheese, the manchego was good too.

- grilled octopus: nice slight char taste, and wasn't too chewy..great texture. Easily my favorite dish of the night

- mussels: good flavor, but the mussels lacked a nice texture. It just crumbled once I put it in my mouth

- pork belly: obviously! Very tender..a must for pork belly lovers like myself.

- creme fraiche bread pudding: not overly sweet but a little heavy since it is a bread pudding. Would've been great with vanilla ice cream!

Overall, it was a lovely dinner meal. Good food, and good service. Thank you, Publican!

Food was good: pannetone French toast, biscuits and gravy, but spicy pork rinds were the best I've ever had.  Didn't care for the booth with closed doors on it, makes for a tight fit to relax in with group of 4 and makes you feel like your caged barn animals...weird concept.

What a great local eatery! Had a really enjoyable brunch experience here. Fantastic locally sourced food with a neat atmosphere! Highly suggest the bacon! (thick cut and almost like smoked pork belly) I need to say the service was outstanding as well - quick, friendly, helpful! Andres made our first time here delightful.

So what could I say. They do not care about their customers. Especially when they have a Birthday. I know guys you are always busy. But with such an bad attitude you will lose them continuously. I am guarantee you that. My BF wanted to make a surprise for me. And you guys have ruined my Birthday Evening. Plus he mentioned you he needs a special table, because his BF has a BD. But you even did not try to do something. Anyway we found such a good alternative is RM Champagne, who could find a perfect table even when they totally booked for the evening. And Dear The Republican, Good Bless you and your meat business
Terrible service tonight. This place has gone way down hill. Used to love everything Paul Kahan represents, but not now.  And guess who has fallen off the 2019 Michelin Bib Gourmand list....

I had the ultimate brunch experience today! The food was delicious and the atmosphere was energetic. When you go please ask for Katie she was beyond the best server I've had ever! She was pleasant and very quick to assist and give recommendations as needed. We had a delectable cinnamon roll for starters that made my entire day! I ordered the corned beef hash and when I say it was so savory it was to die for!!! The coffee is strong but that is just my speed especially doing brunch after a late Saturday night! The summer sausage was EVERYTHING!!! I also had the Publican "mimosa" which is a mimosa that uses a Belgian wheat beer instead of champagne and I LOVED it! Overall, I will most certainly be back and I have so many other meals I'd like to try on a regular weekday! Good job!!!!

my recommendation is to go with a big group so you can try the most food! the menu changes. i went with a group of 8. i can't remember everything that we tried but it was all delicious. two of the things that i do remember though: spicy pork rinds ($7) and pate ($13) served with toasted ciabatta slices. yum!

My favorite spot during my last visit to Chicago! I love this place! I could sit here all day eating everything on the menu! This place felt like home. The service was impeccable, cheese was amazing and meats were delicious!

Indoor and outdoor seating is available which is key for the unexpected weather in Chicago.

This restaurant is located in a mixed neighborhood...business district meets hip new restaurants that will leave you wanting more. I wish I had more time to visit a few other places nearby.

As a foodie I can appreciate the chef that is constantly changing the menu and working with the seasons for ingredients. As a lazy a## I love looking thru pics on Yelp to find out what looks amazing so I can just order that!  However, sucks for me when I find out I can't order the Crab scramble with cream fraiche because it is no where to be found on the menu! Pure agony! Lol. Yes I'm being dramatic but damn that looked so good!!

My favorite meat and cheese board should always come with at least three different cheese options, some kind of spread or jams, pickled veggies, honey, soft bread and a ton of Prociutto! The cheese board was perfect as soon as I added the Prociutto! I wanted to sit there all day eating my cheese drinking Chandon splits for $5 bucks!! It was a perfect afternoon on the patio.

The sausage plate was tasty too. They offered three different sausages chicken, spicy chorizo and blood sausage. It was served sautéed in a green mojo sauce, potatoes and cheese definitely worth tasting.

Can't wait to see what's on the menu during my next visit to the Windy City!

pics.caption: Sausage plate (chicken, chorizo and blood sausage) served with green chile mojo sauce, potatoes and cheese
California champagne split only $5 bucks great deal and it goes perfectly with my cheese board
Cheese board and I added prosciutto. It was my favorite appetizer in Chicago.

review.des: This might of been one of the best meals we've ever eaten. Anywhere. Being located in the hip Fulton Market district didn't hurt either. The service was fantastic but the meal was just off the charts. The price point makes it even more wonderful as you can afford to sample lots of things. Give yourself lots of time when you come -- you want to savor every bite

Mo is the best, hands down. She remembered my preference of beer, suggested everything I ordered, and I am in heaven right now. Mo deserves an award. So ridiculously delicious... All of it. Great customer service. I need me so mo' Mo!

We recently came back here for Valentine's day. This time, we sat in the long, uncomfortable communal table. My date and I felt uncomfortable sitting in-between strangers, and we were only able to face each other straight. I really don't see the point of this crammy seating arrangement as it makes people feel uncomfortable and claustrophobic.

Anyway, they had a prix-fixe menu for Valentine's day, and they all sounded okay, but the food was actually good as the last time we came here. We had a plate of charcuterie again, and they never fail to impress me with it. What opened my eyes were foie gras on crostini. They put a generous amount of foie gras which was a plus. The only thing I was disappointed with was the pork dish. I couldn't even believe that it was pork because the look, texture, and taste was just like a big slice of ham. I hope they won't serve that again, because it makes them look bad as a meat/butcher restaurant.

I wasn't sure what to expect when I heard we had a reservation at the Publican. Brunch? For sure. Kind of has German flair. Tall backed chairs, standing room in the middle, back wall has closed door stable seating which I've never seen before.

Three of us ordered the smoked brisket on a biscuit, topped with a fried sunny side up egg. Flavors were popping but as with all brisket, there was too much fat for my taste. The others ordered chicken liver pâté, mushroom toast, sausage, and a combination of the following:

Pecan sticky bun-- delicious
Cinnamon streusel coffee cake was ok, big slice.
Meyer lemon old fashioned doughnut was alright, donut hole on top.
Pork belly bacon is worth mentioning, charred just a bit for smokey flavor.
Frittes under fried eggs. Interesting.
Unlimited coffee $3, everyone else opted for it.
Water refills consistent, no drought in Chi town.

No complaints on service, nice people they've got there, if not a bit on the quieter side where they'll speak minimally to give you privacy. This ain't no diner. Long communal table in the middle near the stand up tables. The dining room was empty when we arrived at 11, but a few parties were hanging out in the waiting area. Unique & modern European/American place to eat. Their lights are cool.

*Brunch item portions get larger as you go down the menu.

I'm saddened by our latest experience here.  We love this place so much that I often will build in time to my travels to eat at the Ohare location!  Yesterday, celebrating the husband's birthday early with brunch and it was just off.  We immediately noticed the pork rinds were not on the menu and when I asked, the waiter said they just didn't have enough supply to make even one order!  He joked that he would understand if we got up and left, but I seriously thought about it.  The rest of the menu was just not inspiring.  We ordered three plates and a side of the buttermilk biscuit (yum!).  My plate was the sliced avocado with boiled egg that had something like "everything bagel" seasoning on top and was delicious.  The other plates, not so much.  The johnnycakes came with scrambled eggs, but were caked in carmelized onions and green onions, which was gross when the onion juice soaked into the cake.  The last plate was the pork belly with fried egg.  Egg was fine, pork was a bit lackluster and the bean/corn stuff on the bottom had WAY too much mustard seed for me.  I really hope it was just that day, because I would hate to lose a favorite.

What a wonderful place to dine. Was 30 minutes late for our reservation and where still sat right away. Bar side in front of the kitchen, which although undesirable table to most, for my boyfriend and I it was the most perfect place to sit at. Watching the chefs do their craft and seeing all the great dishes coming from the open kitchen, just enhanced the ambiance.

We picked a bottle of wine, a bit on the hard side since it was not very American wine friendly menu. Lots of rare picks, but good. Our waiter Will was nice and educated, service could have been a little cleaner, but his personality made up for any small glitches,like not icing our white wine.

The menu had a perfect balance of items and we got a little bit of everything. Before our food came the gm, a young hospitable man came with complimentary cheese and bread plate that just blew my mind. House made butter and pimento cheese stole the show, with salty and creamy flavored that played perfectly on the crunchy bread. Simple and absolute perfect!!! This butter changed my life!!!

A delicious plate of house made meats and Spanish ham followed, and then crispy pork rinds that were perfectly flavored and were like pig clouds in my mouth. But by far the two top dogs that night, a fried onion dish that I will say was my favorite thing I ate in Chicago, and a pork belly entree that although smelled like the tropics, tasted like Christmas dinner, the smell of this dish actually brought a tear to my eye.

The meal was finished by house made ice cream that although almost impossible to eat at the end of 8 course, refreshed and made my palate very happy..

This place is a must, simple good ingredients that make the stomach and soul very happy, made me feel like home and I can't wait to my future trips to Chicago to visit them again.

pics.caption: Cow tounge with tomatoes n Boursin cheese
Pork belly, fresh dill and grapefruit

review.des:
Beautiful decor, great food - if you're willing to spend a pretty penny.

I came here on 2 occasions - once for dinner, once for brunch. The experiences were so different, had I been more unfamiliar with the decor, I wouldn't even have known they were the same restaurant.

The dinner: beautifully rich, dark, and loud. We had a party of 6 with a majority mid-career physicians so money was really no issue..that being said, we ordered nearly everything on the menu + about 7 bottles of a beautiful red wine. Everything was rich, and bold. The menu changes from time to time so I won't bore you with the irrelevant things we ordered, but I can assure you there were good, but so heavy and much of it consisted of bacon complements. I almost fell asleep at the table..but that could have been the wine. Due to our party size, we sat at a communal table, which I wasn't a huge fan of. We did have to shout at times just to communicate, but all in all, a fun night.

Brunch: while dinner was rich, dark and loud, brunch was unexpectedly bright, slow and mellow. I had a smoked fish omelet, which was good but questionably worth the $18 I paid for it. Service was slow and seating was similar. Echoing other reviews of frustration, our reservation was at 1 and we weren't seated until 1:40. Kind of puts a damper in the brunch. It was okay but I won't be jumping for joy at coming back anytime soon.

We wanted a special place to go on our night out with family. We are visiting from San Diego. I'm glad we were directed to The Publican. Family style so we all shared, amazing is an understatement. Fantastic place and on our next visit we will be back.

I was excited to try the food here and it delivered. I had the bread to start-firstly the pricing is not clear for the bread. Apparently there is a base price for the bread and the listed price for the toppings is additional, not total. That was a disappointing part of the bill. Secondly- the dining is what I perceive to be an experience because it took FOREVER to get any attention. The waterboy was around every time I took a sip. But our server was absent for the most part and had to be asked twice for the final check. That was disappointing. Aside from that the food was magnificent. After our bread we had the halibut which was succulent flaky and flavorful. The beef heart was a little chewy but as I worked my way in the meat seemed more tender. The best part of the meal was the duck confit. It was flavorful, juicy and substantial. This would be a full five stars if it wasn't for the lack of service.
Went to publican for brunch. It was soooooo good but the portion sizes were huge. I also like to get freshly baked bread from publican whenever I can and take it home.

I don't know really how to describe my feelings exactly. Underwhelmed?

High hopes for this place given the name. (platter, Nationals... hello! - Bring it On). Let's take this from the top ladies and gents.

Walking in I didn't even know where the door was so we're off to a bad start. Proceed to walk over to our table to see that it looked like we were in a horses stable. Swinging Doors! (- Uptown Girl) and honestly couldn't really keep my composure after that. BUT have to mention the horse stable was definitely a better situation than the communal tables where you can eat with strangers. Like constant "Lunch in my new work places cafeteria on my first day" eating. Then come the drinks. They were tasty but definitely looked sad. Almost like they were depressed? Seek some Zoloft for your sangria.

The food was good but I almost felt like I was at my great aunt Cindy's house eating her "famous" casserole that is good but definitely nothing to write home from camp about.

Also- the Diet Coke came in a glass bottle. I felt like I was on death row enjoying my soda.

For all those reasons "I'm out dawg" Miss you Randy Jackson.

See ya at Publican Quality Meats!

Ate at the Publican for Sunday brunch and I was excited to try out their Belgian waffle. Overall, the experience and food were fine. This is not my favorite brunch in the city (or even in the west loop) BUT you do get quality food for what you are paying. Note: the wait staff was nice but a bit slow.

pics.caption: Scrambled eggs with avocado & grilled toast.
Belgian waffle with peach jam & sausage

review.des: Ya know, I was super pumped about this place because everyone said they had the best mussels and food in Chicago.. I was not impressed, unfortunately. We went during off hours and I believe they were only serving "snacks". We ordered a sampler platter that had pate, different meats and pickles with a full order of mussels. The only thing I liked of the whole meal was the pate.. Did not meet my expectations ):

I made a 12:30PM reservation but got here super early and they were still able to seat me immediately by the bar.

I love that the whole place is communal seating and there are tables for those who prefer to stand and eat.

Everyone was super friendly and helpful with the menu. We ended up ordering way too much!

The sticky buns are a MUST for your side order. They remind me of a cinnamon bun but with the texture of a warm monkey bread. SO GOOD!

The warm scones are also amazing, but I would skip this if you're not that hungry because it was very filling.

The pork schnitzel was seriously one of the best I ever tried. There was the perfect amount of batter and perfectly fried - the pork was very tender and full of flavor. The fried egg and corn on top complemented it well.

The crispy bread pudding was also soooo delicious! The sausage added a nice salty kick to the sweet bread pudding (made from French toast) and the peaches.

I'll definitely be back the next time I'm in Chicago!

One of our wedding menu items was charcuterie from the Publican so we were keen to check out their restaurant for a special occasion.

We hated it.

The service was good. In fact, the service was probably the best thing about this place.

I don't know what it is about the Publican that has enabled it to generate such hype. It's crowded, loud and the food isn't that good. There was a piece of meat that I absolutely could. not. chew. My teeth and jaws did not have the endurance to break it down and I had to go to the bathroom to spit it out.

I seem to remember one or two vegetarian appetizers that we liked; however, the Publican is known for it's meat. We didn't like either the meat or seafood options. I don't know what else to say.

We had an amazing meal and wonderful evening at The Publican tonight. Every dish was so delicious and the service by Monique could not have been better!  The chicken liver pate' is to die for with the most smooth and luscious flavor. If they have mussels definitely get them, the signature chicken and sausage dish should not be missed.  Lots of wonderful breads and spreads, and their beer selection is unmatched. All in all The Publican is a great place and I will be back again soon. Monique thank you again for making my Partner Wagdy's birthday so special!

As a kid, we had a neighbor who ran an upscale business out of his home; he built a nice office and showroom and had it outfitted with chandeliers and beautiful furniture-- it was quite a showpiece. When he moved, a large farming family moved in and turned the beautiful space into an animal shed, where chickens made nests in the pool table and pigs lay on the expensive carpeted floors.
The Publican reminded me of that "luxury office turned barnyard" from my youth-- a confusing space that is partially upscale in its furnishings and prices yet somehow makes you feel like you're eating in a rustic feed lot.
Growing up on a farm, the enclosed booths looked like people (ironically) locked into in a feeding pen, and as a left handed person I really hated being squeezed at a large table with strangers, leaving me to wonder where we were all supposed to put those "family style", tapas sized entrees we were supposed to share. 90's music was blaring overhead a little too loudly and the menu didn't offer much besides pork dishes (the rustic paintings of pigs were the only decor on the walls, completing the ambiance that made me feel like I was in a 1990's Sizzler with an identity complex)... the restaurant or dining experience wasn't appealing at all, and I very much disliked the dishes we got-- the mussels were more fishy than I've had before, anywhere, and the lukewarm cauliflower salad, while decent enough, complemented nothing on the menu and was overpriced (around $14).
I should have read the reviews before going.... I asked my dining companion if we could please go elsewhere about 10 minutes after we arrived since I was really turned off by the decor, the lack of options on the menu, the strange seating (why did they cram us next to other diners when most of the communal tables were empty?) and the terrible blaring music. I wish we had left, it was easily the most unpleasant dining experience I've had in the city to date.

I've been here many times for brunch and once for dinner. Their brunch menu varies on Saturdays and Sundays, but my favorite items are only offered on Sundays.

For Sunday brunch, I absolutely love their french toast and the red wined poached eggs. Those two are both amazing options that I love going back for. Definitely order their famous Publican bacon on the side too.

The only meal I haven't liked here was the Belgian waffle. It's very crispy and not the classic fluffy type of waffle I had expected.

This is for a dinner review. Was recommended to come here as the best place for dinner by a friend. The two stars are for the restaurant setup communal style and the great service.

The food was not my taste and was expensive for what we got. We ordered the bread ($4) with pimento cheese (was ok), the fried eggplant app ($12 was cold and undercooked and tangy), pickles ($5 cold and tangy), beets (also cold and tangy), snapper (raw, cold and tangy and 6 small bites of fish for $19), the octopus (warm...finally, but just one finger for $17), and half chicken ($27 salty and boring). My friend and I had to order hot tea to warm ourselves up from the over use of cold and tangy dishes.

Maybe we ordered wrong, but we ordered quite a few items off the menu and all were forgettable and nothing special.

This is a great place for brunch. We had reservations and requested to sit outside. Even with the reservation, they told us it would be a 30-45 minute wait. The communal tables didn't bother me, but we got placed at a table adjacent to the bar which was just really inconvenient - I was in the foot traffic of all the servers and bartenders which was really inconvenient.

The food was really great. I had red wine poached eggs which were incredible. It came with a side of prosciutto which was yummy, but I wish it was integrated into the dish. We also split a side of bacon and sausage, the bacon was better than the sausage. The sausage was pretty standard. We also got bloody Mary's which came with a beer back and were very good.

I came here with my parents due to the food reviews.  We were quickly sat with a reservation and excited by the menu but constantly waiting on the slow service.  As soon as we sat down we were given drink and food menus, waited 30 minutes for drink orders, then waited another 30 minutes to order food.  Food was great we enjoyed everything.  But after we finished our last course we waited for 20 minutes just to get our bill.  Terrible service, great food.  Very strange experience for the price.  Would try another restaurant in the area just to get better service.
Slow inattentive service. Good food. Pork belly was really good. Pork rinds...ordinary. Halibut was good. Stone fruit cobbler...AMAZING...so good.
830 reservation - its 827. No you can't sit down and no you can't go to the bar because its full. But the 3 people who walk in off the street can sit down right away.  Killing me.

17 Jun 2018

When for drinks and appetizer

Two appetizers, Pate and Pork rinds. The pate was of the spreadable style. it had been blended with strawberries. It was quite good with the bread they served with it. The pork rinds were light and crispy with a dusting of a spicy powder, it was a nice dish.

I had been wanting to try The Publican for a while, so I was excited when my friend let me know that she had made a brunch reservation for us here.  This place has an interesting vibe, and I enjoyed the fact that the booths exist in essentially "stalls" like you would see in a barn.  My friend and I ended up at a communal table, and this got a little loud and cozy when we had parties join directly next to us--not ideal for catching up, but we made it.  

The food was excellent, and I really enjoyed the French Toast I ordered.  My scrambled eggs were also delicious.  The coffee was excellent, but I was a bit disappointed that my cup was empty for a while without an offer to be refilled--I eventually had to ask the busboy for more coffee.  The service in general was fine, but nothing amazing.  Overall, though, I liked this place and would be interested in coming back for lunch or dinner!

I have been wanting to eat brunch at The Publican for the longest time and finally had the chance to do so over the weekend. I would recommend calling in to make a reservation to secure your spot since this place is quite popular especially during the weekends. One thing to keep in mind is that your experience here will involve communal dining. Basically everyone is seated together at a long table. If you have a party of two, you and your friend will be seated next to strangers on either side. This took me by surprise since I was not expecting to be sitting so close to other people that I could hear their conversations. The communal dining aspect made my experience a bit uncomfortable but looking back, it wasn't too terrible.

My friend and I ordered the duck confit and avocado toast to share. The flavoring of the duck was decent. Perhaps it was a bit salty for my taste, but it was enjoyable. There was nothing too memorable about the dish, however. As for the avocado toast, it tasted as avocado toast should. Again, there was nothing too memorable but I did appreciate the hints of lime that peeked out through the creaminess of the avocado.

I was a bit disappointed in my meal at The Publican, but perhaps my expectations were too high. Brunch was tasty and enjoyable, but it was nothing special that would cause me to come back in the future.

Do yourself a favor and eat here!  This is how all food should taste.  

Plates that are shared between guests which is a great way to taste all the deliciousness.  We had the Brussels Sprout salad, the fried Cauliflower, the Taste of 3 Hams, Sirloin and the Pork Belly.  We ended the meal with the Apple Strudel for dessert.  

The 3 of us all agreed that the favorites were the Fried Cauliflower and the Pork Belly...... heavenly.

The atmosphere and decor are contemporary.  The noise levels can get rather loud.  We had a reservation for 10pm.

pics.caption: The Pork Belly - definitely a must!

review.des: I must say that the food here is absolutely delicious!!!!!!!
