Everything we ordered exceeded our expectation, my friend quoted" I will never look at beets them same"  because they were that amazing. We also tired different cocktails, and loved every last one. If you go here with an open mind for food, you will not be disappointed. (I forgot to take all the pic but here's some)

I'm not a foodie by any means, so I'm not going to delve too deeply into my dining experience.

Simply put: brunch done right. Super fresh ingredients and great portions. Customer service is top notch.

Make a reservation if you're dining during peak hours.

I've come here for both brunch and dinner.  More of a fan of the brunch menu and would probably give that four stars.  The restaurant definitely emphasize share plates and communal style, so I wouldn't recommend the restaurant if you're not open to that.  Options for tables are either your own personal "pig pen" or a communal table or high top.

For dinner, you definitely have to be prepared to share because the plates all come out at different times.  The friend we went to really dislikes share plates so he ordered the avocado salad while my boyfriend and I ordered the mussels, bread plate, and cuttlefish ink pasta to share.  We got the salad before everything else so he was done with his meal way before we even got our dishes.

The mussels really were well cooked with good flavor.  The pasta was al dente if you like that style. The bread plate was pretty meh.  Cold bread with very ordinary hummus and butter for $11.  I wouldn't get it again.  

We sat at a "pig pen" for dinner which was pretty awkward service-wise.  Our server wasn't very friendly and some things fell off plates when they were brought to our table.

pics.caption: Bread plate with hummus, salted butter, and white cheddar pimento cheese

review.des:
My recent brunch at Publican was... life changing.

Brunch was a whim after a workout class with my friend - we drove on over to Publican (made a 12:30 reservation on the drive over) and ended up valet parking after a 5-10 min hunt for west loop parking ($12 if I remember correctly).

We were seated immediately at the end of a mostly empty communal table, and started in on the menu. Full disclosure, a close friend of my friend works here, and treated us to mini-mimosas and an olive oil cake to get started, and a good start it was indeed. The mimosas were translucent orange, which is the only way I think is right to serve a mimosa. We also ordered the spoon bread (temporary menu item) and the smoked Arctic char scramble, and I ordered a Bloody Mary. All was brought within a reasonable amount of time and our server was lovely.

The food was like heaven to my mouth. First of all, the olive oil cake (or loaf? I can't remember what it was called) was like a mild lemon bundt - not too sugary at all - with a lemon curd and like candied ginger or something on the plate. OMG I continued to die over this the entire time we were there and until the plate was cleaned.

(I've decided each of these food items deserves its own paragraph, so bear with me) My friend ordered the spoon bread because the server recommended it over the French toast, which is a menu staple. It came in this small cast iron skillet, and had a shredded brussel sprout slaw over it and it was divine. I admittedly didn't read the description on the menu, but whatever it said, it was amazing. Much more savory than I expected, just killer all the way around.

I had the Arctic char scramble which, I don't have much to say about due to its pretty simple composition, but I really enjoyed it. Delicious smoked Arctic char (tasted a lot like smoked salmon/smoked anything) with eggs and shallots and dill, served with toast. Yummy and filling for sure.

I also had the Bloody Mary (vodka version - they have a tequila version which I MUST try). It was the best bloody I've had in a long time if not ever. It had the perfect balance of spicyness, salty-vinegary-ness, and whatever else goes into a perfect Bloody Mary. Gah drooling thinking about it. So good, and had plenty of veg inside (I love to eat it).

Basically my soul was just as happy as can be enjoying that meal. We paid ~$30 a person before tip (not including the freebies) which I felt was surprisingly reasonable and definitely worth it.

I will be back, I can't wait to be back actually because I loved it so much. Thank you for such a dream of a meal!

pics.caption: Smoking Maria in the front, Bloody Mary in the back. Both amazing! Maria has tequila

review.des:
First off the service here is impeccable and that is what will have you coming back more than anything.  The food is great quality, you can taste the quality of produce and meat that they buy from the best farms.  
Overall, however, the food is just ok nothing to rant or rave about.  It's for people who want simple food with straightforward flavors without nuance.  It's sort of a steakhouse without the steak.  We had mussels, country ham, oysters, sirloin steak.  For the price of the food it's just not inventive or doing anything new.  If that's what you're looking for you will find it at The Publican with great attentive service.

Came here with a friend for dinner last week.  Had been here for Brunch once before so had high hopes.  We ordered the Barbecue Carrots (Good-very smoky and we were advised it has been on the menu since day one), Country Rib (Great), and Half Taste of Pulican La Querica (Tasty).  This ended up being plenty for the 2 of us-along with several beers.  Service was very attentive too.

Prices are great for the quality and the West loop location. I would 100% come back again for brunch or dinner!

Made a reservation the other night (no its not part of restaurant week, but I'd been here before for amaze balls brunch and was curious how the dinner would be).  Came with a couple friends.  They provide a coat check and valet is outside for $12.  The lighting is subdued and there are many stand up tables near the bar where I met my friends before sitting down right away.  The server was smiling and engaging.  We were offered water quicker than I could ask (#watergameonpoint) and a warm basket of bread.  The server suggested two items per person, but together we ordered four, and if we were still hungry, we'd order more.  No sense in taking it home if unnecessary.  The dishes are tapas style (meant for sharing) and come out as ready.  

Started out with a full portion of the Bouchot mussels.  Oh boy.  These succulent monsters!  They were bold and beautiful (better than the short lived Soap Opera), and good sized suckers.   Nothing puny here!  Buttery and seasoned with bay leaf and garlic in a broth.  It came with a nice sized baguette that is just crusty on the outside with a soft fleshy interior, perfect for soaking up the leftover bath.  

I also ordered the charcuterie plate.  A carnivorous feast on a plate.  Slices of sour beer salami (great color and temperature and sliced with precision).  The harissa pâte was delicious and a bit salty, which I love, great to spread on more baguette.  The Morteau sausage was incredible, and accompanied with the sour and bitterness of the caper berries sent my mouth into not talking mode.  The pork pie was less impressive for me, as the crust was greasy and chunky, a little gummy.  

The brussel sprout salad was also tasty, but due to poor lighting, I couldn't get a great shot.  Shredded sprouts, with apple for a natural sweetness and tart, honey, pear, and Marcona almonds were all spot on components.  

My friends had the smoked pork shank, but I was already full, and waiting for dessert.  Of course.

The pavlova was a burnt vanilla ice cream/gelato underneath multiple shards of toasted milk meringue, with a flurry of tangerine powder.  Simply stated, elegant.  Fun.  Aesthetically pleasing.

Such a fun vibe and outstanding food.

Service was ON POINT!

Next time I'm in Chicago, I will definitely be back :)

Went for Saturday brunch. Food was good - wish they had more egg options as there was really only one dish (avocado scramble which was good) on this particular day. Pork shnitzel was okay. Would come back to explore other menus as I'm sure they change a lot. The atmosphere was cool and different.

Out of all the great places in the West Loop, I'd skip this place. Large dining hall-style restaurant with nonchalant-but-forceful service and mediocre food. I will have to say their vegetable dishes were very, very good--definitely try the barbeque carrots!--but the main meats, like the porchetta, were disappointing, albeit big portioned. Probably great for large family dinners but definitely not for special occasions. Great beer list though.

Absolutely excellent food in a fun environment. A group of 5 of us were extremely well treated (originally only had reservations for 4) and the group showed up in stages.

Food was award worthy. Had the daily pickles (nicely done not over sour) and chicken liver pate (delicious and that bread) to start.

Mains included the sirloin (not fair to call it a sirloin it came across as hanger steak and was smoked!), striped bass (this is what I was expecting at a James beard award winning chef in Atlanta) which everyone remarked was perfectly seasoned, and Serrano ham with goat cheese (to die for).

On top of that the cocktails were absolutely top shelf. Whenever I am in Chicago again this will be a must visit.

We were really excited to check this place out after reading wonderful reviews. It had delicious food, but overpriced for the portions. We were told it was family style, but the portions for the sirloin and beef were appetizer sized. Ambiance is great, but not rushing to go back.

I came here with my coworkers on a Tuesday night. We had been travelling all day so this was actually my first meal....so maybe my opinions on this meal is a little skewed? Book reservations in advance because this place can get packed. If you don't like sitting close to strangers, make sure you request for your own table and ask to not be seated at the communal ones. It got pretty snug, but I personally didn't mind it.

As for the food, I don't recommend coming to this place with a small party. Everything is served family style. Some portions are very big, and some are very small. I'd recommend asking the waitress what his or her thoughts are on the sizing for your party.

VEGETABLES
1. Avocado Salad - The avocado pieces are big, flavor was good, but this dish is meant to be split between 2 people.
2. Asparagus - This was good, but like the avocado salad, really meant to be split between two people.  

BREAD
3. Taste of Three & Bread - This is a pretty big plate! We had a party of 10 and had leftovers. The plate comes with sour dough bread (with really crispy crusts) and three types of spread. Cultured butter & seat salt, sunflower sikil pak & mint, and white cheddar pimento cheese. It seems to be AYCE bread because the waitress was able to bring us another round when she saw we had left over spread.

SEAFOOD
4. Halibut - This was okay. This is a very small serving size and honestly should be enough for one person. I thought the flavoring was okay, but this is really unmemorable. Nothing horrible, nothing amazing. For $30, you're better off spending it on another dish.
5. Oysters - These were soooo good. They were big, juicy, and incredibly fresh. I also really enjoyed their mignonette sauce.

MEAT
6. Charcuterie Plate - A large selection of random meats for all the carnivores out there. Here are some items it came with: salami, pate, sausage, etc. I thought everything was delicious. My favorite would be the pate, maybe because it tastes just like the pates they have in banh mi. Yum!
7. Spicy Pork Rinds - This is more of an appetizer, but it was soooooo good. We ended up ordering two. It's light, flavorful and actually not spicy at all. My favorite appetizer of the night.
8. Farm Chicken - You can opt for a whole chicken or half. Since we had a large party, we went with the whole one. I thought this dish was okay. The chicken was a little dry for me. The fries that sit underneath was nothing out of the ordinary.
9. Pork Belly - This was the one dish that my coworkers raved about before we arrived. It's very flavorful and savory. I think this one is a must if you're coming here. The dish is pretty small so I wouldn't recommend sharing one with more than 4 people.
10. Sirloin Steak - This was cooked very well. I'm a huge steak person so if you are too, I'd recommend this one.

Overall, I really enjoyed this place. I say only come with large parties so you can try all the different dishes. Expect to drop some cash, but I don't think you'd regret it. Hopefully I will be back next time I'm in Chicago.
Delicious brunch in chicago. The fried chicken is a must have when it is on the menu and a side of bacon is required for all.

Go here for the beer selection and meat quality but you have to tolerate really slow service and shared tables. The cool thing about this spot is every waiter is beer certified so they really help direct you in choosing a beer to your taste. Unfortunately, the service was painfully slow and you're basically hitting elbows with the diner sitting next to you unless you get into a private booth or high-top. On an uncrowded Sunday night we waited an hour between our bread plate and our chicharrones appetizer and then another 30 minutes for our Beef Tongue. It was as if our order was forgotten but the waiters didn't acknowledge it once or seem bothered. The food wasn't as impressive but still good. That being said the Beef Tounge was amazing - must order! Chicharrones were good, the bread with the pimento and pesto spread was very average which was surprising since they're known for they're bread. I'd go back for the beer and meat (I want to try their breakfast bacon) but would pass because of the unrelaxing table set-up and bad service (maybe it was a one-off?).

New favorite brunch spot in Chicagoland! This gem was located about a mile from downtown, a short Uber ride away and what we found was absolutely magic.

Upon entering we found ourselves in a very rustic type atmosphere, that was reminiscent almost of stables of yesteryear. There's a lot of exposed wood, some actual stable appearing booths on the left side of the restaurant, and some very fun bench seating that is accompanied by some counter height tables to stand out while you're waiting for your food to come. It's very conducive to conversation and is very laid back!

The food we had here was absolutely unreal. The pork belly, disguised on the menu as bacon, was glazed in maple syrup it was absolutely incredible. The coffee was delicious and was accentuated by the oddly shaped sugar cubes which were just delightful. In life, it really is the little things. My wife had a barrel aged black tea that was absolutely out of this world. We're fans of all things barrel aged at this point, and this is the first time we actually come across a good barrel aged tea. Little bit different flavor, but served hot, it was absolutely perfect.

The food here stood out among many of the places that we've been to recently. My wife had the red wine poached eggs which was reminiscent of eggs benedict crossed with purple eggs. It was basically the most delicious Dr Seuss book ever! I had the spoon bread for the recommendation of our server and it was absolutely amazing. It was like cornbread and grits had a baby that contained all of their best features. Sort of reminiscent of a soft quiche, with the cheese and bacon dwelling within. It was absolutely fantastic! Pair that with the aforementioned bacon and delicious beverages, and you've got the place we want to go to every weekend.

If you live in Chicago, you're lucky to have this place close by. If you don't live in Chicago and ever visit there, you should probably make this one of your stops. The meat shop across the way is a great way to finish up the morning and get yourself some delicious animal for the ride home.

This place was so freaking cute, from the lights hanging throughout the interior to the communal sinks near the bathroom (I know it sounds weird, but trust).

My publican mimosa tastes a lot like a blue moon, which was cool, but the coffee. Woah. I don't know what it was, but it was seriously the best coffee of my life. It was flavorful. Strong not too strong. Whatever it was, I couldn't get enough of the stuff. My sirloin was great, like better than most, but man that coffee.

My one complaint was the service: our waiter was nice, but didn't come around much, and same with the guy who refilled water and coffee. I ran out of my delicious nectar of the gods coffee, and it took what I thought was too long to flag someone down. Even when I did, he forgot, and I had to get my waiter and ask him. What's the point of bottomless coffee if you can't even get refills?

Not sure if publican meats has the same coffee. If it does, I would definitely stop by for a cup, and save myself the trouble of sitting down

wow has this place slid downhill. I've come here once a year for the past 10 years so maybe I've just been unlucky, but it feels like a trend. Historically it has always been too loud, too brash, too much swagger, large groups of guys there for the beer menu. But that was ok because the food used to be GREAT. Not so much, now. We had english peas (tasted of vinegar); beets (meh); and soft shell crab - the absolute worst I have ever had, in season too, glutinous and tasteless. Desserts were uninspiring. Don't do this. Chicago has extraordinary restaurants. Go there, instead.

Its the American version of Tapas.

Lots of farm to table options, so a lot of pork here. Great veggie options too.

Very interesting interior, interesting devotees. Very hipsters, but you can look past that and just eat well and you will be happy you did.

I LOVE the Publican! It's my FAVORITE restaurant! The servers are so knowledgeable and friendly. They really do a great job. They are always busy and yes you may sit next to strangers but it still feels comfy and comfortable. Their food is amazing! Fresh ingredients with genius flavor combo! I try to go home and replicate it but of course it's not easy! Hehe. If anyone I know is visiting Chicago, I always tell them to try this restaurant. (Only thing I will point out for restaurant to consider is.... when you walk in the main door and you go straight down, the seats located around the corner is in the pathway of servers going in and out from that corner area. One time I sat there and servers would constantly bump into me)

If you've ever wanted to experience what it must've been like to eat in a Medieval communal dining hall -- with much better food -- you've come to the right place! The Publican is a unique communal dining experience that definitely helped top our recent trip to Chicago.

The highlight of the meal was assuredly the suckling pig, which had delicious flavor and was perfectly balanced. A close second was a tie between the duck heart toast and the smoky carrots with dill sauce. We thought the chicken with fries needed a sauce and the accompanying sausage lacked flavor. The daily pickles were also a bit too sweet for our taste.

That being said, the overall delicious dishes combined with stellar service and a unique atmosphere made this a night to remember!

Some friends that live in Chicago recommended The Publican for dinner, so I had my first experience there last week, and it was great one.  The inside of the restaurant was a classy casual interior or as our Chicago local friend would call it, "urban chic".  We had a reservation, so we were seated as soon as we got there.  The place was packed and we went on a Monday night during the week of Christmas.  

The concept here is family style sharing, so everything that we ordered was placed in the center of the table and a group of four of us shared it.  I'll list everything that we ordered and will tell you my thoughts.

Let's start with the drinks...I ordered red wine and drank on that all night.  It was a decent bottle of Pinot Noir.

Avocado Salad
The salad was divine, I only wish I didn't have to share it.  The lemony dressing on this salad alone was killer.  If I were close to The Publican right now, I'd be there eating this.

Barbecue Carrots
These were hands down the best carrots I've ever been blessed to have.  The carrots were so soft and had the most amazing flavor.  The creamy dressing and pecans really kicked the carrots up a notch.

Brussels Sprouts
I love brussels sprouts and I've had many in my day, but never have I had shaved brussels sprouts salad quite like this one.  The honey vinaigrette was the star of this plate.

Frites with Barb's eggs
French fries are French fries and there's really no getting around it.  But, I'm still trying to figure out how these fries stayed crunchy even when we broke the fried egg yolk.  Let's just say, I've always needed ketchup with my fries, but not with these.  They were wonderful!

Daily Pickled Plate
This was an array of pickled cauliflower, onions, and pickles and I was amazed at how good this sour plate was.  

Black Bass
The light broth's aroma was just as pleasant as the taste.  This was one of my favorite dishes of the night and I had the pleasure of eating most of it myself.  The seabass was cooked just right and went very well with the basil broth it was drenched in.  It was very refreshing.

Hake
I've never had hake before, but I finally got the chance to try it and it was heavenly with the cream sauce, corn, and potatoes.  

Ham Chop "in hay"
I'm not a fan of pork, but I could have eaten on this all night long.  None of my friends would believe me when I say this, but this was actual my absolute favorite of the night.  The ham was cooked just right and had a delicious flavor I couldn't resist.

Apple Crisp
This dessert is huge, so it's perfect for four people to share.  I thought I made the best homemade apple crisp until I came here and tried this one.  The cinnamon apples were divine with the crispy granola topping and ice cream.

The food was so great that we almost went back the next night!  Overall, we had a great experience and wonderful time trying all of the food together.  I highly recommend this spot!

The Publican has been voted the 'Best Restaurant Design' by the James Beard Foundation. It is no doubt one of the coolest restaurant designs I've seen, the dining room lights and bathrooms are truly captivating. The unique brunch menu and cool ambience/decor makes The Publican one of our favorite restaurants in Chicago. Love the perfectly cooked hash browns and maple bacon. Don't miss out on their bloody Mary's, it comes with a choice of beer shooter, YUM!!

pics.caption: Bloody Mary with a choice of beer shooter. The pickled cauliflower and dill pickle was amazing.

review.des:
Underwhelming in every way possible. From the seating (placed weirdly right next to another couple even though the restaurant was empty when we arrived) to the food. Pork belly was dry and was essentially just an overlooked, dry (and small) piece of pork fat.  Farm chicken was again dry and the fries tasted like they had been fried in pure fat.

Redeeming qualities: summer sausage was tasty, and the billeted were strong.  Best part were the waitstaff-- very attentive bussers who cleared plates and refilled waters constantly.

There are plenty of better options in the neighborhood.

Got there on a very cold morning, and the very first thing I ordered was a Bloody Mary. And yes... That was the start of great decisions that I made that day at the Publican. This place was packed at 11:30 am on Sunday so I would advice you to make a reservation. Their waiting area/bar is right in the middle of the restaurant which, being different, just didn't feel right. But I didn't have to wait too long as my reserved table/booth was ready. And yes, I love that the booths have doors! Waiters were attentive and efficient and knowledgable which really helped with picking a great brunch pick. I went with the chicken and dumplings which didn't seem a lot, but was surprisingly filling. It came in a shallow soup plate. Trust me- even though it might have looked ordinary, it has flavor and warmth to hit the spot on a very cold Sunday morning!

I paired that dish with their Burton's maple syrup-braised Publican bacon, and that took that meal to a whole new level. I could try to describe the two chunks of pork belly coated with the maple syrup sweetness but I would fail to do justice to that side dish. I have taken pictures of it but honestly, it was so good, that I walked across to the Publican meat market just to get those chunks of pork belly so that I can try to cook them myself!

All in all, it's a cozy place (for brunch at least) with great options and with great service! They do have valet parking, as well, if you don't want to deal with trying to find a spot.

I've gone to The Publican multiple times for dinner, but this was the first time I tried it for brunch.  It was a wonderful experience.  The space was nice and bright in the daytime.  The bloody mary's were spicy and delicious.  We were lucky to get the last sticky bun, which acted as a perfect appetizer.  Scrambled eggs with mushrooms were very tasty.  Lonza added a unique meaty experience to the eggs benedict.  Publican Quality Meats were also featured in the thick-cut bacon and sausage sides.
Excellent vibe, pork lover heaven.  Excellent counter service - will come back when in town.

Came here for brunch on Saturday afternoon. Make reservations at least a few days in advance, because they do fill up quickly and there was a wait when we arrived. An explanation of the rating:

Atmosphere- Lovely, very lively. They have different seating options (high tables and then more private ones with swinging doors). If you don't mind a noisy and bustling environment then you'll like The Publican.

Service- Overall, speedy, though we had to remind our waitress to bring a few things at certain points. We were seated quickly because we had a reservation.

Food- Very good. I wanted to try the spoon bread but they ran out. Instead I had their eggs with chorizo. Overall very flavorful. Their sauce is homemade. My friend had the french toast which is a menu staple. If you've got a sweet tooth, you'll love it. They also give you coffee. We ordered their pecan sticky bread, it was DELICIOUS. You must get it! Their baguette with homemade nutella... not so much. I had very high expectations. Our waitress was nice and didn't charge us for it because she noticed we barely ate it.

Overall, I recommend this spot for a good brunch. The only reason why I gave it a 4 is because there were about 3 things we ordered (2 entrees) that they had run out of. Otherwise, a great experience!

pics.caption: Eggs with chorizo sauce (which was homemade). Very tasty!

review.des: Outstanding brunch. The Publican has Saturday and Sunday brunch and as expected it was crowded and reservations a must even at 1:30pm. We got seated in the dining room, a really cool venue with shared seating; throwback wood paneling sort of like an old school pub. Beer menu is surprisingly good for a brunch spot (although their dinner is just as notorious). About 10 draughts and 30 bottles, leaning highly towards international with about 5 local beers as well in bottles.  The food lives up to the hype for sure. In total we had the donut, sweet potato pound cake, bacon, and mushroom scramble. The sweets were delicious and came out quick and fresh. Really nice candies walnuts and whipped cream on the pound cake made that dish a winner. The bacon was as expected. Large pork belly that reminds me of a cut through ham, with a much stronger taste. Fantastic and must have addition to any brunch. The mushroom scramble was just a really good dish. Cheesy scramble with fresh mushrooms and a few pieces of charred toast, the best way to cook bread.  The Publican had everyone seated from families to groups to single diners. This place is great and every dish looked good. Definitely a winner in Chicago.

I've seen this place reviewed on at least one food show, and noticed they had opened a location at O'Hare. The day to come is Sunday. Check out the awesome brunch specials. I had the Pastrami hash. It was awesome... in fact, it was SO awesome, that the couple seated next to me asked what it was, and also ordered it.

I really, really, really want to rate this place much better than three stars but our visit on Saturday was pretty upsetting.

I decided to organize a quick group brunch before I went traveling for the holidays and heard nothing but great things about The Publican. I made a reservation almost a week in advanced and was extremely excited to try out the joint.

When we arrived about 5 minutes before our reservation, we were told that we needed to wait a few minutes before our table was going to be ready which was fine. The wait turned into a 30 minute wait in a small corridor at its entrance where guest were walking in out of the restroom. I tried not to let that ruin the mood as we finally got seated at a very unique long communal table which I thought was very cool.

Now, here comes the fun part - we look at the menu and two items are already sold out. Two items that most of us wanted to have and try out. There were about five other options available as the menu isn't too big so I decided to ask for the biscuits and chorizo gravy. Not so fast though, that was now sold out as well. At that point I was so frustrated and upset - I could not enjoy the rest of the brunch.

Although the waiter did send over comp'd menu items it was nothing any of us wanted and it left all of us pretty upset. In fact a few even stating they wouldn't return. I would like to give these guys another chance as I really enjoyed the environment but unfortunately cannot give an accurate review for their popular menu items.

Hoping they can figure out their inventory and actually allow people to eat after 12:30.

I am not a vegetarian but if I got to eat the vegetables at The Publican every day I could easily be turned. This place just had amazing veggies, but that is not all that is amazing - I was blown away by the entire meal.
The whole community table concept can be a bit daunting at first but once you start tucking into your first course (or your first cocktail) any awkwardness goes away. I was with a fairly large group but we still ended up meeting some cool people down the table from us as we bonded over the delicious barbecue carrots. I still have dreams about how good these carrots are.
Even if you are not into veggies, The Publican needs to be on your list. The oysters are top notch and the farm chicken was one of my other favorite items on the menu. I would try to get as many people together for a group here as it will allow you to try a lot of different things. The added benefit of the community dining experience is seeing what dishes other people are ordering. It's classier than pictures on the menu but gets the trick done!
Getting a booking here can sometimes be tough and it's worth it to plan early, especially for a larger group size. I will certainly be back, but until then I will keep dreaming about those carrots.

Never did I ever think I would enjoy the feeling of pork grease running down my gullet so much! Nor did I ever think I would ever enjoy pork rinds, period. Even the daring beef heart tartare was not something I'd normally order, but alas, it was incredible.

This place comes with a lot of hype, has an incredibly overpriced beer list, and is a place to see and be seen. The hype is warranted, the beer is delicious (free beers since we sat at the bar certainly didn't hurt), and the servers are cordial, friendly, and know their shit.

The rillettes are delightfully rich and greasy - arguably the best pork I've ever tasted in my life. The raspberry jam is a perfect accoutrement and the toasted sourdough works well as a base. The pork rinds are dusted with a bomb spice and cheese blend that makes them better than any bar snack I've ever tasted. The most unique dish, the beef heart tartare, featured a curious addition of pine nuts and pomegranate seeds, which gave it a sour kick and also a great texture. The cheese on the bread was a great finish to the dish.

Since the food here is so rich, order one dish at a time, or you'll get full and not be able to finish your food. I'm ashamed that it took me eight years to finally come eat here. Truly a meat-lover's paradise.

I'm a bit disappointed with this place. I made reservations for brunch and they did sit us right away but the floor was dirty with a piece of a broken mug. There was food on the floor they hadn't picked up. The service was ok nothing special. The food was expensive and the plates were small not like the pics from others. The menu was very limited they didn't have many of the items I see on the pictures. Two eggs alone are $9 and a side of their bacon which was just okay was $7. For brunch they had very limited options. They only had like three dishes with egg and like I mentioned before the portions were small. My friend ordered a mimosa and it was very small and overpriced. I wouldn't go back. Huge disappointment I took a few friends here because they were new to Chicago and I was embarrassed more than anything. Not worth the $$$.

Where do you go if you want to be with other foodies? Chicago has many great choices but if you are craving gastropub and superb meat proteins, head over to Publican.  Pork rinds and his belly, with an order of their brussel sprouts are great plates to share with the table as I am sure are other items on the menu.  Personally I noticed the "Chefs Menu", which allows "the kitchen decide".  I'll need to return for this. These guys are too legit for me to decide.

Who doesn't love bacon?
Publican is a fun place to eat and their meat selections are great! I also was pleasantly surprised by their mushroom strata. So  yum ( I do think their brunch selection changes though)!

The communal seating isn't always my favorite but I'll do it for the Publican! It's fun when you can snag a table too! I love the lighting inside and I appreciate the laid back vibe.

it's def worth a try!

pics.caption: This dish was OK but I say go for their meat dishes!
I think this picture speaks for itself ;P

review.des:
The Publican always has some fantastic offerings on the menu. Since most of the dishes are quite small and intended for sharing, you'll have an opportunity to try a good number things before your belly is full.

Each category on the menu has something worth trying. However, every time someone in our party orders the pickles I feel like they're exceptionally sour even for pickles. The pork dishes in particular are usually incredibly tasty. And I was very impressed with the super fresh raw oysters. Keep in mind that these tiny dishes are priced like full sized dishes. It adds up very quickly.

The restaurant is often times packed, and most people end up sitting right beside strangers at the long communal tables. Hopefully you'll be lost in conversation with your dinner companions, because the big crowds and high volume of dishes going back and forth can take its toll on the servers. Sometimes you'll find yourself waiting a bit for an opportunity to place an order. But, we've been lucky so far and everyone there is capable, professional, and personable.

My friends and I were visiting Chicago and came here for dinner and had an INCREDIBLE time. The atmosphere is top notch, from the pig portraits, to the bathrooms, to the paper straws (thanks for saving the environment!), it really felt like they embraced their theme. The food was great - our favorite was the sirloin, asparagus, and chicken. The family style meal was perfect, and our waitress gave us great advice on how best to order for our group. The staff was wonderful - jovial, attentive, and courteous. Would recommend this place for any group, and special occasion. Make sure to ask why the ring the bell.

I had such a great dinner at The Publican! Went on a Saturday for an early evening date so it wasn't crazy busy and our waiter was perfect. Friendly, knowledgeable and he looked a little like my brother so maybe I was a little biased. Anyway, we ordered the Chef's Menu which was just, perfect! I am attaching photos because words can't do it any justice. Surprisingly the vegetarian dishes were the highlights - the deliciousness of the Cauliflower has been haunting me since! And just when I thought it couldn't get any better, we were given the fluffiest waffle I've ever had topped with ice-cream (which had lemon or orange shortbread bits inside, heaven!) and a box of various biscuits and cakes which we took home with us because we were stuffed. Our bill came up to about $200 including tip and a couple of non-alcoholic cocktails. Ambiance get's pretty loud as the evening goes on but still maintains a low-key vibe with mellow lighting and clean minimal furnishings. Writing this review is bringing it all back. I would definitely go back and I would highly recommend - HELL YES!
Amazing brunch...highly recommend the pork rinds, pound cake, and maple glazed bacon. Love the ambience.

Wow. My friend whom were were visiting in Chicago RAVES about this place, and he wasn't overselling it. We came here as a group of 5. We split the tasting menu, which had so much great food. SO MUCH FOOD. Every time we thought it was over, they'd bring more dishes. Our favorites were the duck and strawberry jam with toast, the crab, the pork rinds, and the pork belly. The desserts also did not disappoint; there were three of them! My favorite was the pavlova for sure, but I am partially swayed by the presentation of the kitty cookie jar filled with little cookies and treats. I will be back for sure!

pics.caption: Fish they deboned cooked with mussels and pomegranate

review.des:
Great sandwiches and great meat!
Had the seasonal chicken wrap with chick peas and a great vinaigrette sauce  of the house!

Chicago sure does love it's pork, and brunch is a great way to enjoy it!

we were surprised by the communal seating, you sit RIGHT next to strangers and across from your partner!
---spicy pork rinds: mMmm kind of tasted like creamy cheetoes (not in a bad way), these were a nice snack
---red wine poached eggs with prosciutto: PERFECTLY poached eggs, but didn't think the red wine added much to the dish
---asparagus fettunta: a HEFTY plate if you're hungry! if you like asparagus this is all you

top it all off with some fresh squeezed orange juice or grapefruit juice to wash it down

NOTE: they also have a market with a more casual cafe a block away

pics.caption: Asparagus fettunta, spicy pork rinds, and red wine poached eggs

review.des: First of all Amazing staff!!! Its crazy how they make you feel like you've been coming here forever (Aaron the bartender and Gio and actually anyone working who passed by!) Im from out of town and i came here because a bunch of famous chefs recommend this  restaurant on tv! I loved the food and service. Try the pork rinds . You're welcome

We went here for Sunday brunch. The food was excellent.  There were 4 of us, and everyone loved their food.  We started with the bacon (get it - you won't be disappointed). Between the four of us, we had French toast, a Belgian waffle, the pork shoulder, and some sides.  My favorite was the French toast.  My husband favored the pork shoulder.

Mimosas are $10, which I guess is average for Chicago, but seems crazy to me

The location is pretty hip.  There's a patio, and the inside has family style dining, plus some individual booths.  

It was about a 10 minute uber from downtown.
Great location, great brunch menu, great food! Our waiter was so kind and everything was good.

pics.caption: Bloody Mary with tequila, fun spin on the BM, I prefer the traditional which they do have but this was a festive twist
Red wine poached eggs benny was great!

review.des: Hard to beat this staple in Chicago. My family and I ordered a lot of different sides, including spring onions with honey and smoked carrots. Everything was done in a original way and everything tasted great! I had the porchetta, which was also excellent. We also ordered the chicken with fries, but I was not as impressed with that dish. However, everything else was amazing and I would recommend this place to anyone in town! The restaurant is beautifully decorated and our waiter did a great job. You can even order beer for the kitchen staff if you enjoyed your meal!

This place will obviously present some limitations to vegans and devout Jews since almost everything involved a pig in some way. The rest of us will roll around in pig product and sprinkle bacon on everything.

We came with a reservation for 2 on our last trip to Chicago. The communal tables were more awkward than novel. It was so cramped that I had to ask the lady standing behind me at a high top to move so I could  get out. Then, there's the fact that you're probably crammed sitting next to a bunch of other people on dates, and all of you are trying quite hard to be friendly while basically ignoring each other. The proximity can be pretty distracting, and I'm not sure I'd come unless I had a group big enough to secure a booth.

The fries were delicious - made in bacon fat, I believe - and served with aioli the way we like it. They came piping hot and presented in a paper cone just like they were from in Belgium.

The sea bass was disappointing. Good rice with gumbo flavors and pancetta, but the fish didn't stand out to me. Definitely an opportunity lost here.

The suckling pig on the other hand was AMAZING - especially the caramelized, melt in your mouth shredded part. The white meat was more like pork chop and went well with the beans and sauce.

A ham half portion is plenty for 2 people, or just a small taste for 4, probably 1.5-2oz meat per person with a buttery-type spread.

Fun night out, but not somewhere I'd be itching to revisit.

The quality and variety of flavors and textures in the vegetable dishes were  fabulous. The boquerones were well seasoned. The roast chicken which I rarely order was perfect. I think the precision of the entire meal reminds me of some of the best meals at Chez Panisse in Berkeley. The service was efficient and very welcoming. If I lived in Chicago I would be a regular.

Okay, now THIS is brunch. I probably shouldn't fail to mention that I ordered 6 different things and was dining alone. But how can you not when dining at Publican? Everything looks so damn good. And what's better? It tastes even better. Do have the bacon. And the frites with fried egg.

When I come to Chicago, I come to the Publican.  The bottomless is coffee is hair-raising and the selection for breaky-brunch is excellent.  You can come early, before 10AM and get a table, or just chat it up with the neighbors in their famous communal table.  The pancakes are awesome, and def try the bacon.  They have skimped a little bit on the size of the bacon this last time, but still pretty tasty.  Their bathroom setup is pretty cool and the service is always A+ even with a packed house!

The food was good. I really liked the mussels and the oysters, both are a must-try.

I was a little disappointed with the servers lack of wine knowledge. They had a great opportunity to pair wine with their dishes, but our waiter had no recommendations. We knew oysters and champagne go well, but would have liked to have a wider spread of options.

This is more of an observation, and therefore has no bearing in my star ranking. If you do not like shared seating, do not go here. The problem with communal seating is that 1) it's hard to hear your dinner companion from across their long table, especially in their restaurant which can get quite loud. 2) we had mussels, oysters, and a champagne bucket out on the table at one time, which took up a lot of space and was encroaching on our neighbors space.

We went there on Sunday at 1:00 pm for brunch. The hostess were so confused and told us the wait is 30 min and we were fine to wait and then they called us in 3 min that you table is ready. We were surprised how quickly we got a table . Food was excellent. Service was not so good. The servers brought Wong food twice for us. Bloody merry was awesome it came with a small glass for f beer on the side. I give 4 star fir awesome food. Hopefully they work on their service

AMAZING brunch! No wonder it's on the top 10 Zagat list of best brunches in Chicago! The Publican really isnphenomenal. The portions are huge! I was actually sad to only be able to eat half of mine and not be able to take the other half with me back to my hotel.

The dishes here are fresh and innovative, with the great blending of unique ingredients. They make a mean Bloody Mary and had a nice beer list as well. Already eager to return back to Chicago to come for dinner. Five stars aren't enough to express how much I love this place!

pics.caption: Sourdough pancakes with sausage and bacon wrapped chicken thigh

review.des: One of my favorites in town. The flavors are explosive! We had the charcuterie plate, bbq carrots, the striped bass, the fluke, pork belly and the country rib. All were great but I think the country rib and the fluke stole the show! It was my second time there and they did not disappoint. I'll be back!

Check out the blog for more details!

------

After having visited Alinea the last time I was in Chicago, I knew I had to try one of Paul Kahan's restaurants this time around. Chef Kahan's a compatriot of vaunted Philly chef Marc Vetri, likely rooted from being in the 1999 James Beard Award Best New Chef class. Kahan has a veritable Chicago empire with the lauded Black Bird, Avec, Publican Quality Meats, and of course, the Publican, just to name a few. The fact that other well-established chefs are using PQM meats for their menu speaks volumes; clearly the Kahan family's dedication to quality butchery and charcuterie is on point.

2014 George T. Stagg Antique Collection [$20]

I was able to enjoy a nice pour of the 2014 Buffalo Trace Antique Collection - Stagg to be exact. FYI - the 2015 collection is already popping up across the nation! This was quite the treat - straight out of the barrel, uncut, and unfiltered. Neat was the way to go, with smooth toffee notes that lent way to an ineffable sweetness, though with an undeniable kick that hits you to the back of your throat from the spice and the barrel-proof strength. On the finish, there were nice notes of fruit, coffee, and raisin.

Madai Snapper Crudo [$18]
Tsukiji Market madai, habazi spice, apple, mint

And with my first taste, I was sold. Snapper from Tsukiji? You can't fault the sourcing. Technique takes care of ensuring the snap and texture of the high-quality fish. But the true star for me? The crudo was incredibly seasoned. The salt really opened up the palate while also allowing you to taste the accents to the fish. The herbaceousness of the mint balanced the unoffending undertones of the Shabazzi oil, with the bright tartness of the apple really coming through on the forefront with a bit of acidity. I also appreciated how the Shabazzi coated the tongue - light and clean. Amazing.

Porchetta [$33]
Slagel Family Farm, roasted clams, corn, pea tendrils

The Publican is often described as pork paradise. I can see why. In addition to providing hefty portions of both the wrapped loin and the gorgeously unctuous yet crisped pork belly exterior, the accompanying elements to the dish were clearly carefully thought out. The Korean in me heard the call of bosam. I mean pork and bivalves? Yes, please! The sweet clams also had an innate salinity that accented the notes of sweet corn and hits of salt from the pork. The broth was light when compared to the rest of the dish, but also worked to heighten the heft of the dish especially when the cream sauce melded in. The potatoes were slightly crisp on the outside, but lent way to perfectly roasted innards.

The Publican - Porchetta

But in the end, it is all about that pork. The loin was moist and meaty. The belly portion? A contrast in crisp and gluttonous textures with everything I love about pork belly coming through. Admittedly, it might be a bit much for some and may be better shared. But for me, there was no sharing. From first bite to last, I knew I had a smile with each forkful. I am still talking about food, right?

How could I possible top the last bite? With the last dregs of BTAC Stagg of course, real deal whiskey sediment included. Happiness.

Butterscotch Pudding [$11]
Vanilla cream, cashew brittle, oatmeal cookies

And for someone who doesn't have much of a sweet tooth, the extreme heft of the porchetta called for some sweetness to balance out the palate. So I went with their butterscotch pudding, which offered light vanilla, which was a nice countervailing element to the nice hits of sweet and salty cashew toffee brittle. The pudding itself was the pure essence of butterscotch, with some levity. The oatmeal cookies had great texture and were incredibly buttery. Milk was needed. But instead ...

Kyle's "After Pork" Digestif [$9]

For obvious reasons, I opted to try chief mixologist Kyle's "after pork" digestif. Benny was kind enough to comp the easily quaffable concoction, which featured Cynar, dark rum, Chartreuse, and mint. With the rum providing a sweet substantive foundation, the light bitterness from the artichoke and herbal liquers made for a refreshing end to the meal. Very nice.

Not only does the Publican have a strong pork program (that obviously extends to the rest of their menu!), but they also make sure to have high quality drinks and beers on offer. How many places do you know that have BTAC and Van Winkle 12 Year Special Reserve on hand this late in the season? And while the food and drink at the Publican is top notch, it's the service will earn my reco as the spot to go to if you're in need of the former.

pics.caption: Last Dregs of the 2014 George T Stagg Antique Collection

review.des:
3 stars, for dinner. Just average food in an environment that is trying to be unique.

- Communal seating: meh, way too tight for my taste. Not a fan of rubbing elbows (literally) with the two people next to me, and hearing every word of their conversation.
- Flounder Crudo: Good flavor, small portion, nothing amazing.
- Little Gem salad: Pretty good. Loved the crispy pig ears on top. It's a nice and unique touch to the salad!
- Country ribs: Its a pork chop. We couldn't even finish eating it. Dry, charred, tons of fat.
- Mussels: Butter, butter and more butter. Oh wait, there's some mussels. Did I mention butter?
- Wine: As someone who frequents Napa Valley and Sonoma Valley, the glass of Pinot Noir tasted like a 2-buck chuck.

We left half our meal uneaten and didn't finish the wine. I'm not understanding the high rating for this place.

The restaurant is a happening place. Not formal but welcoming.

Service was great, my waiter was friendly and took time to explain the theme of restaurant and their cuisine. He was attentive, possibly due to that it was not as busy a night.

I had the blood sausage which I think was not what I expected - buy hey, it's a blood sausage, for sure you taste the blood. :)

I like the concept of the restaurant and really support the idea of sourcing ingredients from nearby farms. Will go back for more next time I visit Chicago.

I like this restaurant. All the dishes are fresh, especially the seafood (definitely is a great place for oysters). It is  communal seating (although there are a few private booths for 4 or more people), and the dishes are generally meant to be shared, as they are large.  The craft beer and wine menu are good as well. I have been here several times, and have had largely good experiences, although I had one bad experience right after the Xmas holiday. You can get a reservation here, as opposed to the trendy and way overrated Girl and the Goat (I found the food here better).  There is a really lively atmosphere, although I wish they could tone down the music a bit. It is on the expensive side.

We went there for brunch. Although we made a reservation and were one of the first people there that morning, it took a while for us to be seated. The food was good, borderline okay. We weren't overly excited with any of it. Service was just okay too. Maybe too much hype caused the let down, or may it's a brunch vs. dinner difference. Not sure, but with all the other amazing options in Chicago, not sure if I would go here again.

Most people know to not walk into a butcher's restaurant and expect to be served a salad. Well, expect diet-sized portions at this place. I got 4 pork belly cubes for $27. You walk in hungry, you'll walk out hungry.

Good, quality food that is expensive and overrated. Laughable beer menu.

Got the cauliflower($13), squid ink pasta($20), ham trio plate($25), and the panna cotta. Overall just decent, nothing that blew us out of the water for the high price points. Pasta had an okay lemon sauce but bad  consistency compared to other fresh ink pastas we have had in the past. Ham was okay, nothing special. Cauliflower was fried well and had a pretty good spicy honey sauce but would not come back just for that.

The beer menu was full of $14 to $50 beers that only had around 7% ABV. Pretentious AF. Around $14 is what I expect to pay for a fancy small batch beer of abv 11% or higher at an expensive restaurant.

What a fun place. The sitting is communal which is fun and they have private booths along the side wtb interesting doors on the booths. You'll have to see it to understand.

The drink menu has some traditional staples but also some fun new twists on drinks. The food was amazing. Couldn't decided between 5 dishes. But ended up landing on the Reuben hash which was sooooooo good. I highly recommend it.

Valet out front for $12 since here isn't a place in the entire area to park ever.

And that's all I have to say about that.
Jackée

Great locally sourced and straightforward food (had the 1/2 porchetta, beets, and ham sampler) in an elegant, but not fancy atmosphere. Would have preferred a slightly shorter menu, but luckily my dining companion's gluten allergy helped us pare it down. Our server was excellent. Beer list tends big and bold, but tasty. The room was not super full and it still felt a little bit too loud for the width of the tables (tone down the music a pinch?).

I'm taking 1.5 stars off, though, because there was a nice chunk of twine in my porchetta leftovers. Mistakes happen, but that's pretty sloppy for the reputation and price point of this place.

My friend and I were looking for a restaurant to eat dinner on a Friday and decided to stop in and check if there were any openings. Luckily, we got a table right away! We were seated outside which was nice because it wasn't as loud as inside. We weren't that hungry so we only ordered 2 dishes: fried cauliflower and suckling pig. The fried cauliflower was surprisingly light; the batter didn't weigh it down at all. The suckling pig was a good portion to share. It was very tender and flavorful.  I recommend both dishes. Also, our server was very friendly and helpful. The Publican is a solid choice for a delicious dinner!
Fantastic corn beef hash and Dutch baby. The sticky roll was probably the best I have ever had. Bottomless coffee = thanks you, baby Jesus.

I've never been so disappointed in a top tier restaurant.  After reading so many wonderful reviews I took a group of friends to Easter Brunch at The Publican.  The food was okay, not out of this world.  But it's the service that I really want to comment on.

We had so much trouble getting the attention of the very disinterested servers.  They literally would walk past our table as we were waving them down...and all we wanted were simple, reasonable, things like fill empty water glasses or to offer us dessert.  One of my companions suggested that they looked like they were wasted.  And, on second thought, I think she was right.  The servers seemed much more interested in huddling in the corner socializing with each other than seeing what their tables might need. I can see from another honest reviewer below who was there the same day that we were not the only ones who had a hard time with the wait staff.

The real coup de grace, however, was that at 2pm the staff decided to crank the music up absurdly loud.  Add to that it was a really obnoxious choice of music for dining.  It was so loud we couldn't even hear the person next to us. I love a good party, and I get the "commons" aspect of sharing tables--but this was really inappropriate.  And, of course, incredibly annoying.

My interpretation?  I think that the real management was not on duty this day.  There is no excuse for what happened that morning.  It was a stunt by a bunch of unprofessional servers who didn't want to be there.

My response?  Six foodies who will never go back.  There are a million fantastic restaurants in Chicago, all which take pride in providing a pleasant dining experience.  Why bother?

Bottom line:    Absolutely no professional pride.  Go across the street to Beatrix or next door to Duck Duck Goat.  You'll have a great meal and a pleasant experience. To heck with this joint.

Went here last night, had reservations but decided to sit next to each other at the bar instead of across from each other at one of the larger tables.

We had the razor clam ceviche, taste of three hams, green beans with peaches and feta, and pork belly with grits. They were all delicious, we liked them in that order. Razor clams were tasty, but it's served warm and it's a fairly small portion for the price. The hams were salty, sweet, and balanced, served with bread and goat butter. I liked them all, my fiancee didn't care for the sweet one.

Those green beans though, they were amazing. Almonds, peppers, goat cheese, grilled peaches, some amazing vinaigrette. I'd eat that all day. Then the pork belly was divine, cooked perfectly on top of grits.

Had one of the cheeses for dessert, tasty as well, a brie-like goat cheese with blueberries and crunchy flat bread like chips.

Service was great, food might have been slow to come out at first but we were having a good time and barely noticed. Probably not a place for a quick dinner or if you don't like your company. Great for us, we bought the kitchen a six pack.

Would definitely go again.

I used to love this place. I was looking forward to coming back when I visited Chicago, and in fact made a reservation weeks in advance. Went on a Sunday morning, beat the rush actually, in fact probably didn't even need a reservation. Everyone is always nice, and we got seated quite promptly.

Coffee is strong and is apparently a special blend from Intelligentsia. Publican, I give you that! You gotta have good, strong, flavorful coffee for the brunch crown. Am I right?

We had the crab scramble, chicken fried steak, and side of bacon.

Crab scramble - worthwhile. Eggs were fluffy and quite a bit of crab. Tasted fresh, light and not too heavy. The creme fraiche and pickled shallot added the extra kick to this already simple, yet tasty dish.

Chicken fried steak - not worthwhile. When you think of chicken fried steak, you imagine going to a dive dinner and having this fried gloriness covered in savory gravy. You already have something in mind, and I didn't get this experience. The steak was tough, chewy and not tender. Gravy was sub-par and bland. This dish tries to upscale, but fails to deliver and the essentials. Missed the target on this one. When your paying more than $15 for chicken fried steak, you'd hope for better.

Bacon - always a pleaser. Crisp, maple syrup, not fatty.

Publican has always had a foodie place in my heart for brunch, but after this experience (chicken fried steak), I don't think it's going to be on top of my list when I visit. Maybe I'm being too harsh? Oh well.

I'd really like to to give this place 4 stars because it's difficult to hear inside but I can't because this is one of the best meals I've ever had and the service was great as well. They make the menu up everyday so this review will probably be obsolete soon.
Not knowing what to get, we trusted in our waiter Chad. He led us towards bbq carrots, hake fish, country rib and cauliflower. I would recommend the country rib and bbq carrots to anyone. The country rib is marinated in a chile lime sauce that words cant do justice to, this was our favorite dish.  The carrots have a bbq rub and then yogurt and dill, I didnt know carrots could taste like that.  The cauliflower has Parmesan cheese and is deep fried. The hake is an ordinary white fish but it was served in a really great sauce.  For desert we got the small cookie jar, which ended up being more than enough.
We sat at a communal table and it was really difficult to hear anyone speak but the food and service were outstanding.

This review is not for the food, which was good, but for the hostess/seating policy set by management. We arrived on time but were missing one person from our party. We were refused seating even though we said we would be ordering cocktails and wine immediately. The restaurant was half empty. We proceeded to witness a pregnant woman being treated in the same way and they refused to seat her until the rest of her party arrived.

Went here with a friend for some catching up, and opted for the tasting menu, as we were feeling adventurous.  Liked that they had reasonable valet service.  We were greeted warmly, and shown to our table on-time for our reservation.  We chose to sit outside--be warned that it is very noisy inside (in a fun way, if that's your thing).

Our server came right away, was knowledgeable and helpful--we appreciated his guidance.
The food was good---not great--some dishes were better than others.   Loved the Rillettes, the Plums with Burratta, Fried Cauliflower and Boudin Noir.  Mackerel and the Sea Perch were good, but not our favorites.  The only complete miss for us were the Corn (tasted like corn mixed with mayo) and the Porchetta.  The Porchetta was a real disappointment--it was expensive, tough, fatty and altogether unappealing,  and too many ingredients fighting for attention.  Be warned and take a pass--there are much better versions out there.

For dessert, we had Melon Dreamsicle and the Chocolate Coconut Cream Pie.  Both were amazing, and each completely different.  After a heavy meal, to me, the Melon was refreshing and unique.  They also have a great selection of after-dinner digestifs, which worked wonders after all that rich food.

We'll be back, but next time will likely stick closer in to our favorite vegetable dishes, the dry-aged hams, salumi and their fantastic breads and spreads.

Real rating: 3.5 stars.

A few friends and I came here to celebrate finishing midterms. After hearing raving reviews from others, I'd have to say I was disappointed with the meal overall.

Chef's selection of 12 oysters for $36 -- There were 6 types, all imported from different places (including Canada!). Although it was cool to try the various types of oysters, none of them really wow-ed me. The house-made saltines are a very nice touch though and a great palate cleanser between the oysters.

Delicata Squash -- I love my sugar, but this was cloyingly sweet. I felt like I was eating maple syrup, so I couldn't even finish my portion. Would not recommend even to my worst enemies.

Duck Hearts -- The pairing with dill cream sauce was very interesting. I enjoyed the texture of the heart over the bread!

Squid ink pasta -- We were disappointed with the portion size and the flavor. There were barely any noodles and didn't taste as good as squid ink I've had at other places. You're better off going to Eataly and buying your own squid ink!

Pork with grits, cheese, and nectarine -- This was the winner that redeemed the meal. The pork was so tender and paired perfectly with the nectarine. Loved every bite of it! If I had to redo the meal I would just order a pound of this for each of us.

I think I'll return for brunch to give The Publican another shot, but overall, the meal was "meh."

I've been meaning to try The Publican for a while now but could never get the timing right. The other night my husband and I decided to walk in on a Saturday and see if we could get in, and they were able to seat us right away around 9pm. The restaurant has a great German beer hall vibe and was cozy and comfortable, even though you're likely seated next to strangers at the longer tables. Our server was extremely helpful in explaining the menu and helping us pick out drinks. I ended up trying 2 red wines, one of which was German, and they were both delicious.

We started with the pickles plate and the chicken liver pate. The pickles were vinegary in a good way, and my husband really enjoyed the pate. It was a huge serving and came with a lot of bread. We also had the half portion of the serrano ham, and I was shocked by how big it was. It came with a generous portion of meat, some bread, and goat butter. It felt like double of what I'd normally get at a restaurant when ordering a full serving. Next we had the BBQ carrots, which were really interesting, and again, a huge portion. You could smell the smoke on them and they had a strong BBQ flavor with some spice. Finally we had the cajun sausage, which came kind of mixed with cornbread, ricotta, and brussel sprouts if I remember correctly. It was a nice marriage of flavors and textures, and the sausage had a great spice.

We honestly didn't finish most of our food because the portions were so large. (Not complaining though!) They neatly packed each of our leftovers into 4 separate boxes so they didn't mix into each other, which I thought was nice. I really enjoyed our meal and our experience here. The menu is definitely different so I find it's a great place to try if you want something adventurous, or aren't sure what you want at all.

Something was off about our trip to Publican. We made reservations for three, two days in advance. We were told dinner would take 2 hours. We were in and out in 45 minutes after ordering a large amount of food. Not major, but a slight inconvenience when you're on vacation and making plans for the evening and are told to budget such a large amount of time.

Our server asked if we had ever been before, all of us said no,  so she gave us the rundown of how the menu works and how to order. We were told that it is sharing style, portions get bigger the further down the menu you go, and we should order two dishes per person. I think this was the major issue that all of us had with our experience. We grossly overordered by using the 2 dishes per person recommendation.

The food was all very good, not amazing like the awards on the wall would have lead us to believe. It also all came out at once, which I think took away from the experience when it's meant to be a sharing menu. It didn't give us the chance to savor each dish individually.

Lastly, the music being played was very out of character for what this restaurant is trying to be. They were playing top 40 Pop and EDM, which I personally like, but felt like it detracted from the ambiance of this restaurant.

Perhaps the 3 stars is a bit harsh. I wish I could do 3.5 as that would be a more fair rating.

Yet another delicious brunch location in Chicago! This is a really cool restaurant located right in the Fulton Market District. There are long tables that you dine at with the other guests, making it easy to socialize with some new people and scope out all the dishes as they come out. The high-backed chairs and tables built into the walls gave it a very Frank Lloyd Wright vibe.

The food was stellar. I ordered the Red Wine Poached Eggs, which is one of two permanent items on their brunch menu. It's a permanent staple here for a reason! The dish is served with prosciutto, which really brings it to the next level! My boyfriend ordered the Pork Shoulder dish, which had a remarkable sauce, a healthy portion of pork shoulder, a fried egg and delicious potatoes. The hash browns are great too -- so crispy, which is just the way I like hash browns.

For drinks, I ordered the Smokin Maria, which is a spicy tequila/Bloody Mary drink. It was spicy and breakfast-y... Just what I look for in Sunday brunch drinks!

Definitely recommend to anyone looking for a great Sunday brunch, just be sure to make reservations in advance, as it fills up quickly

Just ate there today and very much enjoyed my meal!

I had the spoon bread, which was like a savory bread pudding consisting of cornbread, bacon pieces, herbs, a fried egg, and some greens. This dish was super unique, and the flavors blended together perfectly.

My friend ordered the waffle and sang its praises. We both tried the hash browns, which was one large circle of fried shredded potato. I like the concept, but I think it was too greasy and lacked any flavor besides the potato itself...

The place was spacious, with long tables for seating and high back chairs. It had a hip diner vibe with the large circle lights. Because it's a popular place, it was pretty loud, but that's what I expected.

I would go back to try their red wine poached eggs and also try their other eateries--Publican Quality Meats and Publican Quality Bread!

Lotta lotta meat. Aged ham. Amazing. Radish and burrata was yummy if you like those two things- fresh and pretty untransformed. Pork rinds - large portion. Oysters - tiny... Spanish mackral dish - flavorful! Cheuterrie plate.. I didn't care too much for it but my friends liked it.

Our waiter was fantastic. Was great and not phased one friend has a nut allergy and the other had gluten intolerance. Made sure things were separated from main dish so they'd be able to enjoy what they could.  

The experience somehow felt more fun sitting in the pig pen. Haha.

Talking about brunch. I thought the people, the place and the services were fine.

I thought the value equation for the food offering was out off balance. I mean $13 for three average sized pieces of bread with some jam and whipped cream (Freedom Toast) or whatever they called it was ridiculous, especially since there was nothing else accompanying the dish. Everything else was an add on, breakfast sausage, hash browns, fries. By the time you add sides, in my opinion your talking about a price point well out of sync with the quality of the food and experience.

Not for me.

Wonderful Sunday brunch! The weather was perfect, so we sat outside under a shady umbrella. When we checked in, I could tell the main dining room was going to be to loud for me for conversation, so I think nice weather days will be it for me here. I had a very interesting duck confit with Johnnie cake, arugula and blueberries. Delicious. Two of our party had eggs Benedict with procuitto on toast and one had heirloom tomatoes with arugula.  Everyone was very pleased. Our. bill came to $65 which was very reasonable (no alcohol).  Look forward to returning!

The Yorkshire pudding brunch was an experience and hit the spot after a night out. The menu changes regularly you might not find the pudding when you visit... the staples like the scrambled eggs my friend had were perfect luxury. The bacon was thick and medieval toned. Coffee was not the best I've had but I have had the best - no names mentioned to prevent bias. Have to visit The Publican

The Publican is a rambunctious, casual spot with a medieval feel with its long, connected wooden tables. The tables along the back wall are designed like pig pens with a wooden panel to enclose the table. Fun!

The food was alright, but nothing memorable. We ordered the cuttlefish ink pasta with clams, the bouchot mussels, and the avocado salad. But thought everything was too salty and the portions were on the small side.

Plus, it was too loud & dark for me. As much as I loved the sister restaurant Avec, I was not the hugest fan of this spot.

Notes:
- dining al fresco also an option
- be sure to make a reservation (on opentable), seems to get pretty crowded
