review.des:
My first visit to The Publican in 2014 for brunch was amazing. If anyone asked me for recommendations, I definitely told them to stop here for brunch. I love their pancake, bacon, chicken dish. The bloodsausage was a comfort dish for me as well.

My second visit in 2015 for dinner is quite the opposite. I dined with a friend and we opted for the chef's menu. Our server asked us if we had any dishes we wanted to try and we chose for them to decide. This was definitely a mistake on our part. I believe it was 6-7 dishes with a dessert. Overall, I couldn't figure out the theme of the dishes they brought out. Some seemed mediterranean inspired while others were not. Also, we didn't bring our appetite so we felt very wasteful! We were visiting, so didn't have a place to store and reheat the food!

I definitely want to give it another chance, this time choosing the items instead!

Honestly some of the best food I've ever tried. I like this menu because it brings together so many different flavors. We ordered the fried brussel sprouts, avocado salad, and the chicken and fry platter. Be warned, the full size chicken platter is extremely large! The lighting is also very cool here!

Have been here for dinner and brunch, and both were delicious.  The food is very unique (we had some incredible offal), and the cocktails are great.  It could be a little bit cheaper, but overall everything is quite good.

My girlfriend loves this place, and she takes me here whenever she can.  Will definitely keep coming back.

3.5 stars. We wound up here, without reservation, and were immediately seated at 7:30 on a Tuesday. I found our experience here to be very hit or miss. The honeycrisp apple salad was phenomenal. I think if we'd just ordered that, it would have been a five star review. Also fantastic was the white cheddar pimento cheese spread. The grilled sour cream pound cake was also quite good, although I found the creme fraiche ice cream didn't add anything and sort of took away from the rest of the dish. The fried quail was maybe two bites of meat, although the Texas-toast style bread and bed of corn were quite good (I probably would have been much more a fan of that dish if it had been called elotes and Texas toast!).

On the more disappointing side, the spicy pork rinds were a let down. They were not particularly spicy and the spices did not seem to reach the rinds further down in the cup at all. They also tasted a bit stale, so they wound up mostly being crunchy flavorless calories. Also disappointing were the other bread sides - the butter tasted like when you'd get at the grocery store, and the date and mint spread mostly just tasted like tomato sauce.

I rounded up a star because our server was great. (I've forgotten her name, a woman with short blond hair.) When a friend of mine expressed that she really wanted to try the summer sausage but wasn't hungry enough for the full fried chicken dinner that it came with, our waitress immediately offered to just bring us a side of sausage. It was springy and quite good, and I very much appreciated the gesture.

I doubt I'll be back, but the price was moderately reasonable for the number of dishes we got to try (this worked out to about $30 a person including tax and tip) and no wait was great.

I had this on my list to try and now I can say been there done that. We were STARVING and wanted to indulge in a sit down restaurant versus the taste of Randolph food fare. We wanted outdoor seating, but after finding out that would take 30 minutes (I totally get it...beautiful day out) we opted to eat inside. Most of the seating was communal which I'm not a fan of.

My friend and I got the French toast and her boyfriend opted for the waffles. LOL...it's not a good sign when my friend took the first bite and said she didn't know if it was done or not. The French toast was a little too mushy for me. Not sure if it had to do with the big block of butter melting into it they had on top. Her boyfriend had the waffles and thought they were just okay. The eggs I ordered on the side were a little bland, so I had to spice them up with some salt and pepper.

The saving grace is knowing I'm a come back because the desserts looked amazing and that's what I care about most. LOL...Will check them out for lunch/dinner in the future.

Pretty amazing meal at The Publican. We went with a group of 14 people, and they automatically select for you with that size group the chef's choice menu.

It is a serious amount of fun to have the food come out and not know quite what you were going to get next. A full range from different seafood to pork to chicken to everything in between. Actual cookie jars come for dessert for you to select from myriad choices. You can also purchase a Sixer for the kitchen, which we did. We just liked hearing the big cow bell ring to let them know somebody had done that for them.

Great house cocktails, and wine list for those who dig that. All around fun (and tasty) experience.

Went for brunch on a Saturday afternoon. Had reservation for 6 and was seated right away.

Small brunch menu but solid offerings. Scrambled egg with avocado toast was very good. These were honestly probably the  way eggs I've ever had in my life.. very meaty, buttery. Cooked perfectly.

Meat was good. Swine is king -- don't come here expecting any chicken sausage alternatives. Great brunch cocktails.

Plan to be back soon to try their dinner menu.

This was a very highly anticipated brunch visit that I planned well in advance. I had visited Chicago many times, but never got the chance to eat at the Publican. I'll just leave this review with the thousands of others.

You'll notice that while there are tables strewn about the place, it's mostly communal table seating. If you want to request a private table, make sure to do so ahead of time. The decor overall is very homey, and I liked the feel of the large wooden tables and chairs. The waiter was very friendly and attentive, and refills of drinks came pretty regularly.

I ordered the shwarma sausage , which came with mint, sunny-side egg, labneh, pita sections, and muhammara, It was a very nice dish, and the mint and labneh really brought it together. It was pretty much like a deconstructed shwarma sandwich, but it worked well in the bowl. That being said, the side of Publican maple bacon is unreal. It's fatty but not too greasy and just the right amount of chew, so that you don't feel like you're just eating pure fat. The maple syrup on top is very subtle and not too sweet, which perfectly complements the salty richness of the bacon.

Great comfort food, friendly service, and reasonable prices. Can't complain here. I definitely need to come back for the dinner menu on one of my visits back to Chicago.

pics.caption: shawarma sausage with a side of Publican bacon

review.des: We had the bread which was outstanding.  Started off with oysters which were outstanding.  Moved on to the Yellow Tail outstanding. Cauliflower was outstanding.Fried Clams just okay (not enough clams).   Drinks were just okay.  Service was very good. Community seating and the noise keep this place from getting five stars.

Reach out and touch someone. Well you don't have to reach out far. If they sit you at a communal table, you'll be almost shoulder to shoulder to some strangers. It's not so bad. But I'm letting you know in case you'll be uncomfortable with that.

Also, if you come with another person, they're going to sit you face each other, not next to. They seem to have a system to pack as much people in as possible.

They also have standing tables. I'm not sure how you get them. But if you prefer to stand instead of sit, maybe you can ask for those?

I came in for brunch and the place was popular. There were seats open, but I would call and reserve your spot just in case.

I tried a few things here for brunch. Their Bloody Mary was good. It comes with pickles, onions, and other things. It's nice and spicy. It was one of my favorite Bloody Marys.

Their Publican Mimosa was interesting too. I never thought combining Wheat Beer with Orange Juice would be tasty. But it was.

For the entrees, I tried their Thai Fried Chicken. It comes with a Sunny Side up egg and thai sweet chili sauce. The skin was nice and crispy. The meat was juicy. And the sweet chili sauce gave it a nice, subtle kick. I loved it with the egg. It was a great meal for brunch.

This week's platonic date squad locale was The Publican. We had a great experience! We had 9 o'clock reservations on a Saturday night and ended up waiting an extra 10 or so minutes because the table was finishing up dessert. The patrons I watched coming in were a bit older and wore fur (fur hats, shawls, coats)... Did I not get the memo? We were seated in a booth that was enclosed by short barn doors. I was delighted by the doors because the Publican is definitely a crowded place and it prevented anyone from bumping into to me. We had planned in advance to get the Chef's selection ($65) because going here was a one time deal and might as well maximize it.

That night's chef selection came with

Spicy pork rinds $6: 5/5 stars. They are so freaking good and addicting. The pork rinds were light, crunchy and had some sort of powder on them (methinks cocaine) which made the already delicious snack even better.

Beets (quark, flax seed, walnut & tahini dressing) $13: 5/5 stars. easily my favorite dish of the night. The beets were incredibly fresh and the dressing on them elevated them to amazing omg I need more beets in my life status.

Oysters $12?: 6/5 stars Hands down the best oysters I've ever had. The mignonette was delightful and served to enhance the flavor.

Fried sweet potatoes (spiced honey, hazelnut & labneh) $12: 5/5 stars. Slather honey on any fried honey and baby I'm in heaven. They weren't greasy and it tasted like curry potatoes but OMG were they good.

Sirloin (muhammara, date, sumac & feta) $21: 4.5/5 stars. My piece was an end piece which made it a little chewy but the second piece was tender and delicious. The pomegranates were a nice touch.

Roasted squash (fromage blanc,cherry, marcona almond & crispy sunchoke) $12: 3.5/5 stars. This wasn't very memorable nor was it my favorite. Felt like a filler dish and I wouldn't go out of my way to order it again.

Striped bass (buttermilk, leek & shabazi spice) $28: 4.5/5 It was so good! I love pungent fish and boy was this right up my alley. The leeks were delicious as was the sauce. It's not for anyone who likes it mellow and light and flaky.

Duck hearts (pepper jelly, boursin cheese, persimmon & multigrain toast) $14: 4.75/5 stars. The toast was really hard to slice through but it had a nice toast when biting into it. Duck hearts are so good, where have you been all of my life.

Porchetta (fig, treviso, pecorino & hazelnut picada) $33: 4/5 stars. The pork was fatty and tender a top a really yummy au jus. I would definitely order this again but was it in no way shape or form adequate as a single entree. *note the entrees should have ended here by the server noticed my sad, hungry face.

Bouchot mussels (publican lambic, bay,celery, butter & garlic) $16: 3.75/5 stars. This was an additional dish provided since my squad and I were still hungry. The mussels were tender and not chewy. The broth was really nice and light; it was the perfect vehicle for the delicious bread provided on the side.

Pumpkin cake (brown butter ice cream pomegranate & pear) $12: 5/5 stars. My favorite desert of the night. The ice cream was to die for. The pumpkin cake was light and fluffy and the sauce they smeared on the plate increased the pumpkin flavor. Definitely order this if you want a new spin on the oh so basic pumpkin flavor.

Ice cream bombe (chocolate, peanut butter, pretzel & caramel) $12: 4.25/5 stars. It would be 5 stars if the peanut butter ice cream wasn't so salty. The peanut butter ice cream was covered in a hard chocolate shell with a caramel drizzle on the plate and chocolate covered pretzels sprinkled on top. The caramel was perfect and my favorite component of the dish.

Service: 5/5 stars. The wait staff changed out our plates after every other dish and my water was never more than 3/4 empty. The server herself was having a rough night because the look of exhaustion was evident on her face but nonetheless she was great and accommodating.

The dishes were great but really small (i.e. tapas size). Every tasting was promptly followed by a "omg this is so good. " I don't think you can go wrong ordering anything here but I would check with the server to see if the portion is adequate as a entree instead of a petite appetizer size. If you're hungry, go for the chicken and sausage with frites. I spied other tables ordering it and seemed like the only substantial sized dish. Overall I don't consider the chef's selection the best value and I would probably order a la carte in the future ($65 a person but the value came out to $47 pp). The meal was supposed to end at the porchetta but server picked up on our sad hungry faces and decided to throw in the mussels. Everything was great and I will definitely come back but probably not for the chef's selection.

review.des:
Y'ALL. I just cannot. If you ever even start to consider if you should go here, DO IT IMMEDIATELY. The seating is communal, which is such a fun concept. I loved it, and struck up a conversation with Daniel sitting next to me and got his opinion on the amazing ham section. It is loud, though, so if you don't like other people and if you hate talking loudly, you probably won't be comfortable here.

Our table of 3 ordered a wide assortment of food: pork rinds, bread plate with pimiento cheese, fried sweet potatoes, suckling pig, and half a chicken. Oh! And the barbecued carrots. SO MUCH FOOD. The pork rinds are an absolute must. And the chicken is THE BEST CHICKEN I have ordered in a restaurant. Hands down. EVER. We ended the night with the sour cream pound cake.

Please go. The experience and the food will definitely not disappoint!!

Has it been nearly five years since I first stepped foot in The Publican? Apparently it has, and it's due time for a review update. My first trip there, as an out-of-towner for a pre-dinner drink, was really eye-opening. Since then, I've often found myself comparing other restaurants to this place--trendy casual, robust beer menu, small plates of goodness, open kitchen, and convivial dining.

The Publican has become a go-to restaurant to bring visitors. It's big, loud, tasty, takes reservations, serves damn good food, and open for an excellent brunch in addition to an excellent dinner, not to mention the pre- or post-meal watering hole. The pig art is surreal. So are the single washrooms, as is sitting in the troughs.

Although I don't have a favorite dish here--unless you could the side of maple-glazed bacon as a dish--anything and everything you order will be tasty. I definitely recommend something something pork (pig art, if you recall). A ham plate or charcuterie for dinner? Yes. Biscuit and gravy with ample chorizo? Also yes. Aforementioned bacon? Ahem, I mean Burton's maple syrup-braised publican bacon? Oh heck yea. Enjoy.

review.des:
Loved dining here. The food was amazing. The service was lovely. We made a reservation for a Saturday night which was needed, the place was packed. We were seated in one of the prestigious sought after booths with doors that lock you in like a pig in a pen. My claustrophobia immediately set in and I needed to get the heck out of that booth. The staff was really kind and helpful and sat us at a glorious open air table where I could actually enjoy the meal. Our server, who was amazing by the way, told us that in the three years he'd been there we were only the second table who hated the booths, most people request them. Freaks.

The food itself was amazing, we weren't super hungry to shared cauliflower, avocado salad and porchetta, all of which were out of control in the flavor department. It was my friends birthday and they brought over a super tasty caramel dessert for her. Very nice.

Overall a great expereience I highly recomend.

Saturday brunch.  We had 10 am reservations.  Beautiful restaurant, sat at the kitchen counter, our preferred seating.  All downhill from there.  We felt rushed.  Our server lacked any personality at all.  Will was his name.  He didn't offer any information, didn't act friendly... We felt rushed from the moment we sat down.  Honestly,, can't even remember the food, it all happened too fast.  The big open room felt like a holding pen for cattle... herd 'em in'...hurry them out.  Won't be back for sure.

Came here with a group for brunch and will definitely be going back!  I got the Smokin Maria which is a spicy bloody mary with tequila- highly recommended.  I also got the avocado toast which was so fresh, blissful cherry tomatoes on it- full of flavor.  The chicken liver mousse is REALLY good however they need more acidic/sweet add ons to cut the fattiness of it.  I'd like to go back and try more things!  Great casual ambience and you sit at long tables which is different and trendy.
Great brunch place to go. Too bad I didn't order too much but friends food were just as good. Definitely will visit again.

Fantastic bunch. Trappist setting. Bloody Mary came with a beer back. I highly recommend this place. It it was a loud place though so be prepared to speak up. Staff was helpful and kind, food came in a good amount of time and honestly the good was legit. I had red wine poached eggs with prosciutto. Honestly : best brunch ever. No hyperbole!!!

So this place is the bomb! I came here on a Thursday night with a friend after hearing great things, and was definitely not disappointed.

For dinner we ordered:
Barbecue carrots- The name is a bit misleading, you would think these things are smothered in BBQ sauce, right?! Wrong. They were just grilled carrots with a herb dressing and pecans- pretty good.

Fried cauliflower. Don't let cauliflower scare you! This cauliflower was crispy, perfectly cooked, just delicious! Highly recommend.

Farm Chicken- This was my favorite dish of the night! The crispness of the chicken skin and the juice of the meat, my mouth is still salivating as I'm writing this! We got the half chicken that comes with a bed of fries, not kidding, BED of fries! The chicken is laid on top of the fries and the jus from the chicken, just adds more flavor to the fries, what else could you ask from life?

Dry-aged sirloin- This was my least favorite dish. Waiter told us it was served medium, but was more rare than expected. It felt like chewing gum, chewing and chewing this thing for five minutes! Good thing though, it wasn't gamy and flavor was nice.  

As for everything else:
Drink- I had the lambic doux, which was very pleasant. Tart beer with a hint of sweetness from the berries. I would give it a try.

Ambiance- Publican is a community-style restaurant, which was a first for me. We shared a large table with another party. It made for a more lively environment. Only complaint is that we didn't have as much space for all our dishes, a little cramped. I loved the simple, wooden tables and spherical lights.

Service- Our waiter was friendly and knowledgeable. Cherry on top of the experience.

I will definitely come back to try out the other dishes!

This place was had awesome food! Everything was portion appropriate and the staff was knowledgeable and offered great suggestions. The space itself is an instagrammers dream! The place does get busy so make reservations in advance. Come hungry!

pics.caption: This is Plums. It was burrata,puntarelle,Urfa pepper & pinenut aillade. It was delicious!!!

review.des: We had the absolute best birthday dinner here. The food was top notch and so unpretentious--especially for the area. Our server was so chill and laid back, she really made it such a great experience. We sat at a communal table which was super fun. There are cubbies under your seat for your coat so it doesn't get too cramped. We got ham, mussels, fried sweet potatoes, and pork belly. The mussels were so fresh and as Bostonians, we are definitely seafood snobs. The fried sweet potatoes I can't even explain--I've been thinking about them ever since. And the pork belly was by far the best we've ever had. Can't wait to go back!

Warning: This is THE BEST restaurant I think I have been to all year.

The service and staff is amazing and super helpful, strongly recommend making a reservation. This place is certainly worth it.  The restaurant does a great job at preparing dishes to serve 2 people. Perfect.

We started out with the tuna sampler (we tried all 3: light, medium, and fatty). The best we have ever had, phenomenal and completely worth it. Incredible, and we are from Boston where seafood is at the finest. We also each tried 4 different selections of oysters which had our eyes rolling to the back of our heads, again we are from Boston.

The apple salad was KILLER, KILLER!!!! Everything complemented each other so nicely; sweet, crunchy, soft, and crisp. The apples, burrata, mustard seed, shaved Brussels sprouts, and Parmesan are the best thing ever. EVER!

We got the fried sweet potatoes which are out of this world and nothing you haven't tried in your life so you best be ordering.

The pork chop was spectacular, I don't think I have said so many positive things about a meal. So much diversity that fits perfectly and creates the best flavors.

Last but not least you will force yourself to make room for the waffle with ice cream, and if not you will walk away with regret because it is the icing on the cake. We got a waffle with rocky road ice cream and a waffle with toffee/pretzel ice cream because we didn't think we could share, and god damnit we were right. This dessert was my ideal dessert, size, flavor, abs sweetness.  There was nothing that wasn't perfect about this waffle.

We also got the French press decaf coffee which has our eyes popping in disbelief on how smooth it was. Make sure to let it sit for 4 minutes.

All in all this place is worth the wait, as an amid traveler this restaurant goes around surpassing expectations. #publicansquadonfleek

Came here for brunch on a Saturday. Service was prompt and we were able to snag a private table probably because we came early (11AM). We tried the pork rinds and found that we like the original version better, i.e., without the cheese powder and spices. The Dutch baby was outstanding but not sure what to do about this pothole of cream which was just on one side of the pancake. The soft shell crabs were crispy and done just right. One of us thought that the Harissa pate was too spicy so ate the sourdough bread without it.

The hype is real, I've tasted it myself, definitely come here if you have a chance!  I am pretty sure we got lucky, but called 15 minutes before and had no issue getting a reservation for 3 at 10 AM!  We had the option of sitting inside or outside for brunch and opted for outside as it was such a gorgeous day!

We started off with a buttermilk-glazed donut which I didn't appreciate as I am used to more fluffy airy donuts...This one has more of a coffee cake consistency and every bite tasted like a desert in my mouth, I was parched.  Oh, but they also give you the donut hole so yay?  Luckily things quickly improved with our main entrees.

Chicken-fried skate sandwich with bibb lettuce, bread and butter pickles, bacon remoulade and green salad.  The skate was fried to perfection providing a nice crispy bite as you sink your teeth into perfectly cooked and tender skate!  The bun was also perfectly grilled as each bite was buttery and crisp, can you tell I like crunchy things?  Anyways, the seasoning of everything was on point and everything was absolutely delicious from the pickles to remoulade sauce and the green salad!

Peekytoe crab scramble with dill, creme fraiche, pickled shallot and toast...OMG these EGGS were freaking amazing!  Never in my life have I tasted eggs soo freaking delicious, creamy, smooth, and fluffy, you have to try this!  The crab flavor wasn't very strong, more like essence of crab, and I would skip the toast as it was quite charred, but OMG those eggs!  Also, hash browns are a must, these had the perfect crispiness and texture I loved it especially with the ramps! Oh and can't forget Publican bacon, dude these aren't your measly strips of bacon that you find at the grocery store, but instead think chunks of pork belly covered with just the right amount of Burton's maple syrup to balance out the savoriness!

Pork Loin Fettunta-think open faced sandwich/ fancy bruschetta but instead of traditional tomato and basil this one was topped with succulent pork loin, ramps, Parmesan, spinach and fried egg.

Overall, freaking delicious eggs and cute atmosphere; skip the donut but the hash browns and bacon are a must! Oh, and maybe see if you can get less charred bread!  Lastly, I hope y'all are more fortunate to try the pork rinds, sadly the day we went the dehydrator was broken =( but I guess there is always next time!

pics.caption: Hash brown with ramps, which are wild spring onions?
Bacon bacon bacon!!! I need more bacon!

review.des:
Here's the thing.
Sometimes I love eating alone. Scratch that...usually I love eating alone.
And this was no exception but it seemed a bit weird.

Was here on a "mystery vacation" that brought me to Chicago.  Single, solo and for 3 days I explored.  The Publican was a must.

Went inside and said I was alone and the hosts were very nice but I felt a bit uncomfortable.  I was seated at the raw bar with a full view of the kitchen ..which is AWESOME and my happy place...but my back was turned to whole restaurant.  I felt like I was in time-out.  That's the best way to put it.  I was alone... there were no other patrons..it was just...me. #awkward.

I get that the vibe of this place was very communal but come on!
My handsome server, Kelly was very attentive and helpful and all around I had absolutely no complaints...none at all.

The food.  It was good....Maybe not completely my style...but good and appreciated for it's creativity.
The salad with pig's ear:  Pig's ear were off the chart.  Like, give me that with some dipping sauce and a stiff drink and Mama is HAAAAPPAAYYYY.
The dressing seemed a bit too creamy/citrusy for me. There was a flavor (orange rind?) In there that I didn't like.
Had the steak with cucumbers and polenta.  It was..good.  The steak was cooked to perfect temp and very well seasoned.  The polenta was luke warm at best and although yummy... all around was just lacking something.  I don't know..
Hell, I'm not a chef.  I don't know the chefs intention and like I said..it was...good.
I just didn't leave saying..Oh F*CK YEAH!! Which is what I wanted.

I am currently researching how to make my own crispy pig's ear.. so if anything, Thanks Publican for the take-away. xxoo

The Publican is a great Gastropub and continues to me a favorite spot of mine.  

Service is always good.  

Ambiance is fun, but can get a bit loud when crowded.  If you have a part of 4 you can sit in a pig pen style table.  There are some community style tables so you may be sitting close to some others so be aware of this.  

The food is fantastic.  Seafood, pork, and great veggies are their specialities.  The Squash is the best squash I have ever eaten in my life and the saved brussel sprout salad also very good veggie.  Get the fries with eggs on them. Potted rillettes delicious.  

They also have a nice beer selection, including many locals.  

If you can, do the tasting menu. Fantastic and a good way to try a lot of different things.  You will not go hungry.  

Come here and come often.  Caveat I went once for Sunday brunch.  That I would skip but come for lunch or dinner.

Outstanding meal and great service at one of the communal tables. The bread with three spreads was terrific, especially the pimento cheese. But the real highlights were the sttawberries with burrata and the hake with curried lentils.  One cautionary note--this is a very noisy restaurant!

Great addition chef Jacob. Met him 5 years ago at g e bistro.  My son then 17 was considering cooking as a carrier.  He asked for a tour of the kitchen.  Chef Jacob took ac1/2 to spend with a kid from Idaho.    My son. Still cooking in Portland.   Thank you chef Jacob.

The menu is hard to navigate, the service wasn't helpful. I ended up with 3 different versions of ham charcuterie boards worded differently. She recommended 2-3 orders per person for sharing...I cancelled my last option because I couldn't take any more meat. The food I got was good but I wouldn't come again for dinner.

We had Sunday brunch this morning at this highly touted restaurant. It was really good but not great.

Our server Elaine (sp?) was great. One of our dishes was later than the rest of our party and she brought us a sticky bun. Nice touch!

Food- We started with the pork rinds. Yelpers highly touted this treat. Hmmm, not sure I get this. Very crunchy but not real flavorful.

My wife had the red wine poached eggs. She loved it. Light and fresh was her comments. I had scrambled eggs on top of hash browns with breakfast sausage. The eggs were perfect and the hash browns were crunchy. I would do both again. The sausage had an odd flavor. I would pass on this. I also tried the thick bacon. I liked it, but my dining companions thought it could have been more carmelized so more fat was rendered.

Ambiance is very loud. Try to get the hostesses to seat you at one of the booths. If you sit at one of the communal tables, you will probably lose your voice hollering across the table to hear each other.

Lastly, get the spicy Bloody Mary with the pilsner 'beer back'. The drink came with a bounty of pickled veges on the top...great way to start any day.

I would go back to the Publican to try lunch or dinner. Brunch was good but not great.

Amazing food! They have small plates, which was great for trying a bunch of stuff. Here's what we tried:
Charcuterie plate- Harissa pate was the highlight of the plate for me. The sausage that came with it was stellar as well. The head cheese was really tasty too.
Barbecued carrots- so good. A nice smokey flavor was really complimented by the dill and pecans. A great herb dressing too.
Fava beans- did not expect falafel to be as good as it was. Honestly could rival any of the middle eastern restaurants we've visited. Nicely crisp but also had a nice spice combination.
Sand dabs- my new favorite fish. They came in an amazing butter sauce and didn't have the typical fishy flavor you might expect. Really delicate.
Green chile sausage- came with the best sauce I've ever had. It had a nice tang from the tangerine and went really well with the slightly spicy sausage.
Suckling pig- amazing. A few different cuts of pork in the same dish on top of some greens and crisps. Succulent and juicy and tender pork that really impressed.
Butterscotch pudding- I cannot emphasize how incredible this was. Amazingly creamy, but not too rich or sweet. The homemade whipped creme was so light and made for the ideal topping.
Tangerine Vanilla sorbet- like a dreamsicle. Really creamy for a sorbet!
Our waiter was amazing wish I could remember his name but he was always there when we needed something. We had a pickier eater with us as well, and he was more than happy to make accommodations.
Really nice atmosphere. Would love to try their brunch service sometime!

pics.caption: The charcuterie plate! Harissa pate was the favorite.
Birthday treat- the butterscotch pudding with heavenly whipped cream and caramel sauce!
The fava bean dish with falafel that would rival any middle eastern restaurant.

review.des:
Came here randomly late last Friday night while in town from KC. What a great experience.

Lets start with the staff - Every person we interacted with was absolutely amazing. Most notably our waitress (wish I could remember your name because you deserve a personalized shout out) and what I would assume was the bar manager or head bartender. After I ordered a pint of the Publican Lambic he came over to ask what I thought of it (it was great) and then told me about their Lambic doux, which they make in house by blending fruit and other ingredients into the house lambic. The blend was strawberry & basil that night and it too was fantastic. Great recommendation.

We ordered 6 oysters (chefs selection) for a warm up and the chefs tasting menu for our main event. I'm not going to go into every detail about every dish here but just know that everything was amazing. I'd highly recommend going this route when you visit.

Thanks for a great dinner. We will be back soon.

Sunday brunch with good friends and my cousins - this was their recommendation and it was a good one.  I had the French toast with breakfast sausage - French toast was covered with sliced Nectarines and whipped cream, real maple syrup, and the sausage, oh my goodness was that amazing!  I definitely want to go back to sample more of their salted, smokey pork offerings!  

The Smokin' Maria, a chipotle infused Bloody Mary, had way to heavy a hand with the chipotle.  I couldn't finish it even with the Pilsner back. SPICY!  The server offered to replace it, which is commendable, but I though I could soldier on.  Nope.

The staff is friendly with many smiles, and the service efficient.  I like the whole communal table thing, it opens the door to meet new people and makes the place feel more like home.  

It has been a long time since I lived in Chicago, and it's amazing how things have changed.  And obviously, sad that some things haven't, but being an optimist I enjoyed this foray into an area that back in the late 80's early 90's was not where you wanted to be.  The Publican is an example of how the inner urban environment can be turned around for the better.

Somehow managed to walk in on a Friday night with 4 people and were sat immediately at a table outside. It was a prefect night so it worked out great!
The food was delicious. For such a meat-centric place it was actually the avocado salad that really stood out for us. We also ordered the Cajun sausage and roasted chicken both of which were very good.

Did the tasting menu at dinner with 2 friends and we all left incredibly satisfied and in awe of the meal we'd had. I'm not a huge meat-eater but I would be if I could eat Publican on the reg. Loved that it was coursed, the server was very well-versed on each dish and we were not rushed.

Probably serves the best meat dishes, especially chicken holy moly. Hands down one of the best places I've ever eaten in Chicago.
It's easy to make reservation here and the waitress are really helpful. I love the concept of communal dining tables and how everyone just shares their food.
Uniquely decorated. Reminded me of LACMA.

Definitely get their oysters! They have a great selection from both coasts (shoutout to sea cow)

This is the order of four hungry Asian girls:

Apple Salad (4.5/5):
Hmm those ham and shreds of moist mozzarella in this salad just upped the game. I love how there's a wide range of texture in this salad: from the crispness of the apples to the softness of the cheese and ham.

chicken liver pâté (5/5):
--Slagel Family Farm, Fairbury, Illinois | strawberry jam & ciabatta--$12
The best chicken liver pâté I've ever had. The idea of putting strawberry jam on top of it was absolutely brilliant. In addition to the smooth chicken liver you also get the pop of strawberry seeds and a sweet scent. The bread was also delicious, soft on the inside and the crust was not hard to bite into (unlike many other places that have breads impossible to chew)

pork belly (4.5/5):
Wow! I was not expecting pork belly to be a little crispy on the outside. This is a sweet take on pork belly but I loved it because it was not overwhelming greasy.

country ribs (5/5):
--Slagel Family Farm, Fairbury, Illinois | bosc pear, dandelion green, hazelnut & spring onion vinaigrette--$28
Also the best ribs I've ever had. Juicy. Medium rare. Flavorful. There were lots of veggies on top of this dish. But whatever the meat itself was really good.

farm chicken (the chicken, 5/5; the sausage it came with, 1/5):
--Slagel Family Farm, Fairbury, Illinois | half chicken with summer sausage & frites--$27
BEST CHICKEN EVER. I've never eaten a chicken that has such strong flavor (i'm not talking about overly salty), but also you can taste the herbs within the chicken. It was also amazing how juicy this chicken is. It almost didn't taste like chicken anymore because the meat was so densely packed together.
However, the sausage that it came with was horrible. The skin was impossible to cut through and it was really salty without anything add on to it.
The fries was good though. Mushy inside but crispy out. Wish they had ketchup or something else that came with it.

porchetta (4/5):
--Slagel Family Farm, Fairbury, Illinois | rosemary, farro, baby turnip & fava bean--$33
Porchetta came at last but was also a little disappointing. The porchetta was a little on the dry side. It was juicy and savoring but nonetheless lacks the dimensions of flavors like the others had.

waffle (5/5):
--honey butter & berry preserves--$10
Their waffle is perfect to my standards. It's light. It's thin. It's crispy. Smothered with soft honey butter and some jam, it's heavenly in one bite. Please please please order this.

apple crisp (3.5/5):
--cinnamon toast ice cream {family-style}--$16
Hm this is quite a disappointing dessert. I could not handle the amount of granola found on top of it. Also beware of the cinnamon toast ice cream. They *do* mean cinnamon toast as you'll find pieces of actually toasts with cinnamon inside of the scoop. The apple chunks were homey and cinnamon-y.

Came for Saturday brunch after doing PanIQ room escape game.  I liked the communal tables and the settings for Publican.  However, it was just way too loud in here, very hard to carry a conversation without having to shout across the table.

The food is decent, nothing too special in particular and I'd say over priced.  Don't need to come back again.

Love the atmosphere with large communal tables, mood lighting and lively energy. Very busy in a Saturday night and service a little slow but they're making it fresh to order. Ordered suckling pig, oysters, and an old fashion (my go to drink).

pics.caption: Summer cobbler with cinnamon ice cream

review.des: Stopped by for Sunday brunch and The Publican did not disappoint me. Good food and cocktails in a great atmosphere. Loved the communal table!

I've heard from so many others that this is an amazing place for brunch, so I had to check it out.
Sure enough on a Sunday this place is packed.
Not a huge fan of the communal tables, as they tend to get loud and cramped.  It makes it a bit awkward to order when you sit there and shout across the table to ask questions about the menu.
Yes there are a couple of veggie options, not a whole lot though.
The mushroom toast however was pretty darn amazing.....the coffee cake...on the other hand i found to be a bit on the dry side.
Service was pretty good
the place itself is quite loud...and energetic.
Valet parking is $12 on Sunday.  There is street parking near by if you get luck.

Finally got a chance to try the Publican for brunch this past Saturday. I had a reservation for 4 people at 11 am and we were seated immediately upon arrival. The restaurant is one giant room with lots of communal tables and even some standing tables for drinks. We started with a round of orange juices and coffees. OJ was only $3 which was great; I don't know when it became acceptable to charge 5+ dollars for OJ like so many other places do.

Anyway, collectively we ordered the brisket, the panchetta sandwich and the waffle. The waffle looked really light and fluffy and was probably the cheapest entree on the menu. The panchetta sandwich (my order) was great. I suggest putting the egg inside the sandwich and then just eating it with a fork and knife. Every bite had a great mix of egg, grilled bread and panchetta along with whatever sauce was on it. The dish even came with a nice little arugula (I think) side salad. Both my friends who got the brisket said it was also really good.

Price point is a little high for brunch, but given the location, and the exceptional quality of the food, I left the Publican feeling very satisfied!

I was so excited to try this place because of all of the amazing reviews. We ordered the gem salad, pork belly, and sirloin steak. Honestly I was not that impressed. My fiancé and I looked at each other and just said "eh". Maybe we didn't order right and or there could be better things on the menu. Would go back, however not in an hurry to....

I was excited to see the Publican at O'Hare because I expected it to be up to the same standards as the one in Chicago, but sadly, it was not. We ordered a pub burger, rare, with fries, the Doug sohn sausage sandwich with chips, a beer and the Kyle's After Pork cocktail. We got a well done burger with fries, a sausage sando with fries instead of chips and the saddest cocktail I've ever seen. It showed up with two ounces of lone booze at the bottom of a filthy glass with two sad straws poking up. The flavor was ok, good enough but not awesome.  Unfortunately all the food was tepid except one order of fries which were outright cold. Our server didn't offer to bring us the chips we actually ordered, she just said she wouldn't charge us for the fries.

Overall, super disappointment. Poor service, long wait times for food and our server's attention, especially at an airport where people are in a hurry. Food was cold but would have been good if cooked correctly.

pics.caption: Sadness. This is two sips after arrival, so this is the presentation they're going for here at Publican.

review.des:
A very solid option for brunch, especially for larger groups. I came by for Sunday brunch (their Saturday and Sunday brunch service offer different things) and enjoyed the food.

Mushroom toast: Nice earthy tones of the mushroom with a generous slab of toast, all of which were topped with two runny eggs. Definitely my favorite of the meal.

Olive oil cake: Light, fruity flavors with just a hint of sweetness from the what I believe was whipped ricotta.

Duck confit: Probably the weakest of the three. Overall, it wasn't bad-- I loved the addition of a sixty minute egg. However, I felt like the ratio between the pinto beans and duck was a bit off--the sauciness of the beans overwhelmed the duck.

My only qualm with my experience was the seating--the large, communal tables made for cramped seating, and sitting so closely to others made it difficult to hear conversation.

Vegetarian Options: Close to none unfortunately unless you are ok with eating sides for brunch. I got the red wine poached eggs without the chorizo and I was thoroughly impressed with this option.

Service/Environment: Really cool environment with tables set up like Hogwarts with all individuals at a large dining table setting. Also, individual booths are organized to look like a stable.

Overall: Cool place to check out in Fulton market with minimal veggie options.

I would have given The Publican a four star but I can't hear after dinner!!! This place is SO LOUD and it really does take away from the dining experience!
The food was very, very good locally sourced, a plus, and presented well. Gio our server was wonderful, very personable and took care of us well. It was as if we were at his kitchen & he was serving us but once again we could not hear what he was saying!!!!
We will return to try a new dish (maybe!) or just enjoy our favorites. Might also bring ear plugs or learn sign language before we return!

The service was fantastic, the waiter was attentive, not overbearing, friendly and we were well taken care of. The 3 stars went to the food. To be fair, I think we ordered the wrong dishes. It was our first time there and weren't sure what to order.

We started out with the oysters... they were amazing! Can't go wrong with those. Our second dish was the taste of the hams. The serving was extremely generous for the two of us so we ended up canceling one of the our other meat dishes. I personally couldn't tell the difference between the hams, just one was saltier than others. Our second dish was the yellowtail. It was ok but the seared texture of the yellowtail threw me off a bit (I'm use raw hamachi). Our next dish was the beets over fresh burrata. That was great! The last dish we got was the squid... again, it was ok. But I felt that the potatoes and chorizo overpowered the flavor of the squid.

Again, I think we ordered the underwhelming dishes. If we had more time for dinner, I definitely would have tried chef's choice.

Quality meat. Came for brunch and ordered the porchetta sandwich which was great. The pimento cheese on it was a good addition but might have had a little too much mustard for my taste. Also had the side of bacon which is less like bacon and more of a side of pig with maple syrup. I'll take it though. That bacon side was amazing. Drinks didn't blow me out of the water. Average Bloody Mary and the beermosa was good but I'd prefer the champs.

I ate here last night and the went with the chefs tasting menu and was pleasantly surprised. The sequence of flavors delivered each course was flawlessly in sync. Not to mention the beautiful decor and ambience of the entire restaurant was on point. This is the first restaurant I ate at so far for my visit here in Chicago and the bar has been set high.
The meats are all on point but the highlight of the my evening was the vegetable courses. You have to try the avocado dish its a perfect flavor profile similar to falafel without all the oiliness but retains the crunch from the crispy quinoa. Hospitality was by far the best I've had in the city and I look forward to eating here more often when I'm in town.
HIGHLY RECOMMEND - 5 stars easily

This is a great spot for brunch and was happy to see they take reservations. We arrived early and stood around in the middle area enjoying our spicy pork rinds. It's been awhile since we were here so I don't remember specifically what else we had except the bacon which was so good and strong coffee.

Service was attentive even with how busy it was. My only complaint was the communal table we sat at. The seats were so close together and I barely had any elbow space. It gets really loud in here and I definitely could not hear what my dining partner was saying.

The beer selection was good but was disappointed in the dinner menu and service. We were in a party of 8 and our server suggested that we share plates. However, the plates were too small to share amongst 8. The vegetable plates were great- we got cauliflower, beets, squash, and sweet potatoes. The mussels are good! We got an order of the whole chicken and the suckling pig to share and for a quality meat restaurant, the meat was scarce on these plates. There was definitely not a lot of chicken, with only 3 legs and no thighs or wings, and only a few pieces of pork. Would have been better if we had each gotten our own meal, the meat didn't have the amount of quantity expected for the price.

They have a good looking menu and an extensive beer list so don't be shy about asking for suggestions if you're overwhelmed.  Just about all our food was fantastic.  We all shared a variety of their options from starters & veggies to seafood & other meats.  We all agreed the 2 veggies we tried, the brussel sprouts & the cauliflower, were some of the best veggies we've ever had.  We also devoured the branzino fish and the ham on "hay" dishes (the best ham I've ever had).  I'd say the "fish fry" dish was the least impressive out of everything we ordered but it still tasted good.  Oh, and of course we continued our gluttony and shared 2 family-style desserts.  One would have been plenty for 4 to share but we couldn't decide between the Sticky Toffee Pudding and the Apple Crisp so ended up getting both.  Both of those were very good.

They were pretty packed on a Saturday night so reservations are definitely recommended.  Because of how busy they were the service from our waiter was rushed and lacking in attentiveness as he was covering many tables. They definitely should have had more severs on a Saturday night so I'm not sure if some called off or if that is how they are typically staffed.  The rest of the staff that was filling our water glasses and taking away empty dishes were  attentive but speedy to the point of being abrupt. All of a sudden an arm would reach out in front of me & whisk an empty plate away from across the table adding a quick "excuse me" as an afterthought.

The bathrooms are a unique layout with individual rooms to do your business and then a communal large round sink in the middle of the area with hand dryers on the walls (they also have 2 larger handicap rooms, 1 men's/1 women's, that have the sink & hand dryer in them as well).  And the rum-scented hand soap they have is divine!

I had heard good things, and was looking forward to trying it.
It took a while for a server to come to our table, even though the restaurant was not busy. Once the server did come, he was apologetic, and attentive, and offered to replace a dish that we did not like.
Still, the dishes that we ordered were hit or miss. We found the pork rinds much too seasoned. The ribs were not what we expected, but our salad was very good.

The food here is incredible. Cooked perfectly and by far the best meal we had in Chicago. However, the portions are very small compared with the prices so I deducted a star for this reason. They need to add a little to their portion sizes and then hands down, Id give 5 stars! The beer is also amazing!

My family and I had the privilege of going for my wife's birthday. I have to tell you the service was nothing short of superb. We had the entire staff from the hostesses to the managers making my wife's special day extraordinary.

The Publican's ever changing menu couldn't have been better. The food, and we had a little bit of everything was phenomenal, and the service of our waiter, Gio was excellent.

I'd highly recommend this place if you haven't tried it yet. You won't be disappointed.

Been meaning to come to the Publican for a long time and I finally went there today for brunch. After dining here , I truly don't really see what all the hype is about.

What I had:

Drink
* Publican Mimosa is definitely worth a try as it's a mix of beer and OJ so a nice twist on the normal mimosa.

Food
* Publican Bacon is good and flavorful, even the fat. I'd recommend trying the bacon as an appetizer or a side for your meal.

* Oven-baked Sourdough Pancake is good, as it's stuffed with bacon wrapped chicken thigh and sausage. I would have liked this dish more than I did if it came without sausage. To me the sausage just didn't taste like it was fully cooked. The bacon wrapped chicken thigh was really good mixed with the pancake and maple syrup.

My friend who has been to the Publican multiple times said that dinner is much better than the brunch so I guess I need to go back and experience dinner.

pics.caption: Oven-baked Sourdough Pancake (bacon-wrapped chicken thigh, breakfast sausage & Burton's maple syrup)

review.des:
My friend and I had a great dinner here. The highlights were the delicata squash and country rib. We had wine with dinner which was delicious but served in a low ball glass, a wine glass would be preferred. Dessert was not too sweet and an excellent finish to a well rounded meal. Chocolate tart with coconut custard and cookie crust.
The flavors of all the dishes were complex and well planned without being over seasoned. I would definitely return for a repeat meal.
The last item was the noise. It's a large open space which makes it noisy which was contributed to with music turned up too loud.  A little tough to hear my friend sitting across the table from me.
Love the entire One Off Hospitality brand. All of their restaurants are fantastic.

Delicious cheese, lots and lots of meat, and cool decor make the Publican a great place to grab drinks, snacks, or dinner with friends and family.  My cousin and I came here for a late lunch and ate from their afternoon dining menu since dinner wasn't going to be offered until 5:30. Highlights included the Serrano  ham and the little gem salad. Portions for meats and charcuterie are offered in half-size or full portions, and the half-sized Serrano serving was enough to fill us both up.

Plus, if you try something and can't get enough of it, pop over to Publican Quality Meats across the street to grab some for home!

The Publican prides itself on pork, oysters, and beer. I fiendishly enjoy all of those essential nutrients, so I knew that I would be as happy as a clam here.

My husband and I had one of the most indulgent and rich meals here for his birthday/celebratory first night in the Windy City in November. This is anti-New Year's Resolution cuisine, so we visited just at the right time.

The menu is everchanging, but The Publican always has the aforementioned goodies, and many more, on the menu. The beer menu is vast and all servers are certified cicerones. We went with some local brews, but their list of Belgians and beyond is impressive. The food menu is sectioned into vegetables, fish, bread, and meat. Highly recommend a charcuterie plate-they have some amazing cured meats here. We enjoyed very finely chopped brussels sprouts, their housemade cuttlefish ink pasta with chorizo, and to secure our fate in gluttony, the porchetta (with figs and hazelnuts-two of my favorite things.) If you haven't noticed, the Publican is kind of a go big or don't go at all place. The portions aren't extreme, but all together add up to a rich dinner. But don't forget dessert. My husband loves chocolate, so we had perhaps one of the best desserts (he's still talking about it :)-the ice cream bombe with chocolate, peanut butter, caramel, and pretzel.

Loved the convivial and boisterous atmosphere here. This is like a German beer hall but with truly exceptional food. Gorgeous setting to gorge yourself on delicious food.
Recommend getting a reservation, especially on the weekend, but the food is great. Another of my West Loop favorites for brunch or dinner.
One of all time faves in the city.  The little gem salad is my go to.  Brunch here is also top notch!

My buddy and I went here for breakfast, but thinking about it, maybe we should have tried this place out for lunch instead? I could have just expected too much from this place? I am willing to give this place another shot on my next visit to Chicago, so, don't crucify me just yet for the "below than stellar" rating.

I ordered the pork belly scrapple which is constructed of rhubarb mostarda, sourdough and sunny side up eggs. I must say, it was nicely porky, and the rhubarb mostarda gave it a slight sweetness to it, but then the yolk from the eggs lovingly engulf each bite with joy. I just wished that possibly the scrapple was a bit more crispier(?), possible?

I shall try you again Publican and your sister across the street. Until we meet again, I will be counting the days.

Came here for brunch and thought it was superb!Showed up at 10 am reservations on a weekend and there was a line waiting but the service moved quickly.
As expected, the dishes were heavy and very filling. I had the avocado toast and added maple bacon as a side. FYI - the bacon is actually a 2 piece of pork belly and it was sublime. The bloody Mary's are spicy and come with a 3oz beer chaser....thought that was interesting, but it worked perfectly.

The indoor decor is kind of a modern take on an old school tavern. Communal sitting with long tables but also spots along the sides of the restaurant and by the bar. It was a gorgeous day so we sat outside.

pics.caption: Spicy pickles Bloody Mary with a beer chaser - it works!

review.des:
A serious parade of food is what ended up on our table.  We even managed to order enough for my veg. husband to need to take home leftovers.  That's always an impressive feat with a sharing plates situation, particularly at a restaurant so meat focused.  

As I mentioned, we ordered a lot.  So many things sounded so good.  On the veggie side, we ordered the BBQ carrots, the avocado salad, and the beets as well as an order of bread with salted butter.  For the more carnivorous (ok, me and my friend) we did a half order of serrano ham, a half order of mussels, and the chicken.  The half order of mussels was huge and came with more bread which was perfect for sopping up the juices in the bowl.  The chicken was also amazing and the summer sausage that came with it, was wonderfully like large pieces of fancy hot dog.  I mean this in the very best way.  

Drinks were good with a respectable beer list and our server was informative.  I'm not always the hugest fan of communal seating, but it's not a bad way to spy on what others are ordering.  

I'll be back for more fancy hot dog!

Interesting atmosphere, definitely more casual than most other highly rated restaurants in the city which is refreshing. They call it "family style" but it doesn't really have to be. You could easily have each person in your party order your own dish and not share with the table, it just might not come out at the same time.

Drinks:
This was probably the biggest disappointment of the meal. I started with the Moody Tongue saison which was a good pick for a refreshing beer on a hot day, with a nice kick of lemon. Next I ordered an Apex Predator, but the waitress came back a few minutes later saying that they were out of it. She offered up another saison/farmhouse ale that they had on tap so I happily agreed to that without investigating it much. Turns out I really should have because they charged $12 for the beer and it was only 5% abv, which is quite low for a saison. I have no idea how they justify charging $12 for that beer, it was very average. I don't mind paying for a high quality beer, especially when it has a higher abv, but this was absurd.

Appetizers:
Charcuterie - We got the half order which was plenty for the two of us to have a tasting of several kinds of meats. The lamb salami was good, but cut so thin you didn't get a whole lot of taste from it. Pork pie was pretty bland and had more bread than meat. The head cheese was good, and not as "funky" as I thought it might be. The foie gras and blood pate was strangely plain and lacking flavor - I expected it to be quite rich flavorful but it just tasted like bologna. The morteau sausage was easily the best on the plate, and it had a nice snap, great flavor, and was a little spicy.
Oysters - We ordered 6 east coast oysters and enjoyed all of them. However, they could do a better job shucking them as we had to crunch down on some bits of shell/sand which is never pleasant.

Entrees and sides:
Bouchot Mussels - We got the half order and that is more than enough for a group of 2-4 to share as the pot was huge and the individual mussels were very large. The broth was amazing and it came with a large piece of bread to soak it all up. If you like mussels, I highly recommend this dish.
Beef Tongue- Hands down the best thing we ate here. I am not what I would call a "foodie" that is used to eating things like this, and I LOVED it. Once you get past the idea that you are eating a tongue, the flavors and textures are outstanding. This dish is well prepared with great sauce/spices and the meat itself is cut into small cubes. It almost has the look and feel of a beefy ham. Do yourself a favor and order this.
Barbecue carrots - Quite good for a side dish, and the barbecue/smokey taste was VERY prevalent. They taste like they are cooked over a bonfire.  

Overall I would come back for the food, and not the drinks. I might try the chef's selection for dinner which gives you 8-10 courses for $65pp.

Where do I begin. We made reservation and were seated upon arrival. They offered us Seats at a community table and I asked if we could get a small table where we have privacy. They were nice enough, and we were lucky that a couple was leaving right when we walked in, so they were able to accommodate our request. Best Bloody Mary of my life. The side of bacon is a MUST. Husband ordered the steak and I got the sausage. Both amazing.  If you live in Chicago and haven't tried this place you are missing out big time!

Overdue review. Good brunch spot in the west loop. Food was delicious though be forewarned they have the communal seating that many restaurants are seeming to adopt now. Service was good and anytime you offer me pork belly the answer will be yes. Will be back.

After coming here during the summer, I had to taste see what they had in store for the winter menu. I was not disappointed. Having already tried their cold cuts and breads, we went straight for the meats/fishes and we were not disappointed.

Recommended:
Pinkerton avocado - get it.  I was really surprised by the mixture of the saltiness of the trout roe with the texture of the sweet walnuts and soft avocado.  

Duck breast - just as before, tender and braised in a sweet wine sauce.  The crispy skin just adds more juice to the already succulent duck.

Dover sole - whole sole with a nice melody rub of spices and salts with

Bread pudding - warm, homey and delicious. It is topped with a nice piece of ice cream.  It is big enough to SHARE!!! (or you can order one and box it up for yourself :) )
If you like BBQ flavor - BBQ carrots were surprisingly good!  They have a bit of spice but if you don't like BBQ sauce flavor, skip it.

Good but I would try something else:
Sturgeon- grilled and prepared nicely but it was lacking flavor

Suckling pig - a bit too salty.  The melody of vegetables in cherry vinaigrette was good but didn't really compensate for the saltiness of the pork.

Skip:
Yellow tail - eh i've had fresher. They claimed it was from tsukiji fish market.  Wasn't that good for 18$
Pumpkin cake - skip - nothing special

All and all, Publican impressed me more than my last visit.  I will be back again in the future.
This place is great! Great service, food and awesome vibe. We had the pork belly, rinds and some Belgian beer. You need to try this place.
Porcetta was so salty. Oysters were great. Mussels were so plump and fantastic. Pork belly with the grits was out of this world. But man we ended on a salty note. That Porcetta. :/

What prompts me to give a restaurant with exceptional food 2 stars...being served caffeinated coffee when you ask for decaf. Leaving you with a pounding headache and not able to sleep. The food is exceptional and the price is reasonable for the quality. The service is top notch. The atmosphere is loud and high energy. the food is as great as the place is LOUD. Could not hear my dinner companion. Was not a relaxing dinner and I couldn't wait to leave. As exceptional as the food was. I wouldn't go back. I found myself yelling to have a conversation. Not enjoyable over all because of how loud it was.

If you like pork, this is the place to be.

Try grabbing a seat at the bar for a little view of the action. Order some absolutely stunning oysters and watch them being shucked right in front of your eyes. Try one of each if you have it in you.

Have some succulent chicken liver pate to put you in the zone and then follow up with the trio of ham and find yourself in a savory meltdown. Overwhelmingly delicious.

pics.caption: Chefs choice oysters = really really good.

review.des: Where to begin? We are in love. Food, service, ambiance all superb! A few things though: expect to spend a bit (its family style so to try more than one item you order a few plates), if you sit in the corner of a community table near the door in the winter, expect to be freezing, and lastly, most courses are decadent so the flavors can be overwhelming if you were brought up on bland cooking; just go slow, get a few oysters and don't over indulge, take it to go! How's that for the worlds worst run on sentence? Overall: check this place out for a new experience and wonderful food.

Although we live in the neighborhood, tonight was our first visit to the Publican but it definitely won't be our last. We mentioned to our server Joanna that it was our wedding anniversary and she surprised us with a nice sparkling wine as we were waiting for our drink order to arrive. The food at the Publican was outstanding, definitely lived up to the well-earned hype. The heirloom tomato salad was the best I've ever had. We also tried the little gem lettuce salad, white sea bass, and that fantastic Slagel Farms chicken, all delicious. The service was smooth, polished, seamless and comfortable. To top off our evening and our order of carrot cake ice cream, Joanna brought out a complimentary order of Erica's Cookie Jar in honor of our anniversary -- yum! Love the Publican. Can't wait to go back.

I have enjoyed eating here three times, and the food is excellent. Very meat-centric as everyone knows, but also interesting and tasty vegetable treatments as well. However, the place is just too loud to be enjoyable. Today we got seated very quickly at a spot near the kitchen, and got excited looking over the menu, but just couldn't communicate our excitement over the cacophony of loud music and screamed conversations around us. We left without ordering, sadly.

Restaurant vibe: the place is spacious and pretty loud. The decor is super cute with nice lights and tall booths.

Food: love the maple glazed bacon - please order it. Although my boyfriend thinks that it's more of a pork belly than bacon - still love it (10/10)

Waffles - too crispy, not that great. Wouldn't order it again. (4/10)

Some pork and biscuit dish - it tasted good, lots of pork given. (7/10)

I would say the food is alright - the hash brown looks nice though, you guys should try it and let me know if it's good.

I've been to Publican many, many times.  It has become a favorite go-to spot for many different occasions - mostly for dinner.  (I've also done the Publican dinner at Slagel Family Farms which too was an awesome experience).  I'm surprised that it took me so long to update my  review and bump it to the 5 stars it deserves.

Service for the most part is excellent, including on our most recent visit in January. We've had a couple of more average experiences but even those are few and far between. They also do the details well - making sure to clear empty plates and get the table ready for the next course. This is particularly important when you are at the communal table as space can be more limited.  (It does get loud and noisy in there. It is not the place for a quiet, intimate dinner).

They have a great beer list and are helpful in providing recommendations.  I appreciate that they have more than just one or two ciders on the list.  The cocktails are carefully crafted but they have a full bar which should be able to meet anyone's tastes.

The food is downright yummy. I love that they use local ingredients when they can.  I want to eat the entire menu but thankfully our waiter stopped us before we could get in over our heads.  The spicy pork rinds are a wonderful starter especially with a pre-dinner beer or cocktail.  Almost every time I go I get oysters, the mussels, and some of the La Quercia ham.  Specifically, on our last trip in we ordered: Cauliflower gratin, a cold smoked fish, the pork shank in addition to my usual suspects.  The pork shank was delicious.  The meat was so tender and it just melted off the bone.  The cold smoked fish was also tasty and a very different option. We absolutely devoured the food.  

Publican remains one of my favorite spots. Reservations are highly recommended (and with some notice for prime times).  It can be a somewhat reasonable dinner for the money but at the same time, it isn't hard before that bill adds up.

We went here on a week night with some colleagues visiting from out of town. We decided to try a variety of items as they suggested the best way to go about the menu is sharing dishes.

We started off with the grilled breads that come with a tasting of the 3 different sides. The pimento chese dip was incredible - could eat that stuff with a spoon. We also got oysters, the full charcuterie and the pork rinds. The charcuterie was delicious - only wish it would be served with some cheeses. The pork rinds were good - I'm not a huge fan of them normally but they were tasty and had a little kick to them.

For our main dishes we split the pork belly, scallop, fried cauliflower and carrots. The pork belly was unbelievable! I could easily go and get just that with the fried cauliflower. Maybe double up on both to be full! .... the fried cauliflower was AMAZING. not soggy, perfectly cooked and sat ontop of a delicious sauce with indian like flavors. the carrots were good - nothing too die for. The scallop was also good - beware: does only come with 1 single scallop. but my one bite was so perfectly cooked and flavored. would highly reccomend.

We finished off with two flavors of ice cream and the waffle. the ice creams were so good - we got a bubblegum flavor, that tasted exactly how you would imagine with small bites of marshmallow, and a chocolate peanut butter. Being a peanut butter gal, I fell in love with the latter of the two. We also got the waffle - it was fluffy and served with a blueberry like jam. while it was good, there are so many other fun options I would get something different next time. Overall, would highly reccommend The Publican. Everything surpassed my expectations and I will for sure be returning

This used to be my favorite restaurant in the city and the last few times I have been there I have left very disappointed.  This last trip we were there for brunch and were one of the first reservations of the day.  When the hostess showed us to one of their high tops (which are extremely uncomfortable to sit at), she rolled her eyes when we asked for any other lower table (the place was only a quarter full).  They rushed our food - the oysters came out 10 min after our entrees (which came out in about 5 minutes).  I know they are trying to turn tables but this place should know well enough how to time food runs.  The food was just OK at that.  Still a solid bloody though.

One night in Chicago. One meal. So many choices. Deep dish pizza, chalk full of sausage and broccoli. Maybe for lunch tomorrow. But this is a meat city. There is only one place on my mind. The Publican. This is a place with only 4 pictures on their wall. Four large five feet by five feet pictures of gourmet swines. Pigs. Meat.

Of course I start with hot spices fried pig skin. Pork rinds. Light. Airy. Not greasy. And washed down by great local Chicago beers. But then where to go?  Pork belly? Ribs? One of their five fresh hams?  Oh no. The waitor says go with the tongue. Beef tongue. I did. Wow.

I have eaten a lot of tongue in my life. It started with my mom's pressure cooked boiled tongue as a kid. Not a favorite memory.  I have moved on to flavorful lengua (Mexican spiced) tongue tacos.  

But this. Tonight was the best tongue ever. Cubed. Pressure cooked. Slow roasted in maple syrup. And seared fast. And then topped with fresh greens, sweet tomatoes and chimichirri. So amazing. Everyone needs to try this tongue. With fresh spring peas. And a Saison beer from local brewery Moody Tongue (ironic, eh?).

Come here. Order the tongue. Or whatever the waiter named Antonio tells you to order.

Food was amazing 2/2 visits here for me. I came back to try the sour dough pancakes again, but their menu was renewed. The other food we ordered still didn't disappoint us. Their pork dishes on the menu are really succulent and delicious!!
Food we tried-waffle, pork shoulder, braised brisket

Serving staff is always attentive and knowledgeable when we ask for the menu. And for the mom with the kids who always have to go to the bathroom in the middle of their meals, the publicans restroom helps reducing the annoying level down for me. Haha.
The bottomless coffee is truly bottomless. They come and refill my mug with delicious intelligentsia coffee nonstop. Love this place! Hoping to come back soon again.

I had a slice of coffee cake as an appetizer and it was delicious. I really wanted the crab scramble but they ran out of crab  so I decided to go with the pimento toast which was still yummy. I'm a very indecisive person and the waitress dealt with my annoyingness very well. She was patient and helpful. All around great food and restaurant aura. Also, LOVE the bathrooms, pretty cool lookin!

pics.caption: Pimento cheese toast and in the back Braised Pork Shoulder
Cinnamon Streusel Coffee Cake. Very yummy flavors, wish I had a glass of milk while eating

review.des: Meh. Totally underwhelmed with their brunch. Service was a 2.5 out of 5 for me. There were times when he was super slow. Didn't explain much about the menu either. The food was mediocre - a small waffle with butter and jam, I can make this easily at home or get at a diner for a lot cheaper. Hashbrowns were boring. Maybe their dinner menu is more of a winner?

The Publican is a wonderful restaurant that describes itself as an homage to beer, pork and oysters.

This is really my kind of restaurant. From the wide open dining space and kitchen down to the extensive and sometimes obscure Craft Beer menu, everything about The Publican drips with Chicago chic. I will admit that the service can feel a bit stuffy and gruff at times, but the kitchen well outshines any service related gripes I would have.

The menu is quartered and it is clear as day that the team in the kitchen is serious about seafood. Fresh Fish, Bi-Valves, Farmed Clams and even Trout can be found along with familiar Pork and Red Meat selections and even some surprises (Beef Heart Tartare, anyone?).  

Our table of four was thankfully full of culinary adventurers and we decided to order numerous plates and share the flavors tapas style. This is definitely the way to roll as you get a great idea of exactly how expansive and creative The Publican's Chef team really is. Table favorites include Spinach Boudin Blanc, Sirloin, Suckling Pig, and the Country Ribs. As for seafood the Suzuki Bass Crudo really shines and their ludicrously fresh Albacore rivals some of ours here in California. I nearly forgot to give a nod to the Oysters (Island Point) and Razor Clams.

There was not a single flavor I didn't adore and although the Chicagoans we dined with sneered at some of the plates costs, it was pretty much what I would expect to pay for fare of this caliber home in Orange County/Los Angeles at say, Animal or Sun of a Gun. Not a direct comparison of restaurants, but you can make out numerous similarities of concept, price point and creative style.

The Publican is truly a great Chicago restaurant and I long for a return visit.

Always love publican brunch!  The Bloody Mary, which I usually love wasn't up to par, hence we knocked off a star...

We ordered:
Duck pate - so good and came on grandmas China!
Lamb - had a really good kick and Mediterranean taste to it
Park shoulder - was told it was really good
Bloody Mary's - not up to usual standards

Regretted not getting the pecan sweet bun!

You can't go wrong with the $65 chef's tasting. Well, it's a crap shoot, since you don't know what they'll bring out, but I can tell you that we had several plates of food and dessert at the end.

However, it's loud and it's close to more like a zoo here, so if you're expecting an intimate chef's course dinner, this is not the place. It's more like gorge yourself and drink without any thoughts of any repercussions after you leave this place kind of place.

And you get a taste of what and why Chicago is one of the best places for food and drinks. I would definitely come back sans half the drinks and not as drunk coming in and try to enjoy more of the other stuff they have to offer.

Even though this place has amazing brunch and dinner items, we actually came here just for the dessert! They used to have a bread pudding that was amazing but when we got there, realized it was taken off the menu..

But that worked out to our advantage because we tried a newer item, the Sticky Toffee Pudding, and oh my god.. Delicious.

The atmosphere is great here, great for date nights and especially good for group gatherings. There are tall tables (standing bars) for just drinks or dessert, etc.

Just be sure to make reservations if you need a table because it can get very packed especially on weekends.

Love their bathroom area, fun communal sink idea.

pics.caption: Sticky Toffee Pudding with Yogurt Ice Cream and candied walnuts = heavennnnn.

review.des:
My husband, friend, and I came here for brunch on Saturday. We made reservations so we got a nice booth table. It's really cute where the booth has doors..as if it was a house. The atmosphere is pretty cool - tall ceilings and they  have communal tables in the middle. The chairs and doors are tall - you must be tall in order to serve here (haha) otherwise your reach may be a little hard.

Onto the food, we started with three types of oysters. We like one of them but the other two we had were a little below average. I had the pork schnitzel entree which was okay. Presentation looks good. My dish was mainly fried batter..and a thin slice of pork inside. It came with potatoes and beans. My husband had their baked egg dish which came with lamb, chick peas, and fennel? It came in a nice le cruset baking dish. He didn't seem to enjoy his dish as much. My friend had their open face proscuitto sandwich. Not sure if she enjoyed it..she didnt say much. We shared the frites with eggs. It's literally just crunchy french fries with a fried egg on top. Boring.

We were able to stick around and chat for a bit. I like the atmosphere. Staff was friendly. Wish food was a little better. Maybe I'll come back for dinner since I hear the dinner menu is better.

I enjoy watching Anthony Bourdain's shows, specifically "Parts Unknown" and "The Layover" while eating dinner (because what better way to eat than to watch someone else eat). This is where I first discovered The Publican. After many trips to Chicago, I finally got the chance to try it out.

The charcuterie, highlighted in Bourdain's adventure, and my love for it first drew me there, but it was the other diverse food options that made the experience unforgettable.  

Located in a very rich food section of the city (Michelin star restaurant, the Goat restaurants, as well as many other excellent choices) it was no surprise that we would have to wait a bit to get seated as we didn't have a reservation. Luckily, it only took 30 minutes to get a seat at the bar and they were nice enough to text us when the seat was ready, while we explored the area.

Straight to the food. Their menu is separated into three main distinct sections: vegetables, fish, and meat. We ended up ordering half charcuterie, a mackerel dish, and a duck breast dish and after asking our server, he suggested adding a vegetable dish. We decided to try out their famous spicy pork rinds instead and we weren't disappointed. A large part of their menu changes frequently, which I am a huge fan of. However, I am a little salty because I ended up eating one of the best dishes I have had in a while there, the duck breast.

The duck breast dish. Perfectly cooked. Duck with persimmon. Not a combination I knew went together like cookies and milk. The incorporation of the persimmon into the sauce as a sort of reduction was the icing on the duck.
