I might have to stalk their menu and hope they revist this dish and make the trip back to Chicago just to try it again.

Not to say that the other dishes weren't amazing, because they were.

The spicy pork rinds came out first and my attempts to stop eating them so I could save room for the rest of the feast were futile. Even the classic "put it out of your reach" method didn't work.

The mackerel came whole and had just the right amount of char-grilled flavor.

The charcuterie sated my charcuterie desire. I do wish they offered a greater variety of mustard.  But that's just a minor gripe.

Do yourself a favor. Come eat here yesterday.

I love to eat in great restaurants and i have been fortunate to live and work in San Francisco, New York, L.A. and Boston in addition to enjoying culinary exploration abroad for many decades. I don't hesitate to put my experience at The Publican in the Top 5 all-time dining experiences of my life. It was an incredible meal and the service was impeccable.

My girlfriend and I are visiting and on two separate occasions while we were making our way to Chicago via L.A. and Mexico we ran into local foodies. In both cases when we asked about where to have a great meal these locals recommended Publican, so we were feeling pretty good about it before we even got there and knew we had to check it out. Our reservation was for 8:00 on Monday. It was busy but they lovely hostess was able to quickly accommodate our request for a table on the patio.

Our waitress Tess was so genuine, friendly, and professional. Even though it was busy she made it seem almost effortless as she took time with us and coursed our meal perfectly. The wine list is interesting and there are a number of northern and eastern European varietals that  I was not familiar with. Tess asked us what wine characteristics we liked and then brought us an amazing Hungarian wine that was, delicious, full-bodied and PERFECT for our meal. We were really impressed by the coursing of the food, and clearly the priority was for us to savor our meal as opposed to the usual (if sometimes subtle) strategy of most restaurants to "turn" tables. As It started to get a little chilly outside Tess went in and borrowed a sweater from the aforementioned lovely hostess for my gf so we could stay at our sweet patio table... incredibly thoughtful. She was also expertly backed up by the super-charismatic and super-helpful assistant manager Kevin who initially took our drink and oyster orders and checked in with us throughout our meal.

We had beautiful, fresh, crisp oysters and clams, a llittle gem salad, chicken liver paté, a delicious marinated eggplant dish with crispy shallots, and an an incredibly savory pork belly entrée with grits, peach, basil vinaigrette & pepita. Every bite was a flavor explosion. I should also mention that the "o-mi" mezcal cocktail was really nice and not overly sweet which I always appreciate. I guess the menu changes almost daily but if our meal is any indication then I would say that you can't make a bad choice here.

The ambiance is definitely lively and busy. It's not fancy but it has the feel of a crafted dining experience. I loved the beer taps and the amazing beer selection as well and when we completed our meal and things started slowing down for the restaurant we lingered at the bar for another hour. We spent most of that time talking to Tess and Kevin who came over just to hang out with us, buy us a beer, and talk about life, Chicago, L.A., etc. What a great evening. Thank you guys and please tell the chef how much we loved it!!

Listen, I don't even eat pork BUT I went here and allowed myself to indulge a little and was surprisingly flabbergasted by how good the food was!  Ok, the only pork I had was their ham and their pork rinds but they were both off the chain!  I ate some of about 6 other dishes(farm chicken, barbecued carrots, etc.) that I can't quite remember right now and they were delicious.  My table had 3 different desserts(apple crisp, waffle and basque cake) and I recommend them all.  You should definitely check out this place.  The food and atmosphere are both enjoyable and the wait staff was cool and friendly.

I will just start off by saying that for an upscalish kinda restaurant I'm not really a fan of community tables.  I think it's kinda lazy and really only designed to pack as many people into the restaurant as possible.  Plus, because there is so many people, it just gets so LOUD.  I could barely hear my husband and I had to practically yell for him to be able to hear me.  Secondly, the food.  It was okay overall...my husband and I ordered the chef's tasting menu. But dang, most everything we received was basically some kind of protein or vegetable covered in a slaw with a citrus-based dressing.  It was all kinda one note cause everything started tasting the same after a few dishes.  We were just sort of waiting for a savory break from all the citrus and acidity, but it never did come.  Dessert was good however...we received the cheesecake ice cream and the waffle, both of which were excellent, and the waffle was probs my favorite part of the meal.  Overall it was a decent dinner, but it lacked variety in its flavor profiles, and the food hall ambience left something to be desired.  Hence the three star review.

Love this place.  First time was a thank you dinner for having made cake and sweets for a friends wedding.  Was wonderful.  Attention to detail, I hope they never get lazy on the little things.  This started my frequent visits to their butcher around the corner.  I know they are known for the whole meat thing but the salads are wonderful.  
Have been back to the restaurant several times since.  A good place to bring someone from out of town.  My one friend --pretty picky, does not like most vegetation, said, they do know how to cook meat here.  That is a high compliment from him.  As he is so picky.  
Anyways, I love this place, though the whole corral concept thing was too tight and not comfy.

This was the first place we had dinner at on our vacation. While the menu looked amazing there was an option for a coursed "chef's choice" menu. We have learned that the best kind of dinners are the ones where the chef decides, and this was incredible. I don't know how many courses we shared - maybe 6 - 8, we started with items like pork rinds, oysters, pate, dover sol, a few other pork dishes and desserts. Everything was amazing and very well priced. The service was on point and the cocktails were well made.

Great Food , superb creations, and the fact they acquire it the morning of is wonderful.
Aaron our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and full of hospitality to us Texans. Yes it's loud but part of the ambiance.
A must do if in Chicago

I've avoided this place because they didn't take reservations, which they do now. I also don't like communal seating, which they do have and don't leave much space between people.
Having gotten that out of the way, the food was very good and so was our server Naomi. I had a half dozen of wonderful oysters. I hardly used any dips because they had so much flavor. We also had the Chef's cheese selection, which also was very good. Food is meant to be shared so we ordered the smoked mackerel and the ham chop. Naomi gave a great description of each and she was right. The mackerel was full of smokey flavor. The ham was tender and large cuts. We took some home.

Does it continue to live up to expectation? Oh hell yeah. With as much high end dining as I do around the country on an ongoing basis, Chicago's resto scene continues to wow. Publican was one of the pioneers and a great fave of my daughter, too, so it became a destination. A couple weeks ago I had the op to bring a biz associate there for dinner. A Paleo devotee. EZ in the realm of food, actually, especially with a cooperative kitchen. The crew at P stepped up immediately and gave her book, chapter and verse of what was going to meet her needs. Nicely played. We drove the menu like Andretti drove Indy. It wasn't cheap, but there was just SO much on the offerings that worked not only for my friend's dietary needs, but also our culinary desires. Kick ass. So don't think twice, just go. You'll be happy you did.

Their smoked chicken and fries dish is one of the tastiest chicken offerings I have ever had. The fries were perfect - tender inside, lightly browned and crisp outside. Chicken was moist and smoky. It easily serves 3-4. Also loved their bread and butter plate. The smash cocktail was delightful. Service was professional but not so friendly.

Went to the publican for brunch today with my girls. Like other reviewers say, "they do brunch well." I ordered the biscuits and gravy with the brunch box. The biscuits and gravy were delish, and the brunch box cocktail was a good switch up to your typical mimosa at brunch. I loved the booth that we were seated in. It was cute and intimate. The only reason I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5 is that I felt the portions weren't large enough. Other than that, great brunch spot. Make reservations.

I found this gem online because I found out that the Purple Pig does not take reservations but this place does! My boyfriend and I had dinner here the first night here at Chicago. We ordered the Spicy Pork Rinds, Mussels, Oysters, and Porchetta. Our experience here was amazing. The servers were extremely attentive and always made sure we were updated on how much longer we would be waiting for the next entree, folded our napkins everytime we left our seats, and never had an empty glass. If you come here, be sure to order the Porchetta. Even though I was full, I made sure to finish every piece that was left on my plate. (So yes, it was THAT good).

I'm a member of The Breakfast Club.

Oh, you thought I meant the one with Judd Nelson? No, sorry... I meant the group of my friends that gets together once a month to visit a new brunch spot in Chicago. (Er, well, now that I've moved, I'm technically not part of their monthly meals anymore.) We've enjoyed a few good meals so far, including one morning at the Publican.

Knowing how popular it is, we called ahead and were told we couldn't make reservations; yet, when we showed up, they asked if we had a reservation. What the heck?? They let us come in anyway, brought us to the area with bar-style tables, and quoted us a 30-minute wait. We were OK with that. Thirty minutes of awkward standing went by and we hadn't heard anything. Finally, one of us approached the front desk and asked what was up. Apparently they forgot about us. Le sigh. They quickly offered us a table available immediately as long as we were able to clear out within an hour for a later reservation. Whatever. We took the table because we didn't have any other option.

We sat at the end of the communal table, right where it connected with a second table going in a different direction. Slightly awkward. The communal tables are interesting. I like the concept, with the potential to encourage different parties to converse and interact with each other, but really, it just felt like we were intruding upon someone else's brunch. And what's the reason for the little doors on the booths? Why do they get to be separated??

Anyway -- the brunch menu looked scrumptious, albeit a bit pricey. I ordered a coffee and a dish with grilled asparagus, egg, and fish. The coffee was fine. My dish was phenomenal. Despite my efforts to cut small pieces and savor every bite, it was quickly devoured. SO. GOOD. And.... not filling enough for me. Boo. I was still kind of hungry at the end of my meal. My friends enjoyed their various meals and mimoas, as well. One person ordered bacon -- the bacon was ridicously huge!! Crazy. Fortunately for the restaurant, we were done within the hour and able to leave so the next group could have their reservation.

Service was OK. The food is the best thing about the Publican. Otherwise, meh.

I wanted to like this place, and I didn't really have much of a reason to dislike it, but there was some kind of pretentious vibe floating through the air that kind of turned me off. It's almost as if you eat here just to look cool or say you've been there. Well.... I guess I'm one of those people too. Been here. Done that. I'm good.

Very disappointing.

Overpriced for food that not only was not impressive and also in small servings.
Atmosphere is very loud and tables as well as service is pub style.
You can have way better in Chicago for the price. Avoid!

Went for brunch

French toast: 5/5
I usually don't love french toast but this one was very special. The Mexican chocolate and strawberries were amazing, and the toast was very thick but still fluffy. The portion size was very big - I had to get a to-go box.

This is an interesting place.  The atmosphere is lively, the decor is odd, the seating arrangements odd (not bad, just different).  The booths have a swing out door to close once your in the booths.  They reminded me of the trains in Europe where you have your own "room" so to speak.  There are long rows of seating where you are next to and amongst others as if the tables are all joined together in a long row.  Again, not bad, just different.

The food was really good.  Meals are for sharing, great tastes and interesting added garnish too.  Lots of bread served so don't get carried away, save your appetite for the plates.  Chicken and fries is awesome.  Great beers and cocktails.  I loved the tomato salad.  Oh yea, the bathroom setup is also different.  You'll see for yourself.

Came for a work dinner and shared several plates. To take my taste into perspective, I'm a "husky guy" that likes meat. From the plates I remembered:

Beets - Yummy. Get it.

Apple salad - pretty good, refreshing. If you're a meat guy though save your money, and space in your belly, for something else.

Oysters - Tasty. This was actually my first time eating oysters so take with a grain of salt

Pork belly - OMG, so friggin good. MUST ORDER. There were 5 of us sharing and wish there was another plate of this.

Chicken and fries - Very good, order it! Chicken was tender and the fries would soak up the juice of the plate.

One thing I didn't like about this place was the seating. They do community seating so they have long tables that fit 20ish people and everyone sits next to each other. I wasn't paying for this dinner so it didn't matter as much but I wouldn't like this if I was going on a date night with my wife. For the prices, I'd want more intimacy. There's No privacy and it's loud.

Overall, yes it was pretty good food but didn't stand out as a place I'd have to come back to.

Note:They have valet for $12

My boyfriend and I walked in here without a reservation on a Thursday night. We got a corner spot at the communal tables right away. They have amazing beer and wine selections and everything on their food menu looked amazing. We opted for the elotes (seasonal), and the bread and spreads. I could eat a whole bowl of those elotes they were to die for. Best I've ever had! Then we ordered sirloin steak with polenta, peaches and pico de gallo which was another one of my favorite dishes this summer. The steak was perfectly cooked and the flavors blended so well together. We also ordered the chicken platter which was slightly underwhelming due to how salty it was but if the salt levels were cut down it would've been on point. Our waiter was also a gem! Love this place!

Special birthday treat.  Unique seating, we were in a booth.  Server was extremely helpful,  giving us great advice regarding the unique (for me) menu.  So many great options.  Great beer options.   Started with oysters,  then avocado salad.  The ham platter was outstanding.   Portions were just right for four people,  and dishes were served at the right time.   Well worth the money spent here.

I literally have not been here since the year it opened! So it was virtually a new experience for me. Overall - fun, lively place for dinner and drinks with good food. Now that I've been in Portland for a year it seemed on the pricier end for what it is...but alas it's Chicago! Also, the service was just "ok." We've been spoiled with really amazing service at restaurants lately so the mediocre service here stood out and kept this at a 4 for me. additionally, if we are ordering family style I feel like the plate sizes were too large for the food and made sharing the table space a bit challenging :)

What We Loved (food-wise) tho I know the menu rotates:
Broccolini - holy shit SO good. The sesame dressing or whatever it was was so tasty
Persimmon/Avocado - EXTREMELY unique, and loved the combo. Haven't had persimmons outside of Asia!
Butternut Squash - Very tasty but not enough for the group to share :)
Ribs - One of the best things we had all night. The flavor was AMAZING, unlike ribs elsewhere. Also note this is a rib cut of meat. Not RIBS. I wish the server would have told us that when we ordered just to prepare us. Still loved it but always good to know going in.
Snail Sausage - very unique, extremely flavorful

What was just ok:
Oysters - great selection, not our favorites, but good. On the $$ end :)
Ham selection - this was tasty! Not sure if it was $24 tasty but it is a generous portion
Apple Crumble - The apples were too firm for my taste. Made the dessert less dreamy :) Ice cream was amaze tho
Suckling Pig - This should've been AMAZING. The bread/kale pudding was delicious but the pork was DRY. It was our last entree dish and was a sad ending.
Ice cream bomb - very tasty, but nothing standout

Service-wise there were just a few things that were off. When we mentioned most of us had not been here in a long time she told us it's family style and then literally said "what else should I tell you about the menu." Between ordering our first round of drinks and coming back to deliver and take our food over it took a very long time.

The drink list is very extensive. Expect to pay more for a list this unique and robust. Same for the wine.

Overall, fun experience.

I wasn't too familiar with the West Loop prior to my most recent trip to Chicago, but now I'm convinced it's the most delicious neighborhood in town.  I started crushin' after visiting Girl & the Goat; I fell in love after visiting the Publican.

My friend and I dropped by the Publican sans reservations on a Tuesday evening.  The place wasn't busy at all, since it was a school night -- but rumor has it that rezzies are a must on weekends.  We were quickly whisked through the cavernous dining room and seated at one of the large communal tables.  

(I'm normally leery about communal tables, but our neighbors at the table were all friendly and polite, so all was well.)

We began with a round of cocktails.  I tried the Slim (gin, Aperol, St. Germain, lime, simple syrup), while my friend opted for a Sazerac (Journeyman Raverswood rye, Demerara syrup, bitters, pernod).  Both were served neat and were perfect for leisurely sipping.  (Clearly, the mixologists at the Publican do not condone slamming your drink before the ice melts!)

We ordered four different dishes, which were served family-style and perfect for sharing:

** Country rib pork chop with ramp kimchi, cashews, and rapini.  I was skeptical about this dish at first, because all the pork chops I've had in the past have been dry and bland -- but not this one!  It was juicy and tender, and paired nicely with the tangy ramps and crunchy cashews.

** Octopus with eggplant, tomato, fennel yogurt, and fideo pasta.  A relatively simple and straightforward dish of seafood and pasta, but the quality was outstanding.  Again, I was skeptical because all the octopus I've ever had in the past has been tough and rubbery, but the Publican's version was outstanding!

** Dry-aged duck breast with strawberries, dandelion greens, harissa, and feta. A gorgeous presentation with perfectly seared duck and fresh accompaniments.  Loved every bite of this!

** Dessert -- Kumquat panna cotta with sweet tea, thai basil, and honey caramel.  This dessert was so gorgeous that I didn't want to disturb it.  But once I did, it was heavy in my mouth -- sweet, silky, spicy, smooth, and luxurious.

Service at the Publican is casual but knowledgeable.  All the servers were running around especially frantically, outfitted in their signature khaki blazers, but there seemed to be a controlled chaos to the whole thing.

Can't wait to pay the Publican another visit next time I'm in Chicago -- and hopefully eat up the rest of the West Loop while I'm at it!  =)

We were adventurous and told the server (Adrian Grenier twin) that we would the the Chef's Menu - and had about 8-10 entrees served to us that we had no idea were coming out. Communal dining was fine and the cocktails were tasty.

Highlights:
Tasty cauliflower, squid, blood sausage and potatoes, red snapper was light and citrusy, The shank was super tender and flavorful and we were very happy but very full. The dessert was a sweet potato dish and it was fluffy and I had to fight my date over it. We were happy with our experience and glad that we made this one of stops during our Chicago weekend.

We had an absolutely wonderful experience. We ate the roasted tomatoes and country ribs. Fantastic! The service was excellent and the atmosphere is warm and lively. Great for families or a date night.

I have been so excited to try The Publican. In fact, we drove up from St Louis with this meal as the main focus of our quick trip!  What a pleasure it was to enjoy a fantastic meal, great service, the best company (my husband of 14 years). I was a little overwhelmed with such a full and eclectic menu, but the nice man taking care of us gave great recommendations. I hope to come back someday. In the meantime, I'll tell everyone I know to check it out!

So after going to two restaurants (the purple pig and au cheval) and was told the wait was from 2-5 hours, we decided to give The Publican a go! It was also on my list to go to, so why not! I don't regret it! They told us the wait was 1 hour for a table, or if we wanted to sit on a shared table we could do that with no wait! Well of course we took the shared table! Loved it! Yes it's a big table and people sit either side to side or next to each other. It was private and personal at the same time. The waiter said the menu changes daily! Waiter gave us amazing service and the busboys had our water constantly filled. The food was so delicious and satisfying. Will definitely recommend.

BEST. BRUNCH. IN. CHICAGO. EVER!!!

I am a breakfast/brunch lover.  Found this place thru yelp, and I am so glad that I tried it this past weekend with my hubby.  I love the look of this restaurant, especially the restroom.  The service is very good and fast here too!

My husband got crab scramble ($18). He loved it that he finished the plate in less than 10 minutes.  Haha!  

I ordered smoked pork shoulder.  OH MY GOD! I just died after one bite.  Now my saliva is pouring while writing this review.  I think I have to go back there this weekend to have that plate again!  The plate has black rice, kimchee, and the sunny side up egg over the meat.  It is really good! I cannot stop saying "oh my god it's so good" to my hubby while eating it. Haha!

My hubby and I also ordered the publican bacon, and it's SO GOOD! I don't know how to describe how good it is! LOL!

I m coming back to try that spicy pork rinds and hash browns! I heard it's good!

Tip for first-timers: Yeah it may be pricey, but it's so worth it!  YOLO! Make sure to try that publican bacon!  You will regret it if you don't try it! ENJOY!

OHHHHH THE MENU CHANGES DAILY!

We came here after our evening at the Aviary, a few doors down on Fulton, as we were still a little hungry, and needed to soak up all the alcohol we just had. Fun atmosphere, interesting community seating. We noshed on the pimento cheese, pickle plate, pork rinds, and the cauliflower. All very good. Great place to come with a group.

Came for brunch. Great atmosphere although it's a little loud. Sound reverberates of the walls and ceilings. Service was excellent. Had the oysters chef selection for $18, which was very good. Also had the biscuit and gravy - which was pretty good. The scrambled eggs with mushroom was excellent.
Also a to share concept. If you're two and don't ask anything particular, get ready to be seated at the big table. Fun concept but not for people afraid of loud. Food is great

One word (that isn't a word): STEAKON. The bacon so thick, it might be steak.
Also the chicken fried steak is bomb. As are the cocktails. I only went for brunch but I'm sure dinner is great too!
ONe of the best places in the city.. If you don't mind long communal table eating.. this is a fun place to go. Not to mention the AMAZING food & awesome beer selection!

When I came to Chicago Booth to interview candidates, my classmate and friends booked this place for our MBA gathering. This place is unique in terms of seating and internal decor. The side tables are blocked off with low table gates, and the middle tables are large farm tables. It is quite a unique experience just to visit and dine here. The food here is of course also amazing. They have a great selection of both vegetarian and meat dishes. We tried several appetizers composed of sausages, pickled goods. And our main dishes are a variety of steamed fish, meat stew, and vegetables. The dessert is a special kind of cheesecake with nuts. The cuisine is American with a dash of European like French. Overall, the food is delicious, and with the unique decor, this place offers a special dining experience.

The menu is a disaster. The entrees are overpriced and pretty terrible. The wines are all very sweet German style wines and the beer list is pretty limited as well...very overpriced and nothing we wanted to drink. I was not a fan of the hipster, impersonal, Germanic scene here. They make the best damn bread though! I will give them that. Get the ham with bread and the amazing goat butter and you are set. The vegetable dishes are well done as well and we enjoyed our fried broccoli with hazelnuts.

pics.caption: Fried broccoli, hazelnuts and too much honey. But good.
Delicious Benton ham with the best bread and goat butter. Winner winner
Smokey dry chicken with what tastes like rubbery pepperidge farm Summer sausage and greasy fries. Skip for $30

review.des: Brunch with a difference: vegies, sweets, proteins- the array of eclectic choices are amazing. A definite treat. Seating is booth communal and atmosphere is authentic and inviting. This was a definite highlight of our foodie Chicago tour.

I had the red wine soaked eggs Benedict and they were excellent. The only reason for not giving five stars is the noise level. I had to ask my friend to repeat herself several times and a few times I just didn't bother and nodded my head and pretended to hear her. Otherwise a good spot.

The Publican had been sitting in my Bookmarks for a while and I finally made it here for the first time with my sister.

The restaurant has an interesting set up with "corrals" along the wall which are like booths with doors.  With just two of us we were seated at the end of one of the communal tables, and there are a few high tops in the middle of the floor.  I also loved the lighting and the huge pig portraits.  It's like part farm part art museum.  It was still fairly empty at 5:30PM on a Saturday but got pretty packed by the time we left.

The food we got was very good, I really enjoyed how they include in the menu where everything is sourced from.  It really adds to the experience with the knowledge of where your food is coming from.

We started with a few oysters, our favorite by far were the Publican ones, small but very tasty and served with some homemade crackers.  This was followed by the Shrimp Ceviche which was visually a little off putting just because besides the edible fried shrimp heads the shrimp were not pink at all.  But it was still very delicious, and texture and taste wise was one of the better dishes of the night.  

Next up was the Spicy Pork Rinds which were cheesy with a bit of kick and a whole lot of pop.  You can definitely tell which table has ordered the Pork Rinds by hearing the pops of the rinds crackling.  Mmmmm, fried fat...

We then moved on to some veggies the Plums which was served with dandelion greans with pine nuts over a healthy wedge of burrata.  We absolutely loved this dish, imagine that, our favorite dish at this place being the salad...  It just had a great contrast of textures and flavors that worked perfectly.  I'm drooling just thinking about it.

After that came our Taste of Three Hams which that night was Colonel Bill Newsom's, Publican La Quercia, and Monte Nevado Serrano.  Of those, we definitely liked Colonel Bill Newsom's from Kentucky the best.  It came with Peasant bread and creamery goat butter which was very good.

We finished off with the Boudin Blanc, which our waiter suggested.  We didn't really like the white sausage, but we did really like the potato and sauce that it came with.

I really enjoyed the tapas style that they serve the food, it really allows you to sit back and slowly savor and enjoy the food.  They timed everything really well, and the service was really good.  Our server was a little unenthusiastic but he was knowledgable and made some great suggestions when it came to the food and did check up on us throughout the night.  Overall a great night.  A note, they do have valet, but there are quite a few free spots within a few blocks.

This is the most memorable breakfast I have had, and one of the best meals overall. Got an Open Table reservation for a Sunday morning at 9am so snagged a nice seat on the patio outside. Service was efficient and friendly, but then the food blew my mind.

There were so many delicious sounding options I had a hard time choosing, but opted for the publican bacon -- a huge quantity of crispy and salty and sweet pork belly -- and the tasso smoked pork shoulder. But it was oh so much more than just pork shoulder. The pork was served on top of farro, with a complement of kimchi, fermented chili, argula, and egg yolk. It was a masterful combination of flavors (salty, spicy, acidic, bitter) and textures (crispy, soft, creamy). I was not only full after eating it, I was totally satisfied.

I can't wait to go back!!!!

pics.caption: Pork shoulder over farro with kimchi and egg yolk.

review.des:
delicious place for a nice dinner. i was dining solo this visit and the staff was super inviting while also giving me space.

seasonal foods, everything was sooo good. i had a squash salad to start, which was divine. wish i could get the recipe! then onto the clams in green sauce--i asked for an extra slice of their crusty bread along with the grains that were already in the dish. then topped it off with basil, cinnamon and blackberry ice cream.

what a dream! definitely had to be rolled out of the place though.

Oh my gosh, that maple bacon though.

Seriously, that bacon itself is good enough to take any restaurant to five stars.

I came here for brunch upon recommendations from my friends to try that bacon. I ended up getting their bottomless coffee, the bacon, and the schnitzel. The schnitzell was extremely crispy on the outside, super tender on the inside, and overall very flavorful and well-seasoned. It came with a fried egg on top, which oozed all over the schnitzel. The chard salad on top was very well dressed.

The bacon as so good. It's not the kind of bacon you eat crispy. It's more like little pork belly steaks that are caramelized on the outside. The flavors are obviously impossible to mess up, but the perfect tenderness inside to the caramelization on the outside is why it's so perfect.

TIP: Make a reservation. We came without reservations. They told me it would be an hour wait, so I wandered the area. They do take your phone number and text you about 10 minutes before your table is available, so that you can wander without worrying about them calling your name. Our wait ended up only being about 35 minutes instead of an hour.

TLDR

I'm glad I tried it but I won't be back.

Just OK for me.  

Oysters - as expected. The crackers served with them were too salty.
Charcuterie plate - ugly presentation.  A pile of mustard, cornuchons, etc but taste wise it was fine.
Trio of ham - as expected. Generous portion.
Duck breast - tender but underseasoned imo. I liked the grapes, pear and other ingredients on the plate.
Pork belly - tiny portion but tasted wonderful
Dorade - awesome. Very large portion.
Cuttlefish ink pasta - very boring salty dish. Also a small portion.
Dessert was a chocolate hazelnut torte and their interpretation of a key lime pavlova.  Those were both fine.

Other considerations:
- I had a problem with the course timing. There was an interminable wait in between some courses and no, they weren't too busy.  
- the hot courses were mostly tepid (maybe has something to do with the previous point....)
- some poor guy came with the dorade to fillet it tableside. He tried unsuccessfully to debone it with a knife and fork. It was super awkward.  Many bones were missed. I'd prefer if they just brought the fish and didn't "help."
- the water guy when refilling our glasses always braced himself on my chair which would rock it.  The best part was how he would breath into my face doing this (since he is standing behind and slightly to the side). He also had an awkward moment pressing my coffee, pushing too hard and causing it to spill all over the table.

This is a busy establishment with a European inspired theme. The food was tasty and unique. The place was crowded and the servers were somewhat attentive. They had a stand up section which was different. The place was semi clean.

Review is based on the Dinner Menu. I'm probably the only one who was willing to review this place that hated it. For the past 5 years, my partner at work has done nothing, but rant and rave about this place and how amazing it is. I mean he literally could be their employee because he speaks of it so much. Being that he is a food loving guru who should host his own show at times, my other coworker and I decided to try it out and see why it is that this man rants and raves about this place. Needless to say we are still pondering the answer to that as tonight I can assure was my first and last time at this location. Allow me to begin with what we ordered:

Appetizer:
Squash- this was pure heaven and the only thing on the menu I'd like to think we would order this again.

Dinner:

1/2 Farm Chicken- it fell off the bone which was nice. It came with fries that were well cooked and crispy. While they praise themselves on everything being grown local, the fries tasted like something out of a frozen bag. I just had to wonder, was grown local, frozen local, and was the packaging just as local?

Pork Belly- we ordered this because they don't serve the glazed bacon during dinner hours, only brunch, and let me tell you what a mistake this was. The Pork Belly was nothing but fat and dry meat. More fat than meat though and the size was nuts for the price! We wondered how this little thing was supposed to feed two people? Maybe if we wanted to eat the fat it would. We were definitely not impressed with this one.

Country Rib- this was far from a rib! It was extremely undercooked and was impossible to cut. The flavor was more on the sweet side and it was so chewy that I felt like I was chewing gum. In the end my friend and I decided that my two boxer mixes would enjoy eating this more than we would as they would be able to handle it. I'm sorry, but the moment it becomes better for my dogs than me, it's a MAJOR problem. They like princes, but I'm the only one who get to eat like a Queen.

Dessert:

Waffle with a Cheesecake Napoleon ice cream- we enjoyed the waffle a lot as it was just the right texture. As for the ice cream, they make it themselves, and I tasted no cheesecake in it. Definitely not impressed with the ice cream. Waffle yes, ice cream no.

Bavarian- we both loved the Bavarian. It was the perfect texture and the perfect dessert. It shared the same texture as a mousse and was simply lovely.

Drink:
Lemonade- When you think of lemonade you think of sweet. This is not the case here, this lemonade is carbonated water and has real lemon it which made it so sour. I drank it even though I hated it because it was $3. No refills, not saying that I would have done it would they have offered them anyways or did they? I was to afraid to ask.

Atmosphere:

The restaurant was loud, had us screaming across the table, and listening into others conversations. It was nearly impossible for us to talk to each other. Think of a high school cafeteria with kids screaming and loud music trying to hide their screams. That's what eating here was like. Not only this, but I deal with Chronic back pain and the chairs were beyond uncomfortable. It was like sitting on the ground. I actually had to take an additional pain killer because the pain was that bad. If the food was better the pain would have been worth it, but it wasn't.

Not only were we unimpressed, but we are still trying to wrap our heads around the fact that the bill was so high when the food tasted so low. Definitely not on my places to eat for dinner again, but hey maybe we caught them on a bad night.

I will say though that I would be willing to try this for breakfast and lunch as the photos look delicious, but dinner is a no go for me.

Love this place. Charcuterie, oysters, clams, and beer! What else can a man ask for right? Perhaps bring a pretty date to enjoy with you I guess.

Their Charcuterie plate is more like pig sausages and pates or pork pies. I didn't receive any in depth selections of prosciutto or soppressata or anything of the sort. They have their own butcher shop directly across the street. Everything is tasty and special. It's casual filled with party energy so come with friends to drink and be merry. Great place!

Publican has a great beer hall type vibe. The restaurant has a great reputation, and has been putting out phenomal food for years.
I really like the overall vibe of the place and that they don't take themselves too seriously. It is laid back, warm, inviting and loud.
However:
I am personally not a huge fan of the menu options overall and the plating of the dishes. It is large homestyle and every dish is very centered around a single item, and they are all heavy decadent dishes. I think the menu and each dish in particular would truly benefit from a little more balance. They lack a bit of freshness and lightness to just compliment the fattiness and sweetness of some the dishes overall.  I am not going into the details of each individual dish as I have been here many times and this is more of a composite review.

Overall this is a very solid restaurant and I do enjoy returning here. I give it 3 stars because it is very solid but it is not a stand out restaurant in terms of overall culinary experience.

Finally,  It is hard to get in here without a reservation. Given the great casual beer hall vibe, a no reservation (walk in only) policy would be much cooler.

Had dinner on Sat 31st had great service meal came as ordered everything looked and tasted great. 24hrs later 3 out of 4 had food poisoning. There where two plates one person didn't have avocado salad and fried clams called was put on hold said manager was in a meeting. I think a customer calling about food poisoning would be more important

It's hard for me to remember a meal I've enjoyed more. The flavor profiles of each dish were so unique, and we just had a blast experiencing each one.

Took my girlfriend here last night for her birthday, and we ordered the following (ordered from favorite to least). Would HIGHLY recommend the first three:
- (something) skate: a ray fish. Definitely our favorite. Powerful flavors, and really fun how it's brought out. The kitchen server removes the cartilage from the center of the meat right at the table. We tried it because we thought, "Ray fish? When do you get to eat a ray fish?" And we were pumped we took the risk because it was awesome.
- beef tongue: really interesting mix of flavors. The fresh herbs really bring this one home. Barely comes in second to the ray fish.
- potted rillettes: a mix of duck and pork belly I believe, mixed with blueberry jam and served with dang good sourdough bread. Brought out first as an app, and won us over immediately.
- Roasted cauliflower. Server recommended this and the avocado salad from the vegetable list. My girlfriend actually liked this more than the beef dish, and while I liked it, it didn't wow me.

At the end, our server brought out a little butterscotch dessert with a candle on it for my girlfriend, on the house. Was a mousse-pudding mix, and it was fantastic.

Also, if they have Red Chair on nitro from Deschutes, get it.

This is my second time at the Publican, and I think this visit cemented it as the best dining experience I've had in Chicago. Prefer it even to Girl and the Goat. Is especially good with a group, b/c you get to try even more dishes.

Wow. What a disappointment. From the rude hostesses, slow service and subpar food, would certainly not recommend. Thought meat was supposed to be their thing as well but the sausage, picnic plate and prosciutto were all lacking in flavor. Pork belly- like bacon was tasty but doesn't merit a visit just for it. The michelada was undrinkable, the bloody mary just average.

Came here for brunch this morning and was very impressed! Great atmosphere and good service- a friend needed a vegan meal and they were able to accommodate her on the spot despite not having vegan dishes on the menu.

The communal seating is interesting.  I like meeting other people so it worked for me, but if you're more private, they also have "high tops" which are four person tables with stools.  These hightops, however, have little cubbies which decrease the leg room when you are sitting on the tall stools.   The men in our party, who are both 6 ft tall, found it uncomfortable, just bad design.  

Several people have mentioned the noise level.  On top of high ceilings which echo the conversations, the night we were there, some kind of hip hop music was being pumped in overhead.  Besides being extremely loud and unnecessary, it was very incongruent with the minimal decor and clientele.  When we asked the waitress about perhaps turning it down, she said  it was "part of the vibe."  Meanwhile, we could hardly hear her explanation of the menu.  It seems that, if your food is not enough to create a vibe for your restaurant, that you have to jazz it up with an overhead party, perhaps that's not a good sign.

She told us that the signature dishes involved pig, and highly recommended the pork shank, which we ordered, along with potted rillettes.  These were both mediocre.  The shank, surprisingly, hardly tasted of pork, having been marinated in or sauced with a too-sweet concoction.  The texture of the meat was very good, and the braised kale was delicious, but the meat was confoundingly tasteless.  The rillettes, consisting of shredded braised duck and pork, also had a nice texture, but too much raspberry jam overcame the distinct and subtle flavors of the meat.  The sourdough toast was a nice textural taste as well, but also a big taste in contrast with the meat.  

The vegetable dishes were much better.  The beet salad was delicious.  The BBQ carrots were also very tasty, smoky with a creamy dill sauce, not oversauced, and nice addition of pecan.  The mushrooms were less successful, not enough mushrooms, and too much toast, but otherwise well done tastes.  

The service was good, the waitress knowledgeable and attentive.  I appreciated that I was able to taste the wines by the glass because the wine list is not familiar (one from Croatia).  I eventually settled on a cab/merlot mix which was very good and a generous pour.

Overall, a solid farm-to-table restaurant (it was nice to have the references to specific farms where the food was sourced) but disappointing because it's supposedly known for the meat, which was nothing special.  Maybe the fish is better.  Vegetable dishes were best for us.   And not the place if you want to have much conversation.

This is a pretty awesome place. I like layout with the wooden tables, lighting, and family style seating. The food was delicious, well seasoned, and came out hot. We had the bread, pork shoulder, and their signature half chicken meal. Again, everything was really tasty. Service was slow at the beginning, but once we ordered everything was timely and service was on point. Definitely recommend this place as it has become one of our new favorite spots when visiting Chicago!

We were seated at one of the communal tables which was fine but the booths looked really cool and I wished we had requested one of those beforehand when I made the reservation. We ordered way too much food or possibly just a combination of too many heavy dishes as we were stuffed even before the last course came out. Here's a breakdown of what we ordered:

- Frites and Fried Eggs: Okay dish, pretty much exactly as described.
- Chicken Liver Mouse with Toast: This is the dish that destroyed our appetite for the rest of the meal...there was so much bread, probably 5 giant slices. I think we were expecting like small crostini slices. Value wise it was very good :P
- Fried Cauliflower: This was my favorite dish of the night. I'm a huge meat lover so I wasn't super excited about this one when we ordered it. But it was a pleasant surprise and oh so good. The batter is light and airy and the sauce added great flavor.
- Scallops: Solid dish, but they need to do a better job of cleaning the scallops as it was a bit grainy.
- Guinea Hen: The sauce was absolutely phenomenal for this dish (I think it was fava bean based) The guinea hen was cooked well and was served with some delicious, tender sausage.

Service here was attentive and friendly. Bathrooms here are interesting, there's a vestibule that opens up to multiple dual gender stalls and in the middle there are communal sinks. Overall, I had a pretty good experience here, but I think we could've done a better job ordering. So I would love to come back sometime and try some of their other dishes, particularly some more vegetable dishes since the cauliflower really surprised me.
Fries with eggs was great, especially with the mild aoli and a glass of Belgian Saison Dupont draught beer.

Awesome German beer hall vibe!  Seating is communal meaning you will sit across from your partner and have strangers on either side of you.  There are also a few stand up tables and very few private booth(made private by saloon doors).

Came here for Brunch on Saturday and had a great time!  I understand the brunch menu changes from Saturday to Sunday so make sure you check the menu out for the right date before you go.  I made reservations thankfully since this place was packed at 1pm on a Saturday. My mom and I ordered the fresh coffee, fresh orange juice, mimosa's(for her)and a smokey bloody mary(for me).  They ended up being fine choices, the coffee was exceptional (2 sugar lumps please) and the Bloody Mary ended up falling flat.
We shared the waffle, avocado toast and maple bacon.  There are no words for the waffle other than outstanding.  The fresh apricot preserves were fantastic! The avocado toast was great with the egg poached perfectly.  The bacon was good but not great.  That was a little disappointing since everyone seems to rave about it, I'll give it a try again just to make sure it wasn't just an off day.  Service was great, our server was phenomenal and helped guide us through the menu and constantly checked on us and refilled glasses of both water and coffee.

FYI a few tips before you go - the google maps directions do not bring you to the right address, it brings you over to the Publican Market across the street.  If you have never been here before that gets a little confusing since there is no signage on The Publican from any side other than on the front door. It's loud so you will have to pretty much shout at your partner sitting across from you. Also remember that while it's polite to say "hi" to your new table mates or stare at their food and ask them about it, it's not polite to actively provided feedback to their conversation.

I went here for my birthday for the first time with my hubby, our 2 kids, and my brother. The first thing that came to mind was "Why the heck have he not taken me here before???" LOL

I love pork. And if you love pork, you would love this place too.

I recommend the hams (my fave was the one from VA). Also, I loved the pork rinds. I also enjoyed the Trout.

My only con is the seating. We sat in those enclosed booths. I felt like a caged animal and it was so cramped. Other than that, the food will get you pass the uncomfortably seating situation.

A meat-eaters paradise. I had been wanting to try this place for a while after hearing so many good things, and was not disappointed!

I had made reservations for my boyfriend and I on a Wednesday evening. Reservations at this time were totally unnecessary, as there were plenty of open tables and seats. We requested to sit outside on the patio and were seated right away. Overall the atmosphere was nice and simple with a rustic farm feel.

The service was fantastic, our server was very attentive and the food runners were very on top of getting our water glasses refilled and empty plates out of the way. The food is served 'family style' and meant to be shared. We started with the charcuterie plate - a good selection of meats and we were big fans of the mustard it came with. The avocado salad came next and was very tasty as well.

We then split the pork belly and farm chicken platter. I was in love with the frites the farm chicken came with (I suspect they were doused in truffle oil - yum!), and the garnishments for the pork belly complemented it very well. It was all so much food and we ended up having to box some up to take home. I will definitely be returning to try brunch!

Tried lots of things; all of them were very good. Particularly enjoyed the squid and the blood sausage dish.

Our service was very uneven. Probably wouldn't go back.

One of the best meals we had in Chicago!   And definitely the best server - Chad was awesome.  Chill, but present, super helpful and attentive without being too obtrusive.  He always showed up at the perfect moment.  Start with the bacon, it's delish.  We went for brunch - fried chicken and grits were so, so good.   The rest of the group had biscuits and gravy and the avocado toast, and all of us raved on its amazingness.    Well worth the trip from downtown.

The Publican is a great place to bring friends and talk over great food. More pork-centric than its other sister restaurants, the Publican shines when it delivers porky goodness. It's another communal table style restaurant, where you'll sit at a long table or at the bar elbow to elbow with strangers.

We started with the Potted Rillettes, a small jam-sized jar of duck and pork, topped with strawberries and served with excellent toasted rustic bread. It's kind of a build-your-own open faced sandwich, and the flavor of the meat coupled with the occasional strawberry is surprisingly good.

The Barbecue Carrots were a spicy and flavorful standout, served with creamy herb dressing, dill and pecans. The carrots are various types of heirlooms, all delicious. It's a combination of flavors that I wouldn't have thought of, but it works very well together. The combination of the herb dressing and barbecue spices is not to be missed.

Our main meals were not quite as flavorful as our first courses, although they were still very well prepared. The Country Rib, served with romesco, spring onions and turnip, was obviously cooked by someone who knows how to cook great pork, and and lightly seasoned. It was their choice to flavor the meat lightly so that the quality can shine, which it did, but I still found myself wanting a bit more flavor since the other flavor combinations we had here were so unique and excellent.

The Yellowtail, served with wax beans, green beans and cherry tomatoes was interesting, in a delicate, creamy kind of sauce. The fish was a bit fishy tasting, but was excellently prepared. Overall, I found the flavors of this dish didn't meld quite so well as other choices on the menu.

For dessert we had the Panna Cotta, flavored with sweet tea, kumquats, thai basil and honey caramel. This is a truly unique dessert, and I found the strong flavors of the thai basil and kumquat to work well together. It is certainly one of the more unique desserts I have tried.

Overall, it seems that The Publican effectively straddles the line between great quality food prepared simply and taking unique flavor combinations to the next level. If you have a group of people that includes both foodies and meat and potatoes types, everyone will be able to find something to their taste here.

pics.caption: Panna Cotta, flavored with sweet tea, kumquats, thai basil and honey caramel...a truly unique dessert!
Barbecue carrots...a spicy and delicious must try!
Potted Rillettes...finely shredded duck & pork served on a small jam pot w/strawberries. Build your own open faced sandwich!

review.des: My favorite brunch spot, I love how the menu changes every weekend, it's a great way to spice things up! Had a pound cake once and ate the entire thing. Also the avocado scramble is amazing. Great service too!

Meat and beer lover's paradise.  This place is still one of the best places to try unique beers in Chciago.

Anand

I know I would like The Publican the moment I stepped inside the Restaurant.

The setting here is lively and intimate at the same time. Love that huge communal table  right in the medium of the dining area. Kind of reminds me of eating in a medieval castle with the knights and ladies.

Just make sure you make a reservation which can be easily done using OpenTable!

We were here for breakfast/brunch so we shared:

Red Wine Poached Eggs ($13) - la quercia proscuitto, sourdough and bearnaise

Oven Baked Sourdough Pancake ($14) - bacon wrapped chicken thigh, breakfast sausage & Burton's maple syrup

Both were quite unique and well executed. The food were so good that we already decided to come back for dinner next time when we were in town to try out other items on the menu!

Service was friendly and efficient!

Highly recommended!

We were a party of 5. Showed up about 20 minutes early for our reservation and waited until our reservation time to actually get seated. Mind you, the location that we ultimately sat in was unoccupied the entire time we had been waiting. Fine... You have this fancy vibe. I get it. It's like a night club that has a line outside but when you walk in, the place is empty.

$65 a head for a chefs choice menu.

Chicharones
1 oyster each
Smoked mackerel
Beet salad
Smoked carrots
Eggplant dish
Some sort of crab dish I believe
Whole chicken entree with french fries
3 desserts

11 courses. The only course that was large (our entree) was the chicken which is listed on the menu for $35. Every other course was normal size as if a diner had just ordered off the menu. I believe this place is known for pork... No pork dish of substance was served (I'm sorry chicharones don't count).

So we got a total of 11 courses which averages out to about $29 a course ($65 x 5 people = $325 / 11 course)

I'm sorry... But that's a total rip off. I'm not poor, I make money, and I spend money. If you're going to charge me $29 for a plate of carrots, chicharones, eggplant, beet salad, or dessert. Something is off here. This doesn't seem to me like a chefs menu. It sound more like a business owner trying to capitalize.

This all being said, the dining experience was nice and the food was tasty but not worth the price tag.

I did not see the progression in our meal... I would recommend you thoughtfully curate the meal.

I really have NO idea why this place has received so much hype.

Ambiance is so-so at best, server was average to poor, but most of all, I found the brunch menu very limited and not enticing in the least. I had to force myself to choose something from the menu, as I was dining with a big group. The food was SERIOUSLY AVERAGE AT BEST. I would definitely NOT return here.

Bottom line: Don't waste your $$ or time.

Ate here with a large group in town for a food trade show- high standards and nobody was disappointed!  
   First off, big props to the service team.  They bussed vacated seats like a NASCAR pit crew.  My water glass was attended to like I was in a hospital recovering from dehydration.  And our plates were changed so often I thought our table's server assistant had OCD.  The service really stood out.
   We had the tasting menu, so we ran the gauntlet.  It was daunting.  Items that stick out were: charcuterie plate (all done in house- very impressive variety & quality), sable fish canape, broccoli tempura, pork belly, some dish with goat cheese and mini potato chips atop a red sauce, asparagus dish also with a goat cheese sauce base I think.  I never saw a menu so I don't know the names or all the ingredients but we probably had 10-12 dishes and those were my favorites.  
   The Slovenian orange wine and Serbian red Janko were the table favorites.

So I've had the Publican on my Chicago bucket list for over two years.  I now will be asking myself why why why did it take me so long to go here?  

This place is so cool from the ambiance to the award winning food; you simply cannot lose dining here.  

The dining room is like a hipsters paradise dream apartment/concert venue.  Beautifully decorated from the Edison bulb lighting all the way to the tasteful pig portraits aligning the walls.  

The restaurant is very clean, pristine silverware, and cool glassware.  The center of the restaurant is family seating and surrounded by cool little enclosed booths along the outside.

The food is every bit as spectacular as the restaurants decor.  I started with a side of super thick bacon.  It was like ham, bacon, and the perfect amount of fat congealing into SUPER BACON.  Needless to say my bacon world has forever been changed.  

I then had the fried chicken.  Perfect white moist center and a flavorful crispy crusty outside.  This is what southerners dream about at night.  The fried pickles were a nice accompaniment and the food was plated thoughtfully and masterfully.  

A couple of additional side notes:
The bathrooms are really clean and really nice.  
The fried chicken comes with a side of hot sauce.  Use caution it is for real spicy!
Get a cup of coffee it is specifically blended for the Publican and it is delicious.

Bottom line I highly recommend dining here.  I will definitely be back with family and friends.  5 stars, enough said!

The Publican came with some good reviews, so coming in LA I was eager to try it. We were seated by the friendly staff at our own booth which meant we got to sit behind a pair of swinging chest high doors, I had to wonder how many servers banged their elbows on them and play it off like it's nothing.

The menu changes daily, so I had no idea what to expect other than high quality, fresh food. The Publican delivered.

Beet salad - Fresh and flavorful

Flounder Crudo - likewise.

3 Tastes of ham - from what I understand these are smoked in-house and sure enough, it is delicious. It's a wee salty so it goes well on the bread they provide.

Here's the problem: 3 slices of sourdough for a trough of ham didn't seem like an appropriate ratio. Not a problem, we just ask for more bread. We do that... bread doesn't come, we ask a second server since our original server sort of disappeared. We sit and stare at half a plate of ham, picking off small pieces while we wait. By the time the bread comes most of the ham is gone, and now we have 8 large pieces of warm toasted bread  (the original bread was room temp so this was a welcome change) to a few slices of ham. Dammit! So we took the bread home... thrilling story I know, but I would like to urge the Publican to get the bread to Ham ratio right, as this was the only thing impeding an otherwise lovely experience.

Let me start by saying that the customer service here is really great and the atmosphere and design was unique and fun, but all of this together cannot save the overpriced wretchedness they call food.

I came here for dinner, they were very quick to seat us.  The seating arrangement was awesome, there were private booths and communal tables.  The fun pretty much stopped there.  We ordered porchetta, pork belly, brussel sprouts, and the apple salad.  The apple salad was really good for what it was...an apple salad.  Everything else just tasted like I swallowed a spoonful of salt.  

For the price they are charging for their food, I expected better plating, it just looked cafeteria style and unappetizing. I just imagine a fat lady with a mustache ladeling my food and plopping it on a plate.  It just looked like a big blob of mush, i couldn't tell what was what.  I do not mind paying for overpriced meals if its worth it (i.e girl and the goat) but this was just ridiculous.  We ordered 5 plates worth of food for four people, it was over 200 dollars and no one was remotely full.

It really upsets me to have to give this restaurant such a low rating.  The food was excellent, but the service is what warranted only 2 stars.

We were a party of 5 with a reservation for brunch. The server was nice and did answer our questions.  However after taking our order for drinks and food, we waited.....and waited....and waited. After almost 20 minutes, no drinks came, but then to our surprise our food did......well some of it.

We ordered 4 main dishes and 2 sides.  2 of the main dishes came out.  We were faced with a dilemma, eat in front of the others or wait and let our food get cold. We decided to eat....still no drinks.  Then we asked about the drinks, they finally showed up (dropped off by someone who was not our server).  Then one of the sides did....then another......then finally the other main dishes.  We ate the sides after having finished our main dishes.....we ordered them as a side, to eat with our meal....so that didn't happen.  It was a HOT day and I asked for a glass of ice for my coffee.....that came 15-20 minutes later after asking 2 more times.  

The waiter only came back one time the entire meal to check on us, and we were offered coffee refills at the end of our meal.

The food was amazing, and I highly recommend the red wine poached eggs. It would have really been nice to eat my sides with my main dish, sip my bloody mary before I got my food, and to have been able to eat with my friends that I went to brunch with,

The Publican was a very interesting dining experience. It's communal dining and it's done very good.

My tip would be to skip the large dishes, and get a lot of well done small ones. It just works better that way.

pics.caption: oh this beer menu is largeeee

review.des: Yummy! Love the red wine poached eggs. The seating a bit too tight. But overall, not bad for brunch.

Disclaimer: I am not a foodie. Just your average Joe going to get a meal. So if you have a very refined palate or whatever than just ignore this review. I'm writing from a regular guys point of view.

What a waste of money. Horrible service. Unappetizing food. As many reviewers said the coffee was really amazing.

Went here for brunch. The potatoes were purple which kind of threw me off. But everything was served in a bowl which would be fine but everything kind of congealed together bc it took the server 45 minutes to get us the food. The eggs were chewy and not very fluffy. I should've taken pictures.

Also Just a warning that I t's one of those places that gives you very little portions I guess you're supposed to savor. Some of it was really good (the parts that didn't get stuck to my bowl) but the majority of the food did not fill me up.

Highly discourage you from going here unless you're a foodie. Which it appears that most other reviewers are.

Honestly, there are so many better brunch places in Chicago. Food and service were mediocre at best. Communal dining makes for a very loud atmosphere. They were out of Earl Grey tea, so we were forced into ordering coffee. Unfortunately, our cream curdled once in the coffee. The French toast was dry and very bland. I won't be back.

Seriously, who doesn't love the Publican?!? It's farm to table, some community style tables and some booths.

Inside tip: your food takes the same whether or not you sit next to strangers! Make the best of it, ask what they got if something looks good, or bad!

Went here once for dinner, once for brunch.  Both great experiences.  For dinner we started with taste of 3 meats.  It's seriously a platter of prosciutto, all you can eat, all amazing!  Do you have any ideas how as a young girl in NYC I would take apart my mozzarella, pepper, and prosciutto hero to just savor the pork goodness?!? Ok maybe I have a slight pork addiction.  I've heard the best entree is really the farm chicken, which I haven't tried, but several people including former employees have said it's the best!  

Just go, enjoy the farm to table pork goodness.  Eating should be an experience.  The best restaurants give you food story.  Your meal, expensive or cheap should be something you can talk about.

How is it possible that the pork belly PORK BELLY PORK BELLY PORK BELLY isn't on yelp highlights is somewhat beyond me. This was by far the most amazing delectable dish we ordered. I usually let the boy have the second half of whatever dish we are sharing after quarter first taste servings but he knew with the fat smile on my face no way jose. Nearly ordered a second serving but had to have some self control at $25 or so a pop and more food coming. Sounds odd I'm sure but I usually don't like American prepared pork belly - love my grandmas flavorful cuts with a fork tender melt in your mouth style and this was it - it actually sort of tastes like Chinese red pork (cha siu) sweet with crispy top but using pork belly...genius! Just occurred to me.

Anyways fun decor with all the bulbs and communal tables. There are some booths and tables on the side but major pro at the large table is seeing some dishes out before making your decision.

Overall fantastic and fun. Reasonable to walk back to Gold Coast (2 miles) after dinner and check out the city & walk off dinner.

Sorry, this one's harsh.

This dinner, for what it cost, was easily my "worst dinner of 2016." Nothing wowed us. Everything underwhelmed us. I can only applaud the waiter, who did a very good job of describing the menu items and answering questions.

We had a very meat-centric dinner, as follows:

Spicy pork rinds
Merguez sausage
Suckling pig
Grilled squid
Farm chicken

The pork rinds were the best food item, the squid, the worst. Get frilled squid someplace like Tac Quick if you want to taste what delicious grilled squid with a kick-ass sauce tastes like.

The sausage, blah. The cheesey stuff that accompanied it was pretty tasty.

The suckling pig, little bits of pig parts in a too-sweet broth. Not enough pig parts to even conjure up a suckling pig image. Just dreadful, if you've ever actually had suckling pig.

Farm chicken, not bad, but not good. Fries, a joke. If your fries can't even compete with a decent hot dog place, why even bother? Also, definitely not "frites," at least in my view. And the summer sausage, we both tried it, then left the rest. Like a bad, tough hot dog? We had trouble cutting it with our knives. Again, why bother?

I'm happy to be the one-star review among the way higher, way more effervescent reviews.

We had brunch here with family on a Sunday. We had reservations so were seated when we arrived. They have long wooden tables and chairs and you sit next to other patrons. I ordered the crab scramble and it was soft and fluffy, topped with bits of crab, and served with 3 slices of buttered toast. This was a very pleasant dining experience and I would definitely like to try this place for lunch and dinner too!

Came for breakfast at 10:30a on a Saturday and was seated immediately. We sat outside since it was a nice day and they have heated lamps. They have the most creative and delicious hashbrowns I've tasted, comes in a cute flat cube with perfectly crisped potatoes all around the outside, which tender strips inside the crust. Ordered the quiche for my meal, super tender, and came with salad on the side. Friend ordered the biscuit plate and I got to try a piece of the biscuit which was very flaky and flavorful. Will definitely be back to try more items and also check it out for dinner.
The hostess was so unpleasant...acting as though she was doing us a favor to seat us, so we decided to leave. We didn't try the food.

I want to give 1 star so i will.

Went here because my gf's friend is in town and heard about this place.

-I dont get the vibe in here : country expensive? What genre is that?

-So its barnyard seating? Why do people think that is cool?

- so everyone in here is wearing auto mechanic shirts. Are they going to change my oil while Im here? Because if so this place would be great!

-lighting is stupid, and i like globe lamps usually. Totally overdoing it and no logic to layout other than rows of lights not spread out well. Too tight.

- wow, five of us and we ordered 7 things. Soooo starving still... I think ill go eat a hot dog now.

-ordered 7 things, 4 of them were fried and 4 of them had mayonnaise in it, serious?! This place sucks.

- so we sit in a "booth" and its like a barn stall with doors. I get it: it looks like a barn in here, great, so? Damn this place sucks.

-so i order a beer that normally costs 6-7$... Good beer. Its $11 here, SERIOUSLY?! I dont get it theres other bars around here with reasonably priced beer.

-location is the only things that makes this place work. I dare them to open 10 blocks west and watch it fail. If you like expensive quality food, go to boeufhaus or something that place is at least put together well.

Sorry everyone, im done with my rant, just left my $50 portion so i guess ill go eat dinner now.

EOM

It's very loud and can cost some dough but the food is really good and well worth it.

We did the tasting thing and we couldn't eat anymore when they brought us more...it was no problem to get it boxed up which was cool.

Great dishes with really cool flavors. The pork belly thing with the polenta and peas and the fried onion thing stood out for me but every thing was excellent.

You think when you're just sitting down that maybe the service was slow but once it gets rolling the service was excellent.

Will go back for sure but maybe at a less busy time for the loudness.

Sometimes you walk in a place and you already know you're going to love it and have a great time. That's exactly what happened here. This was the # one place my brother wanted to bring me to on my most recent visit to Chicago. Everything was awesome. For food, we ordered oysters (fresh and tasty), their spicy pork rinds (get them), chacuterie (head cheese was my favorite and the rhubarb jam, soo good!), Artichoke Falafel (great), Soft Shell Crab (so freaking good!!), Lamb (perfectly crisp exterior with perfectly juicy melt in your mouth inside; the lentils were awesome too), we also got a taste of their pork tenderloin wrapped in pork belly which was tasty, especially the slightly burnt parts of the pork belly. Their amaro barrel aged negroni is the best negroni I"ve ever had and I've had a fair amount of negronis. I also got their Last Word cocktail which was not on the menu. It normally comes with gin, but on our server's suggestion I got it with mezcal. It also had chartruese, luxardo, and lime. It was excellent. They also have a great list of beer (both bottled and on draft) and wine and many variety of spirits to choose from. We also got their chocolate custard and napoleon desserts. Both were excellent finishers and beautifully presented.

An absolute highlight is the service top to bottom. They truly care and do everything possible to ensure you have a memorable time. Tracy, one of the managers I think, is easily one of the most warm and thoughtful people I've come across in a restaurant. Matt, the bar manager, is equally as awesome. Our server David, plus Hector and Carlos were great too. The day we came for dinner also happened to be the final day of the National Restaurant Association Show. As a result, they were packed. I imagine they are normally packed, but on prime days/nights, not on a Monday. As packed as they were, they were hustling and service was exceptional. Aside from the huge paintings of, well, huge pigs which were somehow cool and cute, the decor is pretty plan. It felt kind of like a super beige beer hall to me. It works though and I literally loved everything about this place.

Simply put, service was outstanding, food creative and delicious, and cocktails fantastic. Not much more can be said other than I wish I could take this restaurant with me everywhere. If I still lived in Chicago, I'd be here, a lot and definitely will make it a staple stop every time I'm back in town.

The first time I went to the Publican was about four years ago. My sister and I went to have an early Sunday brunch. She ordered something delicious and I wanted to be skinnier so I got a simple salad. The food and atmosphere were inviting and warm and then suddenly the unthinkable happened-

A hair.

In my salad.

We notified our waiter and he was mortified- management also came and apologized profusely. Our meal was on the house and we were given a box of sweets to take home. I wasn't even upset anymore at that point... I'd actually never had an establishment be so quick to respond.

I didn't go back until this past fall with my boyfriend. Again, we had a wonderful brunch which was divine (no hair!) - and since then have gone for brunch a couple times with friends. The food is always high quality, the staff care about your experience and the bathroom sink looks like it's from Harry Potter.

One of my favorite spots.

We seriously tried super hard to find a complaint about this place. Ultimately, we decided the stools were slightly too tall for the high rise tables.

Seriously, this was some of the best, most flavorful and well-balanced food we've ever had. Service was fantastic, our server Kevin was both a joy and very helpful in recommendations, and the beer selection was wonderful. Above average pricing, but worth the expense if you're looking for a lovely dining experience.

Highlights: taste of three hams, sweet potatoes, and their custom brew coffee.

This may be best known as a meat place, but I've had some of the best vegetarian meals in Chicago here. I'm pleased they've moved the veggie section from the bottom corner right up to the top, I think it shows they're starting to understand that people are coming to eat their excellent, fresh vegetable-based dishes.

Usually I go with people also eating meat, on a recent visit we all ended up eating veggie and trying all of the "side dishes" and sharing. Consistently excellent.

They also have a fantastic beer selection, and the waffle dessert is always tasty, if you have room.

I don't love the acoustics, and try to go right when they open rather than wait for a shared table, but the food is worth that bit of inconvenience.

This place was amazing. The service was attentive but not overbearing, and generally super lovely. I also have quite a few allergies that limited what we could share as a table, but the staff was accommodating and very kind about it. The drinks were great, albeit a smaller than usual list of wines by the glass. Every dish we got was amazing - the brussel sprouts were crisp and refreshing, the bass was stunning, and the lamb chops and suckling pig were two of the best things I've ever eaten.

The desserts were also so freaking delicious - got the ice cream cake and the apple crisp (came with cinnamon toast crunch ice cream which was basically like left-over cereal milk in the best way :) ). Also, the post-dinner aperitivos were stellar; I'd highly recommend the post-pork drink!
Mimosas are good, bacon is AMAZING, seating is a bit weird because we got a booth that was like a box, the menu selection is not super varied but I liked that they had oysters.

pics.caption: Frites with fried egg. Simple but yummy!

review.des: This is a fun re-creation of a public house concept. There is community seating centrally, with stand-up tables scattered around. The outer seating is booth seating enclosed by swinging doors. The menu is seasonal and interesting. We went for brunch, which filled up quickly after opening. The service is pretty speedy too. We had the porchetta sanwhich, which is this amazing pork topped with pimento cheese spread on a brioche bun, topped with a fried egg. It was sooooo good! The chimichurri quail was a hearty meal, served with a good helping of cornbread, baked beans, and a poached egg. The crab scramble was delicate and the flavor of the crab shine through despite the other ingredients. It was served with buttery crunchy bread. We had a side of hash browns which were golden and crunchy, and I think they were better than the Waffle House counterpart. The Bloody Mary was quite spicy, so do ask to hold the tobacco if you aren't a fan of spice- they make their own mix and it's good by itself. Our coffee cups and water glasses remained filled promptly. This place is worth a visit! They take reservations so be sure to make one!

I came here for a Sunday brunch before a day on the water. So we wanted something substantial and that would stick with us. So I was told to go here and get ready for large portions. That we got for sure. We arrived way early and were stuck waiting for a bit. I did see that they have a meat market across the street too. Now I was excited for a good breakfast and get to see a real meat market. Ok drooling begins now. So their menu is not real big but it does have some good looking dishes to choose from. So I went right into the sausage world since it was made right over there. I got the cajun sausage over red beans and a soft egg. This dish was good but lacked the real cajun seasoning that I have had before. So it is the Chicago style cajun was tasty and the sausage was also good. The wife had the brisket with a couple of sunny side up eggs. I will say that the eggs were fabulous they were cooked perfectly and had a flavor that screamed out hen house out back. So I also went in for some of the house or across the street made bacon and breakfast sausage. Neither really wowed me but I'm not easily wowed when it comes to sausage. Like the wife said they are making tons of sausage and I make small batch with a ton of love. I mean it was good it just needed more seasonings. In all the place was beautiful with the old wooden support beam still in place. Then the wife excused herself to do those lady things. She came back and said you have to go to the bathroom right. She then gave me that look and you need to go to the bathroom as she tugged on my hand. Ok bathroom break. This was too cool they had a fountain style multi uses hand washing station in the foyer. There, there was 5 doors. 3 women and 2 means room stales. This most be a Chicago thing cause I have seen it a few times here. But inside the men's room was normal with the old fashion toilets with no sink. But one of the ladies rooms had a giant wooden beam inside in the corner.
